magnus80
2017-09-19 23:29:18
 
 def self.center_menu_check
    ex = ['1, '2', '3']
    items = find_elements(id: 'tvDrawerText').map(&amp;:text)
    # puts items
    raise "#{items} not like #{ex}" if ex.sort != items.sort
  end

ar_cucu
2017-09-20 23:49:29

@ar_cucu has joined the channel

Gem
2017-09-21 08:17:35

@magnus80 In those scenarios you could then do something like

And I see "First tab" enabled |tab|
  tab_checker(tab, enabled)
end

-----

def tab_checker(tab, visibility)
  # code to find specified tab
  # code to check tab's attributes for visibility

end

Mascarua
2017-09-22 10:38:58

When using the CLI for cucumber-ruby, we are only obtaining json output; is there a way to obtain other formats (specifically XML)? Thanks!

Gem
2017-09-22 10:50:00

Hey @Mascarua here are the available built-in options: http://www.rubydoc.info/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/Cucumber/Cli/Options

Gem
2017-09-22 10:51:11

So by default, no XML specifically.

Mascarua
2017-09-22 10:51:29

Thank you, @Gem.

Gem
2017-09-22 10:51:42

There is the ability to make your own and also some others that others have made here though: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki/Custom-Formatters

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber
cucumber - Cucumber monorepo - polyglot home for Cucumber building blocks
Gem
2017-09-22 10:52:03

That also includes a link to the ruby gem for outputting in Allure-XML format.

Gem
2017-09-22 10:52:10

You're welcome!

marius
2017-09-28 05:46:35

quick question with this new improvement in 3.0, if I want a step to capture either 1 or multiple intâ€™s. Any way to do that without capturing it as a string and splitting it up after?

marius
2017-09-28 05:50:30

preferably captured as an array

marius
2017-09-28 06:06:17

Then the 1st employee does service 48582 Then the 2nd employee does service 48857, 48907, 49082

marius
2017-09-28 06:53:12

Never mind. Helped actually reading your blogpost, aslak.

marius
2017-09-28 06:53:20

Sorry about that

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-09-28 06:59:25

@marius: define a parameter type with regexp /[\d,\s]+/ and transformer: -&gt; (ints) { ints.split(',').map(&amp;:to_i) }

marius
2017-09-28 06:59:49

Exactly what I came up with! Thanks anyways!

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-09-28 06:59:56

Nice one!

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-09-29 02:32:07

@marius they're reusable regardless of where you put them, just like step definitions

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-09-29 02:32:28

Conventionally I recommend putting them in env/parameter_types.rb

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-09-29 02:32:47

Err features/support/parameter_types.rb

marius
2017-09-29 02:33:54

2017-09-29 02:34:54

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-09-29 02:35:32

Cucumber will automatically require all .rb files under features/****/**

2017-10-02 08:01:14

Hi all. How can I set '(', ')' in regular expressions? I used step like 'I wait 5(ms)' -> /^I wait (\d+)\(ms\)$/. Now I receive an error has 0 capture groups ([]), but there were 1 parameter types (["ms\\"]) cucumber 3.0.1

Gem
2017-10-02 08:34:34

@Aslak HellesÃ¸y ^ that seems like another edge case similar to the one I found

Gem
2017-10-02 08:42:30

2017-10-02 13:09:03

@Hamster the bug is fixed, but not released: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/254 - @Gem it's the same bug indeed.

GitHub
Cucumber expressions fix regexp parsing by aslakhellesoy Â· Pull Request #254 Â· cucumber/cucumber
Summary Fix how regexps are parsed Details See #253 for a description of the problem. This is an alternative implementation which leverages the existing regexp parser in TreeRegexp, which means con...
ðŸ‘ Gem, Hamster

Brent
2017-10-05 09:48:05

@Brent has joined the channel

Brent
2017-10-05 09:50:19

Hi all, does anyone know if it is possible to use instance variables defined within other step definitions within a defined ParameterType?

Brent
2017-10-05 09:50:42

For example:

Brent
2017-10-05 09:51:38

ParameterType( name: 'received_message', regexp: /the received "(.**?)" message/, transformer: lambda do |msg_type| @buffer["received #{msg_type} message"] end )

matt-SmartBear
2017-10-05 11:41:35

@Brent I donâ€™t know but Iâ€™d guess theyâ€™re running in the same World as everything else. Did you try it?

Brent
2017-10-05 12:08:18

Yes, I did try it but it did not work. I assumed it would be able to grab instance variables from the World since it is part of it but it looks like however ParameterTypes is defined the lambda itself only has the parameters captured from the regex and nothing else.

Gem
2017-10-05 12:33:20

That's an interesting tidbit to find out! Perhaps we need to work to expand parameters to make sure things end up in world?

Gem
2017-10-05 12:33:43

Though if it's due to a restriction of the lambda, that may not be possible/ideal?

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-10-05 13:15:11

@Brent I don't think you can, but I definitely think that's the way it should be! Cucumber.js has the same limitation, and it's already stung me, so I hope to fix that for both Ruby and JavaScript soon. Funnily enough I tend to prioritise bugfixes/improvements that annoy me personally. How selfish of me.

ðŸ‘ Gem
ðŸ˜‚ Ryan Chapman
Brent
2017-10-05 13:19:16

@Aslak HellesÃ¸y Awesome, thanks for the update!

Eyal LEZMY (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/U7E1KMHA9)
<p>Hi guys, I have a question about the <code>cucumber</code> Ruby tool available with <code>gem</code>. Is it possible to use the <code>--format</code> option as the <code>--format/--plugin</code> param on the Java runner?</p>
Slack Conversation
eyal
2017-10-09 09:09:34

Actually I'm working on Genymotion, an Android emulator. We want to improve our integration with your tool and particularly we want be to add some logic executed during the test runs (at the beginning of each test for example). It is possible to do so with the cucumber-jvm by implementing a Formatter and the user can link it when he executes the tests (with the --format or --plugin options).

eyal
2017-10-09 09:10:20

I would like to know if there is an equivalent for Ruby with the cucumber command

brasmusson
2017-10-09 10:01:18

@eyal Yes, see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/features/docs/extending_cucumber/custom_formatter.feature#L16-L36

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber-ruby
cucumber-ruby - Cucumber for Ruby
brasmusson
2017-10-09 10:05:34

See also http://www.rubydoc.info/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/Cucumber/Events

eyal
2017-10-09 12:24:12

       @@ -1,2 +1,2 @@
       -[["html", {}, "file1"], ["html", {}, "file2"]]
       +[["html", {}, "file2"], ["html", {}, "file1"]]

2017-10-10 08:20:28

enkessler
2017-10-10 11:21:14

enkessler
2017-10-10 11:22:19

Oh. Nevermind. Yeah, that's the file system returning files in a different order accross operating systems.

Gem
2017-10-10 11:23:44

@enkessler Anything I can do to overcome that and/or help things work better?

enkessler
2017-10-10 11:24:07

OS file systems will do whatever they want. If order is important on our end, we can write separate tests for each OS. If we don't care about order, then feel free to do a sort on the array and call it a day. Or just use the match_array assertion and then order doesn't matter.

enkessler
2017-10-10 11:29:24

@Gem Let me know if that doesn't solve it.

Gem
2017-10-10 11:51:19

Thanks @enkessler!

Gem
2017-10-10 11:51:43

Manually switching the order in the test makes it pass too haha

Gem
2017-10-10 11:51:47

enkessler
2017-10-10 12:08:14

enkessler
2017-10-10 14:26:43

2017-10-10 14:57:45

enkessler
2017-10-10 15:00:47

Gem
2017-10-10 15:05:39

enkessler
2017-10-10 20:14:01

Update: after actually looking at the code, it has nothing to do with file systems at all. It seems to come down to the fact that Ruby does not guarantee the sort order of objects if they have the same comparison value and the data being used in the test does fall under that category. Different Ruby version, potentially different sort order. Luckily, order does not appear to be significant to the behavior being tested.

ðŸ‘ Gem
Gem
2017-10-10 20:22:39

For those who'd like more, my environment experiencing this is a Windows 7 machine running ruby 2.4.2p198 (2017-09-14 revision 59899) [x64-mingw32]

Gem
2017-10-10 20:24:08

This array: [['progress', {}, 'file1'], ['profile', {}, 'file2']] was going through the sorting we're doing here https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/lib/cucumber/cli/configuration.rb#L129-L131

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber-ruby
cucumber-ruby - Cucumber for Ruby
Gem
2017-10-10 20:25:20

The @out_stream value when testing is an empty string object basically, so it'll always be false. Unfortunately, due to the Ruby nuance Eric mentioned above, on my machine it always came out incorrectly as [['profile', {}, 'file2'], ['progress', {}, 'file1']]

Gem
2017-10-10 20:36:01

@Aslak HellesÃ¸y in investigating above, Eric said you were the one who initially wrote the sort above. We can't figure out the purpose of it, do you happen to remember the purpsoe behind it?

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-10-11 00:26:01

I don't remember @Gem. Do any tests fail if you comment it out?

Ryan Chapman
2017-10-13 04:18:11

Hey guys, This is a question regarding testing environments I have scenarios/scenario outlines that run assertions, but the assertions that I need to use are slightly different from staging to live.

When I click on the "&lt;link&gt;"
Then The next page will have a "&lt;UID&gt;"

The UID will be different for the staging page and live page

I know Features/Scenarios should never contain conditionals, but iâ€™m unsure how to approach having different assertions.

Any advice is greatly appreciated,

Ryan

enkessler
2017-10-13 05:39:30

If the exact URL isn't important from the behavior perspective, then you can simply not explicitly say it and use something like

When I click on the homepage link
Then The next page will have a home page UID

and then in your step definitions you can do different things based on an environmental flag that indicates whether you are in 'staged' or 'live'.

enkessler
2017-10-13 05:42:38

If the exact URL's are important to document, then you could use an outline an go with something like this

Scenario Outline: Going places
  Given I am using the &lt;environment&gt; version of the application
  When I click on the "&lt;link&gt;"
  Then The next page will have a "&lt;UID&gt;"
Examples: possible environments we test in
  | environment | link| |UID|
  | live | link/for/live | 123456 |
  | staging | link/for/staging | 78910 |
Ryan Chapman
2017-10-13 06:42:19

*Thread Reply:* Awesome advice, thanks mate

hmchadwick
2017-10-13 06:01:20

@hmchadwick has joined the channel

Given(/^I want my step to use both (?:multiple words|word)$/)

Aslak HellesÃ¸y

2017-10-16 09:37:52

Given I have created a new staff member Given I have created a new resource

Letâ€™s say that that step has the exact same code, so I would like to keep it as one step.

In cucumber2, I could just go: Given(/^I have created a new (?:staff member|resource)$/)

marius
2017-10-16 09:38:36

but using the new / wonâ€™t work because of the difference of word number, I guess?

hmchadwick
2017-10-16 09:41:20

if you're not capturing the words does it matter if they fit a specific format?

hmchadwick
2017-10-16 09:41:50

you could create a string parameter type that doesn't require " or '

marius
2017-10-16 09:49:38

Yeah, it can prob be solved with a ParameterType, but was wondering if it could be used without it.

marius
2017-10-16 09:54:29

hmchadwick
2017-10-16 10:02:10

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-10-16 10:16:45

@marius the / operator only works with words (not spaces)

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-10-16 10:17:28

Why are you using both staff member and resource in your steps?

marius
2017-10-16 10:33:10

I'm not sure, as it's not my step, but let's say it could be that the api for creating them both is the same.

marius
2017-10-16 10:39:07

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-10-16 11:10:45

It sounds like staff member and resource are being used interchangeably, and that there is no difference between them in the application. I'd take this as an opportunity to make the domain language more consistent and settle on one of them. (I hope it's not resource).

marius
2017-10-16 13:20:20

enkessler
2017-10-26 06:47:17

marius
2017-10-26 06:49:51

marius
2017-10-26 06:50:50

enkessler
2017-10-26 06:50:56

Is it one big cucumber command? Do you split up your suite and farm it out to lots of machines? Do you kick it off with a Rake task?

marius
2017-10-26 06:51:31

Right now I have it as one bug cucumber command

enkessler
2017-10-26 06:51:51

at_exit would work for serial execution, but the moment you try to go parallel, it will have to be some larger process's concern.

marius
2017-10-26 06:52:23

basically, iâ€™ve added the cleanup code, and that works in the After hook, but it wonâ€™t run in at_exit

enkessler
2017-10-26 06:53:27

I don't know if one has the same context in at_exit that one does in a hook because at_exit is a Ruby thing, not a Cucumber thing.

marius
2017-10-26 06:53:51

yeah, probably the issue

enkessler
2017-10-26 06:54:03

You gems should still be loaded, of course, but you may not have the World anymore.

marius
2017-10-26 07:00:21

Ahh, yeah. Looks like that is the issue. Thanks for pointing me in the direction, mate!

enkessler
2017-10-26 07:01:40

You're welcome.

marius
2017-10-26 07:09:01

works perfectly now. Thanks:)

matt-SmartBear
2017-10-31 07:04:27

@marius @Aslak HellesÃ¸y the docs are quite good for events now: https://app.cucumber.pro/projects/cucumber-ruby/documents/branch/master/features/docs/events/test_case_finished_event.feature

matt-SmartBear
2017-10-31 07:05:13

Whatâ€™s broken in the docs (because my yard-fu is weak) is the link to http://www.rubydoc.info/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/Cucumber/Core/Test/Case from http://www.rubydoc.info/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/Cucumber/Events/TestCaseFinished

matt-SmartBear
2017-10-31 07:05:57

in the event handler, event.test_case is an instance of http://www.rubydoc.info/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/Cucumber/Core/Test/Case which should have all the info about the scenario.

matt-SmartBear
2017-10-31 07:06:04

event.result has the result

Gem
2017-11-20 08:54:59

Cucumber 3.x's default behavior when suggesting step def snippets is to use double quotes which by default Rubocop doesn't like as there's no string interpolation happening. Do we have a way to configure whether single or double quote are used? If not, should we or is there perhaps some other thought around this?

Gem
2017-11-22 07:29:57

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak HellesÃ¸y Thoughts?

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-22 16:11:21

*Thread Reply:* I think it should suggest single quotes if there are no single quotes in the expression, double quotes otherwise. Want to add a fix for that?

Gem
2017-11-22 16:54:36

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak HellesÃ¸y Yeah, happy to. ðŸ™‚

Gem
2017-11-22 16:55:22

*Thread Reply:* Would that be under cucumber-expressions or cucumber-ruby itself?

Gem
2017-11-22 18:47:41

*Thread Reply:* Actually found it in the glue for cucumber-ruby I believe. ðŸ™‚

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-23 01:30:17

*Thread Reply:* In cucumber-ruby. The cucumber-expressions lib generates the actual expression for the snippet, but it's cucumber-ruby that decides how to render it as a snippet.

ðŸ‘ Gem
Gem
2017-11-23 09:43:56

*Thread Reply:* Ty!

luke
2017-11-21 23:51:04

â˜ï¸ Valid point. Not sure what the next mode of attack would be. We definitely need to consider firstly what code "creates these" be it the core, the program proper or the expressions gem. Because atm expressions is 1 major version behind on Cucumber3.

hmchadwick
2017-11-29 01:04:52

ParameterType Regexps can't use option Regexp::FIXEDENCODING (Cucumber::CucumberExpressions::CucumberExpressionError) hmmmm

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:06:15

@hmchadwick how do you define your ParameterType regexp?

hmchadwick
2017-11-29 01:12:48

ParameterType( name: 'stake', regexp: /Â£([0-9]+(?:\.[0-9]{2})?)/, transformer: -&gt;(f) { f.nil? ? 1.00 : f.to_f }, use_for_snippets: false )

hmchadwick
2017-11-29 01:12:49

like so

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:19:31

Hm - that's probably a bug. Maybe you can help me fix it @hmchadwick?

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:20:26

I made a release of cucumber-expressions yesterday where I disallow passing the //i flag (case insensitive). I thought it might be a good idea to disallow other flags too, as we're only using the regexp's source, not its flags.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:21:01

But disallowing Regexp::FIXEDENCODING was probably not a good idea.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:22:29

Essentially I want to disallow any flags we cannot keep. A Cucumber Expression gets translated into a RegExp, and we can't keep ParameterType regexp flags since that would affect the entire generated regexp if you see what I mean. Any ideas?

luke
2017-11-29 01:23:03

Could this be related to the Â£ symbol playing weird on my regex captures locally.

hmchadwick
2017-11-29 01:23:15

mmm I don't know enough about ruby to help out here

luke
2017-11-29 01:23:45

@luke uploaded a file: This kind of issue perhaps?

luke
2017-11-29 01:24:11

I know when I capture the Â£ symbol I have issues sometimes, it depends how / where I define my Â£ symbol.

hmchadwick
2017-11-29 01:26:50

seems like it

hmchadwick
2017-11-29 01:27:03

If I remove the Â£ from the regexp it works fine

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:29:09

Ok I'll release a bugfix shortly.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2017-11-29 01:29:20

Sorry folks!

karolxavierleite
2017-12-04 10:20:47

Hi there!

I'm looking for some article or doc about nested steps.

I have this kind of scenario:

Given(/^flub$/) do
  step 'flub 2'
  step 'flub 3'
  step 'flub 4'
  step 'flub 5'
  step 'flub 6'
  step 'flub 7'
  step 'flub 8'
end

I've tried this approach to reuse code. But now I believe that it's a total confusion (specially for new project members).

Also, I have no feedback on witch nested step is running inside the principal.

walterg2
2017-12-04 10:35:17

I have always found that type of step definition coupling to be extremely fragile and avoid it as much as I can.

â˜ï¸ Brant DeBow
walterg2
2017-12-04 10:36:58

If someone, for instance, changes flub 4 to better meet their direct purpose, they may not know to look over here and see how that change would affect the scenario that this step is needing it for.

ðŸ‘ Gem
walterg2
2017-12-04 10:37:22

If youâ€™re getting to the point of having that many steps being nested once, it may be a good opportunity to look at refactoring the steps to better meet their purposes.

walterg2
2017-12-04 10:38:54

A question for you: are your steps more declarative (Given I am on my shopping cart) or imperative (Given I go to <url> And I click Buy And I click Go to my cart) in nature?

Gem
2017-12-04 10:39:26

(I'll throw in a quick note that it's generally considered best practice to shift the step behavior that needs to be reused to a helper method instead. ðŸ™‚ )

â˜ï¸ Brant DeBow
karolxavierleite
2017-12-04 11:01:59

My steps are more declarative! I've tried this approach because my app is a monolith with a "flow" of infos. 

SCENARIOS

Scenario 1
Given Im on init of my flow

Scenario 2
Given Im on flow step 2

Scenario 3
Given Im on flow step 3


STEPS

Given(/^Im on flow step 3$/) do
  step 'Given Im on init of my flow'
  step 'Im on flow step 2'
end

Is something like this.

karolxavierleite
2017-12-04 11:06:55

@Gem great! do you have some article about this approach?

Gem
2017-12-04 11:07:19

I can't find anything unfortunately. ðŸ˜ž I tried looking either, too.

Gem
2017-12-04 11:11:01

@karolxavierleite Check this out: http://grokbase.com/t/gg/cukes/133ey063b8/cucumber-substeps-macro-request-for-the-nth-time

grokbase.com
[Cucumber] Substeps - macro request for the nth time - Grokbase
(11 replies) The request for some sort of macro functionality in Cucumber comes up over and over again. In the early days we had GivenScenario, which we got rid of [1] and replaced with the ability to call steps from step definitions [2]. Over time I have grown to dislike this feature as well. Cucumber old-timers have realised that the best tool to achieve composition and reuse is the host programming language (Java, Ruby etc). You know - *methods*. The pattern is simple: For any step/step definition you
Gem
2017-12-04 11:13:31

@matt-SmartBear @Aslak HellesÃ¸y do either of you have a better link perhaps?

karolxavierleite
2017-12-04 11:14:27

tks @Gem

ðŸ‘ Gem
walterg2
2017-12-04 11:33:53

Sorry, stepped away to satisfy my grumbling bellyâ€¦ Glad that everything is more declarative! Like @Gem said, helper methods or, if you use a page object pattern, pushing things down into the page objects can help as well.

ðŸ‘ Gem, karolxavierleite, Ryan Chapman
sergey
2017-12-05 11:54:06

@sergey has joined the channel

gijs.p
2017-12-06 04:29:42

@karolxavierleite I used to write all my scenario's like that, until the Cucumber Slack people recommended me otherwise. I have to say, moving to helper methods instead of nested steps removes a lot of complications.

Given(/^Im on flow step 3$/) do
 step 'Given Im on init of my flow'
 step 'Im on flow step 2'
end

Would become, for example:

Given(/^Im on flow step 3$/) do
 Flow.ensure_init()
 Flow.ensure_step()
end
gijs.p
2017-12-06 04:32:42

I'm working on a nice Cucumber / Ruby / Watir example to visualize this more. Currently still in development, but it might interest you: https://github.com/spriteCloud/lapis-lazuli/blob/development/lib/lapis_lazuli/generators/cucumber/template/features/step_definitions/account_steps.rb

GitHub
spriteCloud/lapis-lazuli
lapis-lazuli - Cucumber helper functions and scaffolding for easier test automation suite development.
sergey
2017-12-06 04:43:54

Hi @gijs.p, Iâ€™m also interesting in it - as working/playing with nested steps vs writing helpers. Thanks for that.

p.s. shortly reviewed and seeing double @ here - http://take.ms/Ri5Cg Should it be one @ instead ?

sergey
2017-12-06 04:45:59

ah - seems itâ€™s correct â€” seeing the same double in many places ðŸ™‚

sergey
2017-12-06 04:46:23

gijs.p
2017-12-06 05:00:16

All good ðŸ™‚ Keep in mind this is a way to do it, certainly not the way. Some people like to make classes, others use Page Objects. In the end it's about moving your driver interactions from Step definitions to Functions.

ðŸ¥’ Gem, marius

luke
2017-12-07 03:27:29

For instance we have one "arguably horrible" convoluted compressed step. Which has about 8 actions in it.

But its because in every feature (and I mean every feature we have)

Given I am on "uk" page
Given I fly from tenerife 
......
When I make a search

Now we have a nice fully customisable step. It's horrible code, but it looks lovely.

Given I am on "uk" home page, Tenerife to Manchester, 2/0/0 pax, 14 nights, in 21 days time.

ðŸ‘ gijs.p
luke
2017-12-07 03:28:00

because that first step is just white noise. It's just setup.

We can't use Background because some tiny bits change (domain or pax), in between related scenarios.

enkessler
2017-12-07 04:21:14

@luke If it is just 'white noise', then why is it in the Gherkin?

enkessler
2017-12-07 04:21:58

Regardless of whether it is in the form of one step or many steps, if it is not relevant to the scenario at hand then why is it there?

luke
2017-12-07 04:54:48

it's relevant. But it's the same for every one.

For the white noise comment, it's more a case of "Setup steps"

So if we're testing scrapbooking something, we care about When I scrapbook it Then it appears

luke
2017-12-07 04:55:14

We have to have setup steps to visit our website and make a search

gijs.p
2017-12-07 05:07:49

Often, if your setup step (Given) contains too much variables, it's nice to make a configuration out of it:

Given I am on "uk" home page, Tenerife to Manchester, 2/0/0 pax, 14 nights, in 21 days time.
# Becomes:
Given I am on results page "uk-default-search"

config.yml:

uk_default_search:
  locale: uk
  route-from: tenerife
  route-to: manchester
  pax: 2,0,0
  # etc...
ðŸ’¯ marius, Jignesh
luke
2017-12-08 01:16:12

Someone said that, however that's not configurable inline sadly.

luke
2017-12-08 01:16:49

so if we wanted 10 different varieties all with slightly different numbers, we just edit our Gherkin files.

gijs.p
2017-12-08 02:28:54

Good point. As always, it's a balance ðŸ™‚

luke
2017-12-08 03:48:58

in the step code it does look back I admit, but on the front end it's lovely (And in a weird way, only a couple of us are competent enough to do the ruby / step code).

2017-12-29 19:58:06

goossens
2018-01-02 12:55:20

Soooo, the basics of the Custom Formatter are working (it generates the XML-file). However the status of each step is always "skipped", while it's showing as passed with the Pretty Formatter.

goossens
2018-01-02 12:56:27

i'm getting the status from the status parameter of the def step_name(keyword, step_match, status, source_indent, background, file_colon_line) method, or isn't that the right one to use?

brasmusson
2018-01-03 11:03:44

> seem to do the trick in the before_feature method

@goossens You seems to be using an old Cucumber-Ruby version, or at least the deprecated formatter API. With Cucumber-Ruby v3.x.x the recommended formatter API is the event based API, where the step result is one of the attributes on the :test_step_finished event (see for instance the built in json formatter (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/lib/cucumber/formatter/json.rb#L61))

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber-ruby
cucumber-ruby - Cucumber for Ruby
goossens
2018-01-03 11:38:28

@brasmusson i've based it on the built in Pretty Formatter implementation, but it would explain the warning about using the old API ðŸ™‚

goossens
2018-01-03 11:40:05

and cucumber version is 3.1.0

brasmusson
2018-01-03 23:16:11

The Pretty Formatter is one of the two formatters not yet re-written to the new formatter API, see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/839

GitHub
Re-write formatters against new API Â· Issue #839 Â· cucumber/cucumber-ruby
For 3.0 the <https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/lib/cucumber/formatter/legacy_api/adapter.rb> should be removed, and all formatters that ship with Cucumber should go through the new, te...
luke
2018-01-04 04:49:38

Oh aslak, meant to ask.

The formatter (html one), currently doesn't (I'm on 2.4 on master), output times. But we've got some stuff that covers that for us in our aftersteps.

Is there plans to introduce this in cucumber3 at some point. I think I remember seeing it on local runs of my c3/master branch

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-01-04 14:38:13

@luke the plan is to remove the native HTML formatters in Cucumber-Ruby and Cucumber-JVM (Cucumber.js doesn't have one). Instead we'll write a command line tool that reads events from STDIN (as NDJSON, emitted by Cucumber) and writes out a HTML report. More details here: https://docs.cucumber.io/event-protocol/

luke
2018-01-05 00:17:07

That would be quite handy yeh. As I imagine the html formatters are language specific (Although the ruby one gives us 90% of what we need already, so we just use that one built in)

Gederson Chiquesi
2018-01-05 06:03:04

@Gederson Chiquesi has joined the channel

ðŸ‘ Gem
Ryan Chapman
2018-01-22 03:16:08

Iâ€™ve always felt like Ruby/other very high level languages are top tier candidates for cucumber/test automation as a whole.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-01-22 03:25:15

If your tests run in a different process from the SUT I agree. OTOH I always recommend using the same language for tests as the SUT. It's really hard to have fast tests otherwise.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-01-22 03:25:56

When they're the same language, tests and SUT can run in the same process, possibly eliminating slow I/O

Ryan Chapman
2018-01-22 03:27:54

Thatâ€™s a good point, cheers!

hmchadwick
2018-01-24 05:03:49

I know this goes against the Cucumber philosophy, but is there any way to have variables persisting between multiple scenarios, e.g. for all tests within a single feature file?

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-01-24 05:12:59

@hmchadwick store them in a $global_variable - (reallybadidea)

hmchadwick
2018-01-24 05:17:01

It's just something we are exploring. At the moment, if we were to implement these scenarios (~70 in total), then it would take about 5-10 minutes per scenario due to a polling rate we can't change. However, if we were to have them all use the same initial setup variables, we could cut that down to maybe 5 minutes total.

luke
2018-01-24 05:53:19

@hmchadwick You're over-engineering.

luke
2018-01-24 05:53:27

Use a variable per feature, query that feature-level-variable.

luke
2018-01-24 05:53:41

This wouldn't work cross feature, but would work in an individual feature.

Brant DeBow
2018-01-24 05:58:21

@hmchadwick see here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki/Hooks#global-hooks

It sounds like you just need to do the setup once and then have all the scenarios use what you've setup? I've done that before using this technique and/or the one in Running a Before hook only once right below. The thing you want to avoid is having your scenarios depend on each other. If they all depend on some global state, you have less chance for the global var antipattern to bite you

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber
cucumber - Cucumber monorepo - polyglot home for Cucumber building blocks
Brant DeBow
2018-01-24 06:02:24

to give an example of something we've done before: Our tests needed facebook accounts to login, but our business doesn't care about setting up FB accounts (just that you have one to login). So in env we setup a bunch of fake test accounts that are available to our scenarios. But the scenarios could still be run in any order and don't count on any of those accounts being setup in our system prior to being run.

hmchadwick
2018-01-24 06:09:50

mmm That doesn't really solve our problem

hmchadwick
2018-01-24 07:07:18

Okay, our problem seems largely resolved. All the scenarios remained mostly the same, but the checks are added to a global list which is checked in a scenario run after all the previous ones are complete

hmchadwick
2018-01-24 07:08:04

That final scenario waits for the settlement of all the previous setups to finish, so we are only blocked at a single point

luke
2018-01-24 09:07:28

Question (Possibly more ruby than cucumber)

luke
2018-01-24 09:21:41

Scenario 1) Klass.method (This is a memo, and will either use the stored value or fetch it - so fetches say 1

luke
2018-01-24 09:21:58

Scenario 2) Klass.method (This SHOULD fetch it, there should be nothing stored) - So it should say fetch 2. Not use 1 which is memoized. As 1 SHOULDNT be memoized.

luke
2018-01-24 09:23:11

Inside Klass you've got say

def self.method
  @memo ||= rand(1..100)
end
luke
2018-01-24 09:23:44

that should produce a new number when running Klass.method for each scenario in my eyes.

Ryan Chapman
2018-01-24 09:25:57

ahh gotcha

Ryan Chapman
2018-01-24 09:27:42

Well in this case @memo gets set on the first run and will never evaluate rand(1..100) again

luke
2018-01-24 09:31:10

My actual code (btw)

class Domains
  def self.current
    @current ||=
      case current_site
      when :uk
        Domains::UK
      when :se
        Domains::SE
      when :no
        Domains::NO
      end
  end
end

class Domains
    def current
      @current ||=
        case current_site
        when :uk
          Domains::UK
        when :se
          Domains::SE
        when :no
          Domains::NO
        end
    end
end

Then make a new class instance each time you need the class would be a way to make this work

2018-01-24 09:51:59

ukdomain = Domains.new
puts ukdomain.current
&gt; Domains::UK

sedomain = Domains.new
puts sedomain.current
&gt; Domains::SE
luke
2018-01-25 00:24:57

Yes but you're missing the point. That means at the end of a scenario, these things are left in memory. That's the problem / bug.

Ayethin

@luke how did you hack around it? (just interested) the only way I could see was using a for loop to run through all the ivarâ€™s and set them to nil

luke
2018-01-25 01:50:49

luke

luke
2018-01-25 01:51:37
 
class Domains
  def self.current
    @current
  end

  def self.set
    @current =
      case current_site
        when :uk
          Domains::UK
        when :se
          Domains::SE
        when :no
          Domains::NO
      end
  end
end
ðŸ‘ Ayethin
tooky
2018-01-29 01:37:27

@luke class instance variables arenâ€™t reset because they are essentially global state. You donâ€™t get new instances of the classes for each scenario - they are created when the Ruby interpreter encounters the class definition.

tooky
2018-01-29 01:55:40

@luke I think the right approach here is probably to create and inject a new instance of an object that manages those domains into the world. The world is recreated on each scenario run, and therefore any objects within it.

luke
2018-01-29 02:39:14

Right, so because it's kind of a global variable, it's sticking for the entire feature, as opposed to scenario by scenario.

I know what brasmussen also said, just I think that my assumption was valid (Whether the ruby is or isn't is debatable obviously). I would assume each scenario would be a standalone area with regards to variables @tooky

luke
2018-01-29 02:40:21

Thanks for the pointers though, ironically some of the guys at my company have an internal gem that I "may" be able to use (I assumed it needed rails), so actually the problem might fix itself going forwards.

tooky
2018-01-29 04:04:58

@luke youâ€™re right you should expect each scenario to have a clean state â€“ thatâ€™s what Cucumberâ€™s world gives you, state that persists between steps, but not between scenarios - https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki/Configuring-the-Scenario-Execution-Context-%28World%29

Using global state like class instance variables moves that state out of the control of Cucumber. Itâ€™s a bit like using a database. You have to write code to clean your database between steps (or at least explicitly use DatabaseCleaner), youâ€™d need to do the same thing for class instance variables.

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber
cucumber - Cucumber monorepo - polyglot home for Cucumber building blocks
luke
2018-01-29 05:31:49

Thanks again for your help. I'll have to have a rethink about how to do that, as I thought that's what I was doing. Lack of knowledge is crippling me evidently here. I think for now I'm just gonna run a set method once each time and then wait until we have the gem in our stack which handles this better

luke
2018-01-29 05:34:30

I think the reason I didn't just directly place it into a helper module inside the world as it would be re-evaluated each time, and it wouldn't change on each scenario run. Just trying to optimise it so to speak

gijs.p
2018-02-01 06:50:56

Hey guys, for who's interested in an open question edge case situation, that I'd like to hear your idea's about. I have 2 Cucumber projects in 1 company, lets call them ProjectA and ProjectB. Both projects are completely independent from each other, testing a whole different system. Now they want me to make a 3rd project (ProjectC), that tests a different system, that is connected to the systems from ProjectA and ProjectB.

ProjectC will need a lot of the same code from ProjectA & B. Obveously, I don't want to write same functions twice (Like API calls, helpers and login credentials), that would double my maintenance cost. So somehow, I want to include these other 2 projects, in my third project. So for example I could do Create a user and place an order in system A, Send the order in System B, Check product stock went down by 1 in system C.

So, how would you solve this? ðŸ™‚ (I'll describe my current solution in a reply to this message)

gijs.p
2018-02-01 06:54:33

*Thread Reply:* Currently I have created a script that will clone the repositories from the 2 other projects into a separate folder. This clone is only done when you run cucumber -p update So if any code it changed there, you'll need to do a manual action to update it here.

Then, before the first scenario starts running, I require all the files from the other projects I need. This allows me to re-use the functions used there.

The problem with this is that other Modules / config values etc. with the same name are overwritten when the new files are included.

gijs.p
2018-02-01 06:56:48

*Thread Reply:* @luke that sounds like a cool solution, but if I understand correctly, the scenario's from admin need the results from site before it can run. My projects have to be able to run independently from each other.

gijs.p
2018-02-01 07:07:05

*Thread Reply:* Hmmm, unless running the relevant scenario's from ProjectA and storing the results is a part of ProjectC... We're using GitLab instead of Jenkins, but you gave me some inspiration to think about.

tooky
2018-02-01 12:21:34

*Thread Reply:* @gijs.p which way do the dependencies go? Does the new system use the exisiting systems? Will the existing systems know about the new system?

gijs.p
2018-02-02 03:25:45

*Thread Reply:* @tooky the new system will only need to synch with the existing system.

tooky
2018-02-02 03:53:37

*Thread Reply:* @gijs.p ok, I would strongly recommend you look to define the contract between the 2 systems in terms of the consumer (new system) using the producer (existing system) as an automated test. (This does not need to be in cucumber, although it could be if it makes adds value to document the contract with Gherkin.)

You can then add this test to the test suite of the producer to ensure that it always fulfils that contract.

The consumer, your new system, can then use the contract to create a lightweight / fake in-memory implementation which fulfils the same contract as the producer. Your tests will have full control of this.

You wonâ€™t need to use the other system to create a user/order/etc. you just add it into the fake, and you can test your new system independently of the existing system safe in the knowledge that both the real producer and the fake produce fulfil the same contract.

This has the advantage that both systems can be deployed independently of each other, and you only need minimal smoke testing to make sure the integration is working as expected.

This technique is known as consumer-driven contract testing. Much more in-depth stuff here: https://martinfowler.com/articles/consumerDrivenContracts.html

martinfowler.com
Consumer-Driven Contracts: A Service Evolution Pattern
Consumers should drive the definition of service contracts, while limiting to their individual needs. Suppliers should then validate against the union of their consumers' contracts.
gijs.p
2018-02-02 04:44:15

*Thread Reply:* Cool stuff, I'll have a good look at it next week ðŸ‘

enkessler
2018-02-05 18:05:14

*Thread Reply:* If you have common helper code, you could pull it out into its own library and share that as a gem that each project could include.

luke
2018-02-01 06:53:51

jenkins api gem, allows you to pass records from one to the other.

luke
2018-02-01 06:53:59

We have 2 systems (Call them site / admin)

luke
2018-02-01 06:54:12

after running a test on site we then want to run a test on admin including a value we obtain from site

luke
2018-02-01 06:56:28

obviously this only works when running through jenkins. But it is rather handy.

luke
2018-02-01 06:57:49

But in your example

A::Create User
A::Create Order
B::Send Order through to Back Office
C::Check Stock
luke
2018-02-01 06:57:57

so it goes, A then B, then C

Vitalii Afonin

Vitalii Afonin
2018-02-07 22:49:08

Hey guys, I came to Cucumber Ruby from Cucumber Java and I havenâ€™t found how to correctly implement following: Iâ€™d like to prevent browser closing in case some test scenario failed. In Java I just didnâ€™t close the browser in â€˜Afterâ€™ Hooks, could you please share some code snippet/article how to do it in Ruby?

gijs.p
2018-02-07 23:50:30

Hmmm, putting a prompt in the after step should do the trick. One moment

Vitalii Afonin
2018-02-07 23:57:31

*Thread Reply:* Thank you. Looks more like a hack, but yes, it should work

gijs.p
2018-02-07 23:55:27

@Vitalii Afonin 

After do |scenario|
  if scenario.failed?
    print "A scenario has failed, press any key to continue\r"
    gets
  end
end

Cucumber hooks: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki/Hooks Prompting user: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34594018/how-to-code-press-key-to-continue

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber
cucumber - Cucumber monorepo - polyglot home for Cucumber building blocks
stackoverflow.com
How to code "press key to continue"
I am trying to implement a simple "Press any key to continue". I print this message to the console, and I want to erase it after a key is pressed. Following "Writing over previously output lines i...
gijs.p
2018-02-08 00:00:48

You can make this as customable as you want, for example only do this on scenario's that include the @debug tag:

AfterStep('@debug') do |scenario| #...

Or create a profile in cucumber.yml, set a environment variable, like PROMPT_AFTER_FAILURE and change your if statement to:

if scenario.failed? and !ENV['PROMT_AFTER_FAILURE'].nil?
ðŸ‘ Vitalii Afonin
Vitalii Afonin
2018-02-08 00:02:46

Thank you @gijs.p, will try it

gijs.p
2018-02-08 00:05:35

*Thread Reply:* No problem. I'm actually in a situation where I have to use Cucumber jvm, so I might get back to you ðŸ™‚

Vitalii Afonin
2018-02-08 00:07:53

*Thread Reply:* No problem, Iâ€™ll willing to help

pauloeliasjr
2018-02-08 08:04:08

@pauloeliasjr has joined the channel

pauloeliasjr
2018-02-08 08:04:13

Hi all! I'm having a great time testing features with cucumber using some predefined steps created by this wonderful community... I'm not a developer and have no code skills so this is the fastest way I found to test cucumber. I'm currently stuck trying to generate reports that show me the screenshots of any failed step. I know that cucumber has a "-f html" setting, but this only brings me simple report without the screenshots. This is the default for this report or I am missing something? I've tried to test another reports (like ReportBuilder) but I get the same results (a different report layout but no screenshot)

sergey
2018-02-08 08:08:14

*Thread Reply:* You need capybara-screenshots gem, as far as I know.

Steven
2018-02-08 08:05:54

@Steven has joined the channel

enkessler
2018-02-08 08:07:39

You have to take the screenshot yourself and then tell Cucumber to embed the screenshot in the report. Something along the lines of

# Take a screenshot for failing tests
After do |scenario|
  screenshot_directory = 'wherever_you_want_to_save_pictures'
  saved_image_path = "#{screenshot_directory}/#{scenario.name}_screenshot.png"

  if scenario.failed?
    @browser.screenshot.save saved_image_path
    embed saved_image_path, 'image/png'
  end
end
pauloeliasjr
2018-02-08 08:09:15

Hi @enkessler I'll try this and let you know! Thanks for your help

pauloeliasjr
2018-02-08 11:28:46

@enkessler I was able to test and it works perfectly! I had do input this information on env.rb file instead of hooks.rb. On this file, ruby cannot found chrome driver functions (such as screenshot_save), but for now this is ok to me. Thanks a lot!

ðŸ‘ enkessler
luke
2018-02-09 02:39:50

One thing to note is that this will take a screenshot between 0.2 - 1s afterwards. So the screenshot sometimes can be slightly off. To my knowledge there's not really much you can do other than take the screenshot at the instance of failure.

Gem
2018-02-09 07:44:20

Oooooh man have I had a bunch of pain in dealing with the delay around screenshot taking.

sergey
2018-02-09 08:05:08

Just curious - why donâ€™t use capybara-screenshot gem for it - which works perfectly with no delay, and create a screenshot immediately ?

sergey
2018-02-09 08:05:51

just one row in Gemfile + one row in env.rb:

Capybara.save_and_open_page_path = 'public/screenshots'
sergey
2018-02-09 08:06:29

And there is no need to put the code above for After do |scenario|.

elinp
2018-02-19 07:42:29

Ryan Chapman
2018-02-19 07:47:44

after hook is the way iâ€™d do it. Specify the scenario you want to run the code after

Ryan Chapman
2018-02-19 07:49:16
 
After("@LastScenario") do |scenario|
 &lt;stuff&gt;
end
elinp
2018-02-19 07:50:43

but that will run after every scenario with that tag, I want it to run at the end of the feature file that is tagged

Ryan Chapman
2018-02-19 07:53:39

Ah, I see. If you were to tag the last scenario of the feature, I think this could simulate an â€˜after featureâ€™

Ryan Chapman
2018-02-19 07:55:12

to my knowledge, an after feature hook hasnâ€™t been implemented.

elinp
2018-02-19 07:58:26

yeah, doesn't really feel like a good solution as it would prevent single scenarios from being run

luke
2018-02-19 08:03:00

Yeh good use case. Other than a specific tag I'm not sure. I think there is a World Teardown bit somewhere I saw once, but never used it personally.

luke
2018-02-19 08:03:09

I'd be surprised if something doesn't exist. Most use cases are covered.

tooky
2018-02-19 08:06:42

@elinp cucumber-ruby doesnâ€™t really take any notice of which feature file a scenario is defined in when it runs. It doesnâ€™t explicitly know when a feature starts executing or when it finishes. It treats each scenarios as completely standalone. In fact you can ask Cucumber to run them in a random order.

--order TYPE[:SEED]          Run examples in the specified order. Available types:
                                                  [defined]     Run scenarios in the order they were defined (default).
                                                  [random]      Shuffle scenarios before running.
                                             Specify SEED to reproduce the shuffling from a previous run.
                                                e.g. --order random:5738
elinp
2018-02-19 08:06:51

I've 'hack' something that seems to work - After('@load_feature_data') do |scenario| if scenario.location == scenario.feature.feature_elements.last.location

elinp
2018-02-19 08:07:40

I will ensure that I don't run in random order ðŸ™‚ as this definitely will break

tooky
2018-02-19 08:08:26

I believe a more robust way to do this would be to write a custom filter - see https://app.cucumber.pro/projects/cucumber-ruby/documents/branch/master/features/docs/extending_cucumber/custom_filter.feature

elinp
2018-02-19 08:09:25

*Thread Reply:* thanks, I'll take a look

tooky
2018-02-19 08:10:15

*Thread Reply:* Thereâ€™s lots of examples here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/tree/master/lib/cucumber/filters

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber-ruby
cucumber-ruby - Cucumber for Ruby
tooky
2018-02-19 08:12:03

*Thread Reply:* The â€œfilterâ€ should probably collect all the test cases, so it knows which test cases belong to a specific feature, and add a step to the â€œlastâ€ testcase in a scenario.

tooky
2018-02-19 08:13:12

@elinp all that being said. Iâ€™m interested why you want to do this?

elinp
2018-02-19 23:37:42

*Thread Reply:* I have a feature that requires some pre-setup - e.g. a company/user must exists but the actual test cases don't relate to this data but is required for the feature to run

elinp
2018-02-19 23:38:17

*Thread Reply:* I could tear-down after all features have run, but though it would be tidier to do after each feature

matt-SmartBear
2018-02-20 03:14:59

*Thread Reply:* @elinp could you look at it the other way around and leave the system messy after the tests have run, but use a before hook to ensure itâ€™s in the right state before you run your test(s)?

matt-SmartBear
2018-02-20 03:16:15

*Thread Reply:* That way you could use a tag on the feature, a before hook on that tag, and a global flag in your features to skip out of the hook if it has run once already.

matt-SmartBear
2018-02-20 03:16:53

*Thread Reply:* That would allow you to run any scenario and even at random and stuff should just work.

matt-SmartBear
2018-02-20 03:17:42

*Thread Reply:* Itâ€™s also safer as even if someone else has messed about with the state in the system, the test will always get it the way it needs it before it runs.

Vlad Ionescu
2018-02-22 02:57:08

Hi,

I am using Cucumber with Ruby and cheezy/page-object and when I am in a page section function trying to do @browser.screenshot I get undefined method 'screenshot' for #&lt;Watir::HTMLElement'. Is setting @browser a bad idea or is https://github.com/cheezy/page-object/issues/460 a valid bug? I am setting the browser in the Before step in env.rb: 

browser = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, opts

Before do
    @browser = browser
    @browser.driver.manage.timeouts.page_load = 190
    Watir.logger.level = :info
en
GitHub
Browser context changing after updating to 2.2 Â· Issue #460 Â· cheezy/page-object
Hi, I'm writing tests for a page that has a footer. I have a class Footer that is locating the footer element. However, when I try to use a global browser variable, it looks like with the 2.2 upgra...
luke
2018-02-22 02:58:34

I've given a response to this on selenium...

Vlad Ionescu
2018-02-22 02:59:46

Yes, @browser is the wrong type. I agree with that. What I am asking if what I am doing is Cucumber best practice and if anybody has any idea why page-object would re-initialize @browser

luke
2018-02-22 03:00:12

It varies situation to situation. When you instantiate an instance variable inside the Cucumber World it is available all over

luke
2018-02-22 03:00:34

So any World based Object (Step Def / env.rb / hooks.rb / Mixed in modules) has access to this one variable.

luke
2018-02-22 03:01:59

So @browser in your code example would be the same singular instance across all of your Cucumber World.

Vlad Ionescu
2018-02-22 03:03:08

Yup. And looks like that instance is re-initialized by someone. I think page-object, but I am not sure

Vlad Ionescu
2018-02-22 03:22:05

@cheezy, am I doing something wrong? ^

luke
2018-02-22 03:42:01

It can't be getting re-initialized unless you are doing that.

luke
2018-02-22 03:42:07

You haven't shown me any memoization code.

luke
2018-02-22 03:42:41

for it to re initialize you'd need a memo method like

def browser
  @browser ||= NEWBROWSER
end
luke
2018-02-22 03:43:14

it might be that you have one browser instance variable in one place and another in another place. and you're switching contexts?

Vlad Ionescu
2018-02-22 03:44:57

Nope. Just 1 @browser. Hence my confusion to why it's suddenly an Watir::Element

luke
2018-02-22 04:11:27

create a set of debug output chains.

After Suite instantiation, After first page load, Before command

luke
2018-02-22 04:11:37

check the value (object id should be enough), each time.

luke
2018-02-22 04:11:44

see where it changes, allow us to debug it further.

Vlad Ionescu
2018-02-22 05:05:06

I am debugging it now. Looks like it's happening when I nest 3 classes. I'll report back with what I find

Alan M.
2018-02-25 09:39:34

@Alan M. has joined the channel

Paul_N
2018-03-01 13:19:59

How many lines of code in a single step definition? mine are usually between 2-10 as I like to abstract things out - but I know on many occasions I could and should do better. How is everyone else doing with their clean code efforts? I have recently seen a Then step with 150 lines!

enkessler
2018-03-01 13:36:46
 
When /I log into the app/ do
  log_into_app
end
enkessler
2018-03-01 13:36:54

Bam!

â˜ï¸ Jason Koelewyn
Vlad Ionescu
2018-03-01 21:55:21

^ can confirm, most of them are 1 or 2 lines.

Vlad Ionescu
2018-03-01 21:56:10

I do have a couple of higher steps that read from a file and call other steps with the data they read. Those are longer and I'm not sure if this is best practice. Worked fine until now. No other logic than reading from the file is done tho.

luke
2018-03-02 00:30:36

@Paul_N that it what support code is for.For the hardcore ruby/java/python code.

gijs.p
2018-03-02 03:23:56

@Paul_N the only reason for me to have a step def longer than 1 line is because I'm catching a regex logic. The rest is all done in helpers:

When /"{username}" logs (in|out)/ do |username, in_or_out|
  case in_or_out
    when 'in'
      Auth.log_in(username)
    when 'out'
      Auth.log_out
end

Something like:

  • Gherkin > business logic
  • Step def > regex logic** + redirect to helper function
  • Helpers > functionality testing (like clicking elements, confirming presence of things etc.) ** regex logic is now mainly caught with the new Cucumber Expressions.
â˜ï¸ Jason Koelewyn, Gem
brasmusson
2018-03-03 11:10:33

*Thread Reply:* To me it looks are using an unnecessary complex regex/Cucumber-Expression and because of that you are forcing yourself to write an unnecessary complex step definition, instead of using simpler regex/Cucumber-Expressions and then as a side effect get simper step definitions:

When /"{username}" logs in/ do |username|
  Auth.log_in(username)
end

When /"{username}" logs out/ do |username|
  Auth.log_out
end

Fewer more complex step definitions is a false optimization in my mind.

luke
2018-03-02 03:35:56

Yip (Although for 2 situations please use if/else) ðŸ™‚ :grinningfacewithonelargeandonesmalleye:

gijs.p
2018-03-02 03:53:06

*Thread Reply:* haha, yeah, started with case because I wanted a else statement with an error saying the value is not "in" nor "out"... but the regex caught that ðŸ˜›

Jason Koelewyn
2018-03-02 04:39:24

yep! we have a min of 2 lines because every step calls a method to handle our specialized output. But we are very strict that the only logic in steps is switches based on the inputs to consolidate steps. But it is amazing how many people dont do this.

enkessler
2018-03-02 05:31:14

I am amused because I just gave a conference talk on this the other day.

tooky
2018-03-02 05:47:15

When /I log into the app/, :log_into_app

ðŸ™‡â€â™‚ï¸ Jason Koelewyn

2018-03-02 06:10:46

2018-03-02 06:11:19

2018-03-02 07:33:19

I would not want to litter the page object with it and it is too specific for a general helper module so where does it go?

Gem
2018-03-02 08:30:28

I don't do this currently in my Ruby cukes though I know I need to get better with it. With my Go implementation, the way the step definitions are set up, it forces you to put everything into functions/methods which is nice.

Paul_N
2018-03-02 11:20:38

@enkessler something particular to one step in a scenario, say perhaps read a database and compare totals with elements presented on a web page.

Gem
2018-03-02 11:31:07

You could have the step def point to a helper function that wraps the db read and then call the compare function that you've got set up already.

enkessler
2018-03-02 11:36:33

Step definitions remain the correct place for assertions. Page models are just a tool to interact with a system. They don't know the purpose of that interaction. Right and wrong are outside their scope of concern.

Then /it matches some stuff/ do
  the_right_stuff = # insert some code to determine the right answer here

  expect(model.current_stuff).to match(the_right_stuff)
end
Gem
2018-03-02 11:37:15

*Thread Reply:* Then 'it matches some stuff' do use the 3.0 syntax! ðŸ˜›

enkessler
2018-03-02 11:37:26

*Thread Reply:* I haven't upgraded yet. ðŸ˜›

Gem
2018-03-02 11:37:36

*Thread Reply:* Boo!

Gem
2018-03-02 11:37:37

*Thread Reply:* hah

enkessler
2018-03-02 11:38:14

*Thread Reply:* When I feel like fixing everything that 3.0 breaks, I'll get right on that.

Gem
2018-03-02 11:38:55

*Thread Reply:* stillsadtuba.com

Gem
2018-03-02 11:38:59

*Thread Reply:* Fair enough though!

enkessler
2018-03-02 11:45:33

When it takes many model interactions in order to do something, that is where helper methods come in.

Paul_N
2018-03-03 01:28:55

Gederson Chiquesi

Guys, How do I get the "error log" in cucumber using hooks ?

enkessler

Gederson Chiquesi
2018-03-06 10:08:07

got: a expect: 3

Gederson Chiquesi
2018-03-06 10:08:37

after do |scenario| puts scenario.log end

enkessler
2018-03-06 10:12:14

Sounds like you want the Exception that is raised by the test. That should be reachable through the scenario object, although off the top of my head I don't know the exact method chain to get to it.

enkessler
2018-03-06 10:14:17

hey! It looks like it's just #exception. http://www.rubydoc.info/gems/cucumber/1.3.17/Cucumber/Ast/Scenario

enkessler
2018-03-06 10:14:47

Hmm. That's an old version of Cucumber. In any case, the approach is likely to be the same.

Gederson Chiquesi
2018-03-06 10:25:08

luke
2018-03-07 01:09:28

scenario.exception.message is usually a good hit in ruby to get the physical message (I believe exception returns the object)

gijs.p
2018-03-07 04:02:34

Q: Is there a way to use pending outside a step definition?

gijs.p
2018-03-07 04:09:40

To clarify:

Given 'the user clicks something' do
  Page.click_something
end

module Page
  self.click_something
    pending 'To click something has not been created yet.' # &gt; undefined method `pending' for Search:Module (NoMethodError)
  end
end
luke
2018-03-07 04:59:28

the context I'd use it in is like this.

luke
2018-03-07 05:00:07
 
When(/^I log out$/) do
  pending 'Actions are not yet implemented in Firefox' if firefox?
  # do my code
end
luke
2018-03-07 05:00:18

â˜ï¸ Is similar to something we use in our codebase.

luke
2018-03-07 05:01:00

You could override the NoMethodError at an Object level

luke
2018-03-07 05:01:10

But that would not throw pending.

luke
2018-03-07 05:02:16
 
class Object
  def method_missing(method, **args, &amp;block)
    'Oh dear I've not done this yet'
  end
end
gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:03:39

Hah, yeah, but I need the pending to get that status in the formatter (json). So that the results systems can see it's actually pending.

luke
2018-03-07 05:04:16

I think my first version is a pretty good one. I can't think of why you couldn't use that. I suppose if you use the method in twenty places you'd need 20 guard clauses which is bad

luke
2018-03-07 05:04:23

but then you'd wrap it in a compressed step

gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:04:50

The reason why I can't have it in my step def, is because I've moved my code logic to helper files, including some if, else situations. And only one of these if statements need the pending status.

luke
2018-03-07 05:05:04

Right, so you use a compressed step

luke
2018-03-07 05:05:38
 
When(^/I attempt to click$/) do
 pending 'msg' if helper?
end
luke
2018-03-07 05:06:15
 
When(/^I actually click something$/) do
  steps 'When I attempt to click'
  # logic
end
gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:12:40

So this would centralize pending messages, preventing redundant code, which is good. But it doesn't solve the problem of being able to call the pending function from outside a step definition.

gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:15:27

luke

gijs.p

luke
2018-03-07 05:41:39

nope.

luke
2018-03-07 05:41:44

I've got a fully working SSCCE here.

luke
2018-03-07 05:42:06

step code

Given(/^I want to call some code that sets me as pending$/) do
  c = NewClass.new
  c.new_method
end

Then(/^I should not be called$/) do
  raise 'Do not crash!'
end
luke
2018-03-07 05:42:21

Feature Code

Feature: New Feature
  Scenario: I can select code to call pending steps
    Given I want to call some code that sets me as pending
    Then I should not be called
luke
2018-03-07 05:42:34

support code

module NewHelper
  def new_method
    pending 'Please be pending'
  end
end

class NewClass
  include NewHelper
  include Cucumber::RbSupport::RbWorld
end
luke
2018-03-07 05:42:45

you won't ever get Do Not Crash

luke
2018-03-07 05:43:09

the stacktrace looks a bit different, because you're not inside steps.

luke
2018-03-07 05:43:23

@luke uploaded a file: image.png

gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:45:46

Yeahssss! You're a legend @luke, thanks!

luke
2018-03-07 05:46:07

haha no probs. Just be careful including that module though because

luke
2018-03-07 05:46:14

it overwrites puts so puts is now a private method.

luke
2018-03-07 05:46:22

So anywhere you do that, you can no longer call puts.

gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:46:57

Righteo, I'm more of a p and print kind of guy anyways ðŸ˜›

gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:48:29

On a serious note, it's very useful for me like this, so I can just quickly put a todo somewhere inline, without messing up the success/failure statistics.

luke
2018-03-07 05:50:49

todo's are ok, but ideally you wanna use trello or something (Assuming you're at work)

gijs.p
2018-03-07 05:58:05

I'm often setting up initial test suites for a third party. So sometimes they have unfinished functionality and other times a part of the functionality is not relevant for the pilot. Nevertheless, I agree that these kind of thing should be tracked in a issue manager.

enkessler
2018-03-07 07:41:01

@gijs.p Using Cucumber specific code inside of page models is a smell. It violates Separation of Concern. The models shouldn't know that they are being used for testing. They just exist to drive the system. What the system is being driven for is beyond them.

aida
2018-04-04 01:18:49

Hi! I have a question

aida
2018-04-04 01:19:08

Is there any formater to print test execution time in console?

aida
2018-04-04 01:19:28

Iâ€™ve seen one for steps but not for the whole test

gijs.p
2018-04-04 01:22:48

gijs.p
2018-04-04 01:24:36

@gijs.p uploaded a file: totaltesttime.png

aida
2018-04-04 01:44:48

Not all execution, test by test

luke
2018-04-04 02:44:26

someone asked a similar question last week

luke
2018-04-04 02:44:31

In Ruby I would argue to make your own

luke
2018-04-04 02:44:39

make it as granular as you want. It really is like 5-10 lines of code.

luke
2018-04-04 02:44:57

And more custom than any inbuilt one.

We have one for scenario time, and on some features, even a line by line time stamp.

luke
2018-04-04 02:46:31

The Hooks Class inside hooks.rb runs inside the cucumber world. So it shares instance variables.

luke
2018-04-04 02:48:16
 
Before do
  @start_time = Time.now
end

After do
  puts formatted_time
end

def formatted_time
  "#{(Time.now - @start_time).round(2)}s"
end
luke
2018-04-04 02:48:24

there ya go

aida
2018-04-04 02:57:39

Cool thanks, yeah Iâ€™ll do that ðŸ™‚

luke
2018-04-04 03:59:31

Maybe look into some articles on what the "World" is or look inside some of the code.

luke
2018-04-04 03:59:40

It's basically a wrapper layer class around your entire cucumber execution.

aida
2018-04-04 04:00:57

@luke you mention you also have execution time by feature, didnâ€™t you? how do you do so?

luke
2018-04-04 04:38:26

tagging

luke
2018-04-04 04:38:47

you can have multiple Before's / After's

aida
2018-04-04 05:51:13

with tags? Not sure I get it

luke
2018-04-04 06:20:20

aida

gijs.p
2018-04-05 01:22:04

@aida what he means is that you can use filter on tags in the after hook. So you can do the timing only for, say, @feature_01:

Before('@feature_01') do
 @start_time = Time.now
end
After('@feature_01') do
 puts formatted_time
end

That way you can easily group the features by @tags and print out the timing for that specifically. > Yes. If you donâ€™t want to help you can just not answer my question @luke I think that's a rather rude thing to say after he tried to help you quite a bit.

aida
2018-04-05 01:27:14

Oh thatâ€™s not what I was trying to achieve, I probably didnâ€™t explain myself, I was thinking on execution time for every feature, instead of for every scenario on a given feature

luke
2018-04-05 01:29:20

Using the same logic you could append to an array, or re-enumerate the value. If you attack it as the same problem,

luke
2018-04-05 01:29:47
 
Before do
  @cumulative_time ||= 0
end
luke
2018-04-05 01:30:01
 
After do
  @cumulative_time += formatted_time
  puts "Total time taken for feature so far is #{@cumulative_time}"
end
aida
2018-04-05 01:31:36

Yeah, I was thinking on something like that and checking the feature to reset the time

aida
2018-04-05 01:31:54

gijs.p

luke
2018-04-05 02:06:01

Class Variables. Brave soul ðŸ˜„ But yeh, forgot about at_exit Hook. Which is sort of like, do this the very last thing.

gijs.p
2018-04-05 04:23:20

*Thread Reply:* Ghehe, I'm not extremely advanced with programming in Ruby, but this is something I came up with that worked. I actually repeat this kind of moduleClasses quite often in my code. Is there a reason why this is bad? Or is that not what you meant by "Brave soul" ðŸ™‚

luke
2018-04-05 04:25:37

*Thread Reply:* Like you I'm fairly new. But you can use instance variables over class variables. On the whole class variables are considered bad, because there is less control over them. Especially when inheriting self into the Module (So kind of turning it into a metaClass.

The way I look at it, If it works, then it's fine.

gijs.p
2018-04-05 04:28:17

*Thread Reply:* http://i0.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/original/000/977/383/aa1.jpg

gijs.p
2018-04-05 04:29:58

*Thread Reply:* I think (but I should test it) that because of the module inheriting, everytime you call a function from the class, a new instance is created. And thus it needs to be a class variable to be able to store data from 1 function to the other. Let me actually test that ðŸ™‚

gijs.p
2018-04-05 04:34:02

*Thread Reply:* You're right, instance variable @features instead of @@features works fine. Cheers ðŸ‘

aida
2018-04-05 03:56:18

Iâ€™ll check it @gijs.p!

aida
2018-04-05 04:12:58

thatâ€™s it, cool

2018-04-30 00:48:49

I'm guessing you're using Capybara wrappings.

luke
2018-04-30 00:48:58

for reference $ is a js shortcut.

luke
2018-04-30 00:50:38

You probably want something like this.

luke
2018-04-30 00:51:30
 
"document.getElementById('consentsubmit').removeAttr('disabled')"
luke
2018-04-30 00:51:50

Also on a sidenote, thats more of an automation query as opposed to cucumber.

Ryan Chapman
2018-04-30 08:11:12

To add, $ is a jQuery thing. If the website that youâ€™re automating doesnâ€™t have jQuery enabled it just wonâ€™t be usable. Answer Luke has provided is the â€˜vanillaâ€™ JavaScript approach which doesnâ€™t have any restraints and should just work ðŸ™‚

luke
2018-04-30 08:13:45

I "think" (Well I'm fairly certain), because you're using capybara, the way in which you need to execute script code is as mentioned. As they have their own js execution methods. The Gem I maintain (Siteprism), wraps capybara and has that code in it. But I've not personally ever needed to do JS style injection.

Ryan Chapman
2018-04-30 08:18:42
 
page.execute_script("document.getElementById('consentsubmit').removeAttr('disabled');")

Thatâ€™s the Capybara way

Ryan Chapman
2018-04-30 08:19:05

use whatever way works Â¯_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

luke
2018-05-01 01:49:29

@Jonah thats quite a specific ruby question (Nothing really to do with cucumber). To my knowledge you can't.

I'd advocate stubbing the "randomness" and allowing test1 to test error1, and test2 to test error2.

Alternatively, you can say to raise_error.with_message(/message/) if the messages are similar.

Jonah
2018-05-01 01:49:32

@Jonah has joined the channel

Jonah
2018-05-01 07:02:54

@luke Itâ€™s not about randomness in my case. Itâ€™s about not wanting the tests to couple to my implementation. There are validation checks made and errors raised. If you have two validation errors, one of two errors could be raised. If I expect exactly one error, though, then my tests would break if the order of the checks changed. But that should not be the case. Thatâ€™s too brittle.
Separate question: Are rspec questions on topic here?

luke
2018-05-01 07:20:14

its not really cucumber. But I don't mind answering this one.

But when you run your code, it exits for a specific error.

luke
2018-05-01 07:20:34

so It cannot trigger 2 errors. Right...? (Hoping I'm not going crazy and suddenly ruby code can exit with 2 different errors)

Jonah
2018-05-01 07:41:51

@luke Yes, it exits with a specific error. The point is that testing for that error is coupling implicitly to implementation details that should not be coupled to.

luke
2018-05-01 07:42:31

So your unit test checks 2 validation items?

Jonah
2018-05-01 07:57:08

@luke, i want to have test cases where, say, 2 things are wrong. the assertion should be that one of two errors is raised. currently i am just asserting against the one i know will be raised based on knowledge of the implementation. but as i said thatâ€™s brittle.

Jonah
2018-05-01 07:57:29

itâ€™s kind of small point, my rspec question is more pressing ðŸ™‚

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-01 07:58:09

Been trying to play around with this for a little bit, finding it a bit of a pain.

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-01 07:58:59
 
describe 'my Errors' do
    class All_the_errors
        def anError
            raise RuntimeError
        end
    end
    it 'should be able to raise an error' do
        expect {All_the_errors.new.anError}.to raise_error { |e|
            expect(e).to be_a(RuntimeErro) 
        }
    end
end

This works for a single error but I canâ€™t use a || to check for another if the first fails

luke
2018-05-01 08:01:01

To my knowledge you can't do that in Ruby (But I'm no expert). @Jonah I would restructure your tests. And have 2 tests, one for each error.

luke
2018-05-01 08:01:17

If you have an integration test for both, then you would just assert than an error is raised.

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-01 08:01:57

could always rescue multiple error types

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:02:34

@luke i have one for each test already. the idea was to have a test to make sure nothing weird happens when two things are wrong together.

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:03:03

conceptually itâ€™s perfectly valid

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-01 08:05:37
 
        begin 
            All_the_errors.new.anError
        rescue RuntimeError, ArgumentError =&gt; e
            puts e
        end

Will only pass if itâ€™s one of the specified errors I believe

ðŸ‘ Jonah
Jonah
2018-05-01 08:06:51

@luke hereâ€™s my rspec test, with your indulgence. I am testing some classes that live in a rails app under /app/domain, and which get autoloaded by Rails. What do I need to do so that they autload for rspec too? To clarify, the current hack Iâ€™m using to get my rspec test to run is to put the following at the top of the _spec file:

require 'rspec'
$: &lt;&lt; '../../../../app/domain'
require 'authentication/webservice'

I basically just want to know the official rspec way of handling this, but I canâ€™t find anything in the docs.

luke
2018-05-01 08:06:56

â˜ï¸ That is valid yes (Ryan's message)

ðŸ‘ Jonah
luke
2018-05-01 08:07:59

to autoload in files for rspec, I'd just have them inside your spec_helper.

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:08:40

@luke should i be requiring them there or adding to the autoload path and requiring in the spec file?

luke
2018-05-01 08:09:06

If it's one file I'd just add in the one file.

luke
2018-05-01 08:09:12

If it's a directory, add it to LOAD_PATH

luke
2018-05-01 08:09:31

so judging by the above that seems feasible yes.

luke
2018-05-01 08:09:50

Although it feels like your structure is off with the rails app. Doesn't spec live at the same level as app?

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:10:36

app and spec are both in the root

luke
2018-05-01 08:10:42

Should be something like '../app/domain'

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:12:04

i was running the file itself directly from vim during development, and the file is deeper down within spec

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:13:05

i would actually like to retain the ability to run the file on its own, without going thru rspec, but i feel thatâ€™s probably too much against the grain of how itâ€™s intended to work

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:14:34

thanks for your help

luke
2018-05-01 08:23:33

rspec /path/to/file.rb

luke
2018-05-01 08:23:37

or even

luke
2018-05-01 08:23:44

rspec /path/to/file.rb:line_number

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:32:20

@luke the problem with that is it loads everything in the spechelper. which would be fine if the spechelper (i didnâ€™t write it) wasnâ€™t bloated with stuff that makes it take 5 seconds to load. so going thru rspec in this particular case raises my execution time from instant to 5s or so. which is painful to flow.

luke
2018-05-01 08:32:49

ah rightio. So your spec_helper probably has some heavy DB stuff in it. Ok that's understandable (Possibly not correct, but again not 100% myself)

Jonah
2018-05-01 08:34:12

luke
2018-05-04 01:52:01

the response of wait_for (Assuming your helper is coded identically to mine), is yield

luke
2018-05-04 01:52:49

If you're within a spec (individual spec stub), the local assign will work (Although they recommend instance assigns)

luke
2018-05-04 01:52:52

so this would work

luke
2018-05-04 01:53:39
 
wait_for do
  ticket_list = page.find_all('tbody tr')
end.not_to be_empty

ticket_list

You "may" even just be able to do

wait_for do
  page.find_all('tbody tr')
end.not_to be_empty

But I'm not sure if that masks the returned value.

luke
2018-05-04 01:54:31

If you're using Capybara, you can pass in a query value, and that will help you Furthermore, in Capybara 3, this value is by default set to 1+

luke
2018-05-08 00:33:09

you shouldn't use an enumerable ever if you're looking for one value.

luke
2018-05-08 00:33:39

page.all('.class-of-table tr')[index]

luke
2018-05-08 00:33:43

thats literally it.

luke
2018-05-08 00:34:29

Also be careful of not using the default rspec matchers, they're weaker. I always try and use matchers that are "known", to match sounds a bit too vague to me, eq / be / have_text are good ones instead

Arnab
2018-05-08 00:38:36

when you say [index], I suspect you are thinking of the row index

Arnab
2018-05-08 00:38:46

Correct me if I'm wrong

luke
2018-05-08 01:05:47

yes, that will return you an array of rows, you pick which row you want.

luke
2018-05-08 01:06:34

If you want one value (i.e. a row/column), you'd just alter it to.

page.all('.class-of-table tr')[row_index].all('td')[col_index]

Arnab
2018-05-08 03:19:39

i want all the rows

Arnab
2018-05-08 03:20:21

as in...I want to check that every cell in column n has the value X

Arnab
2018-05-08 03:20:38

or rather, has a certain format ðŸ™‚

Arnab
2018-05-08 03:26:24

Is it possible to define a button click step that can be a Given/When/Then step? The point is that developers can write things like 

Given I click the 'reset' button
...
...

Given ...
When I click the 'reset' button
...

Given ...
When ...
Then I click the 'reset' button
And then something happens
Arnab
2018-05-08 03:27:39

I don't really want to create three identical steps. Is there a generic way of defining a step?

Arnab
2018-05-08 03:31:26

Nvm, found this: >The preposition/adverb has no significance when Cucumber is registering or looking for Step Definitions.

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-08 04:40:51

*Thread Reply:* Yep. You can even use ** click the reet button if you ever wanted

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-08 04:40:59

*Thread Reply:* ^ not that I recommend it, but itâ€™s fun to know

luke
2018-05-08 03:48:35

Typically Given steps are a step that is in the past tense, and is something that "has" happened, or "needs to happen"

luke
2018-05-08 03:48:54

When steps are typically actions, so usually present tense, and indicate you're doing something (Walking/Jogging/Clicking a button)

luke
2018-05-08 03:49:28

Then steps are usually future tense, and indicate an expected response (The lights should turn green, The Man should get fat, The height jumped by the Rabbit will be 2metres)

luke
2018-05-08 03:50:50

2 things to note, you can either do testing via enumeration. Or rspec has an all matcher. However this conflicts with Capybara's all matcher.

In the cucumber world, you can create an rspec helper which forcibly uses the rspec all matcher. So you can do something like this.

expect([2,4,6,8,10]).to all be_even

Arnab
2018-05-08 04:26:24

How would I go about creating rspec helpers that forcibly uses that?

Arnab
2018-05-08 04:26:41

And also, that sounds dangerous

luke
2018-05-08 04:50:03

not really. It's really simple. You create a module with a single method that calls the all object, and then mix in that object to the world.

luke
2018-05-08 04:50:17
 
module Helpers
  module CustomMatchers
    def all_match(logic)
      RSpec::Matchers::BuiltIn::All.new(logic)
    end
  end
end

gijs.p
2018-05-09 06:01:27

@Gem You might want to look at Lapis Lazuli, which is a Watir / Cucumber helper which you can use to create a template:

gem install lapis_lazuli
lapis_lazuli create project_name
cd project_name/
bundle install
bundle exec cucumber
gijs.p
2018-05-09 06:02:47

It's not perfect, but it might be inspiring ðŸ™‚

Arnab
2018-05-11 02:57:11

If I have a checkbox of this type, shouldn't check('Request') be enough to check this?

Untitled
Arnab
2018-05-11 02:57:45

(using Capybara if that wasn't obvious)

Arnab
2018-05-11 03:00:37

fyi find('label', text: 'Request') works just fine to find the label

Arnab
2018-05-11 03:02:45

I can also confirm that the input element I am looking for, is inside the innerHTML of the label element I found

luke
2018-05-11 04:14:07

using labels I always advise against, unless you think its unavoidable. CSS Selector has so many powerful attributes.

luke
2018-05-11 04:14:46

.checkbox-mask [type="checkbox"] would be enough or you could even use &gt; if you wanted to be stricter

luke
2018-05-11 04:15:42

Also I'd favour a more human - click event. Because that ensures you're not using enforced JS to set something to checked.

I know that API exists (Set something to checked), but it's not very UX realistic. No-one ever does that in real life.

Arnab
2018-05-11 04:21:38

Well, eventually...I did find('label', text: 'Request').click but I still find check(&lt;locator&gt;) to be more elegant ðŸ˜›

luke
2018-05-11 04:23:08

yes, but you don't know what check is doing under the hood. A Lot of capybara metaprogrammed methods have very long chains.

Are you using selenium? Or pure capybara+rack-test

2018-05-11 04:23:22
