Arnab
2018-05-11 06:21:16

Is it encouraged or frowned upon to use things like 

When('I request to do this thing') do
  step 'I click the "thing" button'
  step 'I click the "thing" link'
end
Jason Koelewyn
2018-05-11 06:40:23

frowned upon. steps should call methods

luke
2018-05-11 06:57:47

on the whole, Jason is right. However there are a couple of exclusions (In my eyes), when you're looking to compress the user facing DSL.

luke
2018-05-11 06:57:57

So my typical e2e tests have 8 given steps.

luke
2018-05-11 06:58:09

I have a compressed step that calls all 8 given steps as 1 given step.

luke
2018-05-11 06:58:36

Also for reference, there is the steps method which takes a newline delimited set of strings (Keywords are needed)

luke
2018-05-11 06:59:10

so you could do

steps "
  When I click the \"thing\" button
  When I click the \"thing\" link
"
Arnab
2018-05-11 07:05:27

I think my point is that there are some methods/steps that can be reused

Arnab
2018-05-11 07:05:43

Things like checking that there is a dropbox with a certain placeholder on the page

Arnab
2018-05-11 07:06:01

I don't care whether I do that by calling ruby code or by calling dynamic steps

Arnab
2018-05-11 07:06:09

I just want to know what the best practice is ðŸ™‚

luke
2018-05-11 07:17:13

depends on the frequency. I personally don't mind re-using steps for some of our Given steps. But that is because in our use case, we are quite given heavy

Gem
2018-05-11 08:21:48

Noooooo, don't call steps from other steps. >.<

Gem
2018-05-11 08:22:46

It's anti-pattern and will be deprecated eventually.

gijs.p
2018-05-12 02:42:07

@luke I used to do the exact same thing, until I came here and @Gem plus others told me it's not the way to go. What I do now it something like this:

# ./features/step_definitions/something_steps.rb
When('I request to do this thing') do
  Something.do_both_things()
end

# ./features/helpers/something_helper.rb
module Something
  class &lt;&lt; self
    #@formatter:off
    def click_button(txt); driver.button(text: txt).click; end
    def click_link(txt); driver.a(text:txt).click; end
    #@formatter:on
    def do_both_things
      Something.click_button('thing')
      Something.click_link('thing')
    end
  end
end
Arnab
2018-05-12 06:06:08

Ok that's fine

Arnab
2018-05-12 06:06:20

What I'm not hearing though...is why this is a bad idea

gijs.p
2018-05-12 07:28:38
  • Better backtrace information
  • You don't put variables in strings that are caught by regexes
  • Your IDE has a better understanding of what is happening
  • As a result of the above, debugging is easier Also personally, using the helpers, gave me a much better overview of what is happening in the code, making it easier to refactor problems and be less repetitive in my code. @Gem anything to add?
Arnab
2018-05-12 08:05:32

Hm, so when you say > You don't put variables in strings that are caught by regexes

You mean that the following should never be done:

When('I click the {string} link') do |link_text|
  find_link(link_text).click
end
gijs.p
2018-05-12 08:20:26

Well, that's a separate discussion. What I meant was:

  • The step definitions are necessary to convert readable (gherkin) text into functions.
  • But lets not overuse this "text-to-code"-functionality by using steps in steps

In regards to litterly translating variables from your Gherkin into functions: It's not seen as best practise, but if it works for you and Gherkin steps are clear in what it's testing, feel free to do it.

gijs.p
2018-05-12 08:22:04

I used to have this 1 function to rule them all, but eventually I was doing 90% of the maintenance in that 1 function, trying to build in more and more exceptions. If someone else had to take over from me, they'd need a week to figure our this find_link() function ðŸ™‚

brasmusson
2018-05-12 11:39:42

@Arnab See: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1525432752000091?thread_ts=1525225428.000089&cid=C60TKS3SL https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1525348407000171

Andrew Premdas (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/UABJRHGP7)
<p>@Michael Jang Yes there is something inherently bad about nested steps. They encourage you to put your code in the wrong place with the wrong method signature. By their nature what you will end with is a fragile feature set where you make a change in one scenario and suddenly completely unrelated scenarios break. This will be do to step calling another step which calls another which relies on a variable being set which calls another step and in this particular case perhaps the variable is wrong but thats going to be really hard to find out as you traverse your steps. I learnt this about 10 years ago when I unested, every step in an e-commerce project whose features had become so unreliable that I was beginning to have severe doubts about the value of using BDD and Cucumber. After 5 days of untangling chains of step calls, applying the extract method refactoring pattern (see Fowler, Refactoring) I ended up with something that was much simpler and more reliable, so much so that when a week or so later I used a nested step I got called out on it by a junior developer. Everything had improved so much over a short period of time and he didnâ€™t want ever have to debug nested steps again.</p> <p>Of course this is just anecdotal evidence. Combine that with the logic of the my first answer and the idea that step definitions are just not a good place for code to live, and hopefully we have enough to convince most folks ðŸ™‚</p>
Original URL: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1525432752000091?thread_ts=1525225428.000089&amp;cid=C60TKS3SL
Thread in Slack Conversation
Andrew Premdas (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/UABJRHGP7)
<p>Calling steps within steps (nested steps) is a really bad idea. There is also a much better alternative. If you think about what that step call is doing you will see that it is just a method call with a really clumsy signature. If you think about what code in a step definition is, its just the body of a method. If we extract that body into its own method then we can easily make the same calls in both methods. This achieves two things</p> <ol><li>Replaces a really clunky method call with a simple method call</li><li>Extracts code out of step definitions and into helper methods</li> </ol> <p>The first is an obvious improvement but perhaps not that significant. The second has much bigger benefits as you continue to work with your features. </p> <p>When you take this approach your step definitions are now responsible for one simple thing, translating natural language into a call. This follow the Unix approach of having simple tools that do one thing well. </p> <p>Your helper methods are in your programming language fully accessible through simple calls. You now can use your programming language to control and organise your test api and use it to create tools that make things easier for your step definitions.</p>
Original URL: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1525348407000171
Thread in Slack Conversation
luke
2018-05-14 00:57:43

@Gem - For my one use case (Most of our compressed steps we could ditch tomorrow), that is complicated is where we call 8 Given steps.

Would you just have us copy the code from those 8 given steps? - I suppose not being DRy isn't a concern inside the step code. But it's something to consider?

Paul_N
2018-05-14 01:16:33

How do people use ruby exceptions in their e2e cucumber tests? Personally I only ever use them when establishing initial connections (api, databases etc) I have just looked at some code that uses them on every Watir element!!! Why? Horribly slow, obfuscates where the real errors are and results in humongous step defs and page objects. These are not user facing programs so what is the point?

luke
2018-05-14 01:22:23

on the whole the error code is irrelevant. But we have custom errors for nearly every potential endpoint we can think of, and then rewrite these custom errors (and messages)

luke
2018-05-14 01:22:40

so a specific timeout in a certain place is a NoResultsError e.t.c.

Arnab
2018-05-14 03:29:53

Is it possible to use some kind of command line argument for setting the capybara driver to :selenium_chrome when running cucumber (something like cucumber set-driver=selenium_chrome)

Paul_N
2018-05-14 03:45:19

@luke but you donâ€™t wrap every interaction in begin/rescue blocks I am sure? I just looked at a single Then step in our code base and it was 90 lines long with a cyclomatic complexity of 22. Mainly because of wrapping things in exceptions.

luke
2018-05-14 03:46:19

Right, so what you do is you have methods that raise items. Here is an example of something you "could do"

luke
2018-05-14 03:47:26
 
def pick_flight(int)
  validate_flights_present(int)
  select_result(int)
end

def validate_flights_present(int)
  raise MissingFlightError if results &lt; int
end
Paul_N
2018-05-14 04:09:37

Could a similar result be achieved just by using Rspec expectations though?

luke
2018-05-14 04:59:28

this isn't a spec, this is a when step, you're validating you aren't picking an invalid flight.

luke
2018-05-14 04:59:46

so if i ask for flight number 11, but there are only 8 flights, you should crash (or alter the flight to flight 1)

luke
2018-05-14 05:00:20

@Arnab - Do you use dotenv in your stack>? If so it's a doddle.

luke
2018-05-14 05:00:42

create your verbose driver using capybara and then set the environment variable to the capabilities class.

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:15:58

@luke Since i have no idea what you are saying, I'm going to say "no" ðŸ˜›

luke
2018-05-14 05:16:13

in your gemfile do you use a gem called dotenv

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:16:19

But I did end up using an env variable CAPYBARA_DRIVER

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:16:31

nope

luke
2018-05-14 05:16:38

In 99.9999% of situations you want to.

luke
2018-05-14 05:16:49

So get that in your stack, and start using it. You'll find testing so much easier.

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:18:25

seems like overkill for just accessing ENV['CAPYBARA_DRIVER']

luke
2018-05-14 05:22:23

not for that. But you can start setting loads of environment specific variables across your suite quickly and easily.

luke
2018-05-14 05:22:39

And the amount of keys you can set depends on what you want to customise / setup in CI

luke
2018-05-14 05:22:51

we set around 20 diff keys - on the fly.

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:23:02

luke
2018-05-14 05:23:16

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:23:34

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:23:45

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:24:26

So right now, I have a comment in the README saying what a dev needs to do if they want to use chrome instead of headless chrome

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:25:00

essentially export CAPYBARA_DRIVER=selenium_chrome

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:25:34

and then I use to_sym to select the :selenium_chrome driver in my env.rb file if the ENV variable is set

Arnab
2018-05-14 05:25:45

Otherwise it is set to :selenium_chrome_headless

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-14 07:34:04

@Arnab You can pass through an environment variable in the command line or in the cucumber profile and match against that in the environment

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-14 07:35:14

so just for local I have stuff like this in my bashprofile:

function chromeRun() {
  IN_BROWSER_CHROME=true bundle exec cucumber -t "$1" --color;
}

Which I invoke with: chromeRun @someStuff

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-14 07:35:46

then Have the ifs in env

pascalbe
2018-05-14 07:37:23

@luke actually I require the cucumber lib in our Rakefile and that fails already. so the test doesnâ€™t even start

luke
2018-05-14 07:40:52

hmmm? thats a bit odd. Not sure you should be doing that?

pascalbe
2018-05-14 07:42:45

yea, I thought so >.< Iâ€™m new to ruby and thats how it was set up by colleagues. Where is that handled normally (the require stuff)? Or is that even needed?

luke
2018-05-14 07:43:52

in rake you will call bundle exec cucumber

luke
2018-05-14 07:44:05

or some derivative. Once you do that, that then runs cucumber and will call your requires in your class files.

pascalbe
2018-05-14 07:46:45

ahh okay. sounds better. thx. ðŸ™‚ but still wondering why that strange error appeared ðŸ˜®

luke
2018-05-14 07:53:41

I think it's some sort of cyclical error.

luke
2018-05-14 07:54:29

At the point you require your library of code, the steps aren't mixed into the ruby runner and as such it might be getting very confused. Not going to lie, it's very deep inside the code your error is occurring.

Gem
2018-05-14 09:09:54

@luke The typical use-case would be to use helper methods instead of calling steps.

Gem
2018-05-14 09:10:31

The second link that @brasmusson shared talks about it well: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1525348407000171

Andrew Premdas (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/UABJRHGP7)
<p>Calling steps within steps (nested steps) is a really bad idea. There is also a much better alternative. If you think about what that step call is doing you will see that it is just a method call with a really clumsy signature. If you think about what code in a step definition is, its just the body of a method. If we extract that body into its own method then we can easily make the same calls in both methods. This achieves two things</p> <ol><li>Replaces a really clunky method call with a simple method call</li><li>Extracts code out of step definitions and into helper methods</li> </ol> <p>The first is an obvious improvement but perhaps not that significant. The second has much bigger benefits as you continue to work with your features. </p> <p>When you take this approach your step definitions are now responsible for one simple thing, translating natural language into a call. This follow the Unix approach of having simple tools that do one thing well. </p> <p>Your helper methods are in your programming language fully accessible through simple calls. You now can use your programming language to control and organise your test api and use it to create tools that make things easier for your step definitions.</p>

Do you want it to interact with someone on the page, or to have a visible cursor?

Selenium/capybara never has a visible cursor you can see, but you can click on certain parts of the page. Everything else is done via element locating with no cursor stuff involved.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-05-22 05:59:55

@Arnab Cucumber doesnâ€™t implement any functionality for interacting with web pages, DOM or browsers. I suggest you ask the community behind the browser automation tool youâ€™re using.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-05-22 06:00:29

The Capybara folks..

Arnab
2018-05-22 06:00:46

Yup I know. They are however, not that fast at responding so was hoping for some luck here ðŸ˜›

luke
2018-05-22 07:57:22

haha, if you're looking to automate a datepicker, then I would advise using either A calculator object, to work out what you are predicting to select, and then picking an element from an index

Or crawl all elements, and stop when you find one.

Either of those is fine, I have opinions on which is better e.t.c.

Jennifer

Jennifer
2018-05-22 23:32:38

how i can i compare integer text value in cucumber??

Jennifer
2018-05-22 23:33:17

find('#test-eth-balance').text == 95.0 is it true or not?

luke
2018-05-23 00:02:56

again, you're talking about using the API binding of whatever language cucumber is in.

So if you're in ruby (Which that looks like you're using capybara). then that is fine.

One thing to note, capybara's #text method returns a string. Not an integer. So you would need to do .to_i on the end of your method chain.

cc/ @Jennifer

2018-05-24 02:32:00

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-24 02:32:07

@luke: Here's something interesting. I can find an input element by doing find('.ask-box').find('input'). However find('.ask-box').find('input').fill_in(with: 'test') does not work. But find('.ask-box').find('input').set('test') does

luke
2018-05-24 03:32:08

It could be that you're selecting an element incorrect - set will use JS injection wherever possible. I think fillin uses something close to sendkeys

For ref you don't need to chain find commands. you can just do a complete css selector.

It also could be a bug....

Arnab
2018-05-24 03:32:59

aha, I found out what it is

Arnab
2018-05-24 03:33:11

fill_in detects on id or name

Arnab
2018-05-24 03:33:26

but I was trying to get it by the element type

Arnab
2018-05-24 03:33:42

which apparently works for find but not for fill_in

luke
2018-05-24 03:35:13

there you go then.

luke
2018-05-24 03:35:29

luke
2018-05-24 03:42:14

luke
2018-05-24 03:42:34
 
def type_into(field, value)
  page.find(field).send_keys(value)
end
luke
2018-05-24 03:43:05

you can also add custom handlers, like wipebefore (true/false), fasttype (true/false)

Go nuts, make anything you want.

luke
2018-05-24 03:44:03

2018-05-24 06:06:52

When I run cucumber --retry 5 features/flaky-features.feature I get a list of flaky tests. But how can I get the same when doing bundle exec cucumber --retry 5 --format html ?

Arnab
2018-05-24 06:13:32

Or is it just "look at the test(s) that both failed and passed" and those are the flaky tests?

Jason Koelewyn
2018-05-24 06:34:34

Retrying flakey tests is a bad practice. What is that telling you? if a test fails and the manual test passes, fix the test. that is maintenance job #1

luke
2018-05-24 06:35:23

luke
2018-05-24 06:35:41

We retry using rake, as at the time the retry option didn't work correctly for us. And we also only set the limit to 1.

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-24 06:35:49

We have retries in as well. If we didnâ€™t thereâ€™d be a lot of â€˜failed testsâ€™ that were purely connectivity

luke
2018-05-24 06:36:01

â˜ï¸ This. But I'd urge your value to be 1.

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-24 06:36:17

yeah I only do the single retry

Ryan Chapman
2018-05-24 06:36:25

If it gets through twice, then itâ€™s probably an issue

luke
2018-05-24 06:49:29

yeh. Occassionally for us (As our data feed is live), we get a blip. Which is fair (Especially as our e2e regular testing, done around 10 times a day, runs 40 1min tests)

Arnab
2018-05-24 07:46:39

That's not really the question I asked. I asked how I can get a list of flaky tests when running with format html

Arnab
2018-05-24 07:47:44

I'd honestly rather get a list of flaky tests than have some randomly fail

Arnab
2018-05-24 07:48:15

There is a distinction between a test that always fails because the app is not behaving correctly, versus a test that sometimes fails because of connectivity issues (as someone mentioned above)

luke
2018-05-24 07:58:49

--format rerun

luke
2018-05-24 07:59:07

that returns you failing tests. You can then pipe that to a file.

luke
2018-05-24 07:59:17

That's what we do in our rakefile.

Arnab
2018-05-24 08:06:16

Do you also generate a HTML report?

luke
2018-05-24 08:47:43

yep

luke
2018-05-24 08:47:57

there's a "nuance" in cucumber, whereby if you use a profile, you can have dual formatst.

luke
2018-05-24 08:48:10

It might be a defect, I'm not sure. But it works for us.

brasmusson
2018-05-24 11:41:08

In Cucumber-Ruby there is the "rerun feature" (--format rerun) and there is the "retry feature" (run the scenario again - up to n times - if it fails, before moving on to the next scenario).

With respect to the "retry feature", the summary listing does distinguish "failed" scenarios (always failed when retried), "flaky" scenarios (failed first, but passed on retry), and "passed" scenarios (passed the first time). The summary listing code does that by examining the event stream and detecting that a scenario first fails and then passes. No formatter perform the same flaky scenario detection, but includes each execution of every scenario. It was a deliberate decision not to delay the inclusion of the retry feature until the reporting was "perfect" in all aspects (all formatters).

For a formatter to perform a better reporting of flaky scenarios, the flaky detection needs to implemented in it, and it has to be decided how to report flaky scenarios (both the case that a scenario is flaky, and how it failed when it did fail are relevant to report).

jerseysu
2018-05-26 22:23:05

@jerseysu has joined the channel

2018-05-29 03:46:30

how do you run cucumber. Through jenkins or on command line?

luke
2018-05-29 03:46:36

or through IDE

luke
2018-05-29 03:46:50

Each fix is different but a one liner.

luke
2018-05-29 03:46:56

(We have same issue)

pascalbe
2018-05-29 03:57:38

I run it via the cucumber rake task. I got formatters and output folders specified through the cucumber.yml

luke
2018-05-29 03:58:03

awesome stuff. so if you're running it on the command line then, and not through a CI interface all you need to do is.

luke
2018-05-29 03:58:19

create the folder, add folder/**.png to .gitignore. Maybe add a .keep file which is blank just to be sure.

luke
2018-05-29 03:58:40

#win

pascalbe
2018-05-29 03:59:16

ðŸ˜„ okay, thanks. I thought about that workaround. but thereâ€™s no way that cucumber creates the folders itself?

luke
2018-05-29 03:59:27

its not cucumbers responsibility at that point. It's ruby's

luke
2018-05-29 03:59:40

and ruby throws an error when you try write to a file that has an invalid directory structure.

luke
2018-05-29 04:00:11

if you want to programmatically think of it. It does something like this.

if Dir.exist?(mydir)
  'do stuff'
else
  raise Error
end
pascalbe
2018-05-29 04:00:41

okay >.< thanks for the explanation. ðŸ™‚

luke
2018-05-29 04:01:03

No probs.

If you're running it through jenkins, and on fresh containers. Just do a couple of bash commands to verify/create

luke
2018-05-29 04:01:30

but if you're running off your repo, that isn't needed. So long as you ensure the repo contains the blank folder (That's why I use the rails-ism of .keep)

luke
2018-05-29 04:10:37

My travis script (Might be portable), is

before_script:
  - |
    case $browser in
      firefox)
        wget <https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/releases/download/v0.20.1/geckodriver-v0.20.1-linux64.tar.gz>
        mkdir geckodriver
        tar -xzf geckodriver**.tar.gz -C geckodriver
        export PATH=$PATH:$PWD/geckodriver
        ;;
      chrome)
        sudo apt-get update -qq &amp;&amp; sudo apt-get install -y chromium-chromedriver
        export PATH=$PATH:/usr/lib/chromium-browser/
        ;;
    esac
  - export DISPLAY=:99.0
  - sh -e /etc/init.d/xvfb start

2018-05-29 04:11:19

Ayethin
2018-06-01 04:14:41

What does your env.rb file look like? ``` Capybara.registerdriver :customchromeheadless do |app| browseroptions = ::Selenium::WebDriver::Chrome::Options.new() browseroptions.args << '--headless' browseroptions.args << '--no-sandbox' browseroptions.args << '--disable-gpu' browseroptions.args << '--window-size=1920,1080' Capybara::Selenium::Driver.new(app, browser: :chrome, options: browser_options ) end

Capybara.defaultdriver = :customchromeheadless Capybara.defaultmaxwaittime = 5 ShowMeTheCookies.registeradapter(:customchrome_headless, ShowMeTheCookies::Selenium)```

Ryan Chapman
2018-06-01 04:14:42

Note: The test was run on a browser and not using standalone

Arnab
2018-06-01 04:15:32

@Arnab uploaded a file: Untitled

Untitled
Ayethin
2018-06-01 04:21:30

have you tried using a custom driver config? rather than their standard headless one, that is the only thing I can think of at the moment that might be causing issues?

Arnab

ðŸ‘ Ayethin, Ryan Chapman
Paul_N
2018-06-06 01:58:26

What is the primary factor that slows down test suites. We have a cucumber/Ruby/Watir suite that uses a lot of gems and is about 60 features and it is getting painfully slow. Is it cucumber that has difficulty with lots of test suites or is it a heavily laden gem wise Ruby that is at fault?

gijs.p
2018-06-06 02:23:52

@Paul_N for me the main slowdown is the browser communication and page load times. For us the automation is a daily regression test running at night, so it's no real problem if it run for longer than an hour. Did you ever try running cucumber -f usage -o usage_report.txt? It could give you an insight on which steps are most re-used and takes the longest overall time to execute.

Paul_N
2018-06-06 02:34:21

@gijs.p never run that report but will give it a go - thanks. I have isolated one of the features and run that separately without the overhead of the rest of the test suite and only with required gems and it is double the speed!

gijs.p
2018-06-06 02:56:15

Oh wow, I wouldn't expect the number of gems to slow the test suite down that much. Unless the time loss is from the bundle install.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-06-06 05:54:11

@Paul_N in the vast majority of cases your program (and therefore your tests) are I/O bound. Too much networking in your stack. Iâ€™d be very surprised if the number of gems has significant impact.

Ryan Chapman
2018-06-06 06:54:43

@Aslak HellesÃ¸y what would you suggest to mitigate the amount of networking involved?

Paul_N
2018-06-06 10:30:50

@Aslak HellesÃ¸y @gijs.p I have had a look at this now and it appears to be the preconditions and set up that is really slowing things down ie an overstuffed env.rb. There is a lot of legacy code I did not write so I might need to push a ticket to have a good look at trimming all that down. Thanks for the advice.

gijs.p
2018-06-06 13:01:40

*Thread Reply:* You're welcome & good luck ðŸ™‚

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-06-06 13:45:08

@Ryan Chapman how to remove all I/O: https://twitter.com/ChicagoRuby/status/1004179711914803200?s=20

Arnab
2018-06-08 03:45:56

Is there a way to do a common before stepdef for all features? (As in, not do the same stepdef over and over again for all features but once for everything)

matt-SmartBear
2018-06-08 15:13:45

@Arnab by default any Ruby file in the features will be required before your features run. Just put it in a file in there somewhere. features/support/env.rb is magic as itâ€™s the first one to be loaded.

Gem
2018-06-12 16:03:15

Sharing this question here, too, as the solution may be language specific and to possibly get more eyes. ðŸ™‚

Jayson Smith (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/U6FV13MB4)
<p>Curious if there's a way that I can determine whether or not the current run of Cucumber is currently a retry or not? I imagine there is due to the retry behavior being able to keep track across multiple runs, I'm just not sure how to get that status myself. </p> <p>Use case: My company has some additional logging in our system that we want to enable only for scenarios that are retried.</p>
Slack Conversation
brasmusson
2018-06-13 00:30:32

Are you talking about "retry" (--retry N) or "rerun" (@rerun.txt)?

man4testing
2018-06-13 01:42:35

@man4testing has joined the channel

Gem
2018-06-13 08:46:25

@brasmusson Right now, simply retry

Arnab
2018-06-14 03:46:20

@Gem: What is the purpose of the logging scenarios that are retried?

Gem
2018-06-14 08:11:44

@Arnab We have a tracking/tracing system in our code that allows us to record calls in our system for troubleshooting. We've been having it run on everything our tests do, but that's expensive and runs into other issues. Instead, we'll be turning it on for items that are retried so in case they continue to fail, we'll have the tracing turned on and be able to utilize it for troubleshooting. ðŸ™‚

Arnab
2018-06-14 08:50:12

So if the first try of a scenario fails, you want to log try #2 and only that?

Arnab
2018-06-14 08:53:34

If that is a case, do an after step where you do this: 1) Did the scenario pass? Ok, let it go. 2) If the scenario failed, add its name to a hash scenarios_to_retry

Then you add a before step where you check if the current scenario is in that hash. Enable logging. Profit! ;)

Arnab
2018-06-14 08:56:15

@Gem

Gem
2018-06-14 08:57:41

Yeah, that's definitely one way! I've actually got a solution that reuses retry and doesn't get in the way of Cucumber's built in behavior. :D

Arnab
2018-06-14 08:58:59

Iâ€™m curious to what that is?

Gem
2018-06-14 11:03:19

@Arnab Here's what I've come up with. https://github.com/jaysonesmith/cuke-retry-tracking

GitHub
jaysonesmith/cuke-retry-tracking
Contribute to cuke-retry-tracking development by creating an account on GitHub.
Original URL: https://github.com/jaysonesmith/cuke-retry-tracking
brasmusson
2018-06-17 09:32:57

*Thread Reply:* You should use scenario.location instead of scenario.name to check if a scenario is retried, the names do not need to be unique.

brasmusson
2018-06-17 09:38:14

> It looks like Cucumber retries outline examples immediately afterward too.

Of course, there is no difference between Scenario and Scenario Outlines with respect to the execution. They are both compiled to Pickles before the execution (well, Cucumber-Ruby does not yet use the Gherkin compiler yet, but perform the corresponding compilation by itself).

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber
cucumber - Cucumber monorepo - polyglot home for Cucumber building blocks
Original URL: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/gherkin#pickles
ðŸ‘ Gem
Gem
2018-06-17 12:34:04

Thank you @brasmusson!

Nicole
2018-06-18 11:26:22

@Nicole has joined the channel

Charan
2018-06-23 18:38:59

@Charan has joined the channel

Gem
2018-06-26 10:23:06

Hey @brasmusson, in trying to implement --strict I'm not getting an actual failed message in my output for an undefined step. Am I misunderstanding the functionality, or am I experiencing something off?

Gem version: 3.1.1 Command: bundle exec cucumber -S features/ad_keys.feature:24 Results:

4 scenarios (4 undefined)
25 steps (21 skipped, 4 undefined)
0m0.019s
brasmusson
2018-06-26 11:25:15

@Gem --strict affects the exit code, not the step or scenario status in the summary. If a scenario is undefined the summary will say so regardless, but with --strict the exit code will be non-zero for a summary like the one above.

Gem
2018-06-26 11:25:50

Ah, gotcha! Thank you. ðŸ™‚ I'll give that a go.

luke
2018-06-27 02:08:21

so in jenkins or whatever it'll appear red instead of green

murphy8486
2018-06-28 12:06:20

is anyone familiar with rubymine I am getting this message on the latest EAP build... 'Error running 'Scenario: Cucumber test': Feature file 'C' doesnt exist' with the latest EAP build?

luke
2018-06-29 01:39:01

Are you using Cucumber3. There are a lot of issues with RubyMines compatibility with Cucumber3. If I were you I'd wait until 2018.2 is cut and is stable.

Also with EAP builds they experiment a lot (Especially with cucumber since they haven't got it fully working yet)

â€˜/(?:englishpattern)|(?:portuguesepattern)/â€˜

2018-07-03 13:22:28

If you absolutely have to I recommend you define the Portuguese and English stepdefs separately - next to each other. The body of each stepdef would call the same method where the logic is.

Jonah
2018-07-06 06:41:20

per the advice iâ€™m @mlvandijk, iâ€™m moving this question about the purpose of env.rb and best practices around setting up World to here:

The line from http://docs.cucumber.io/cucumber/configuration/ that addresses my question (to some extent) is: > Customisations that must be loaded before the rest of Cucumber initialises must be placed at the beginning of the env.rb file.

So would it be fair to say that global setup that needs to be run exactly once (not per scenario) and before anything else should be put in env.rb?

Iâ€™ve noticed that this also means if I setup my World in env.rb (which I think is correct?) that I have to explicitly require my helper modules. Eg: ```require_relative './world'

World(FridayStepHelper)```

Does that look right to you?

mvz
2018-07-06 06:48:07

Yes, that looks about right. You can put stuff that needs to run once in a Before block.

mvz
2018-07-06 06:48:33

I think that quote from the docs is about loading code, not running it.

Jonah
2018-07-06 07:07:37

@mvz, thanks. it just felt sort of strange that despite cucumber having an auto-loading system that does in fact load world.rb, i had to explicitly require it. It makes sense given that env.rb is loaded first, but it made me wonder if there was a better practice around this?

Eg, one thing that seems to work (though Iâ€™m not sure if itâ€™s guaranteed to work by the loading order) is to put the helper modules into their own files, eg friday_step_helper.rb, and then make the world.rb file do nothing but the call to World: ```

this is the whole file world.rb

World(FridayStepHelper)```

Now everything still runs with an empty env.rb.

mvz
2018-07-06 07:09:54

That's probably a question of load order.

Jonah
2018-07-06 07:10:29

I just checkedâ€¦ the above only works because the files are loaded alphabetically.

Jonah
2018-07-06 07:12:13

so it looks like the explicit require in env.rb is the way to go.

Jonah
2018-07-06 07:34:24

confirmed the following about the order of execution:

  1. cucumber loads env.rb
  2. cucumber loads all included files in the profile from the -r dirs in alphabetical order

It seems that it would make more sense here to have some hook into the â€œafter everything is loadedâ€ event, so you could setup World at that point, when all the helper modules have been loaded already, and thus avoid the explicit require.

Doesnâ€™t look like thatâ€™s possible, thoughâ€¦

mvz
2018-07-06 08:02:49

@Jonah You can add more and more stuff to World gradually, do you can have features/support/foo.rb ending in World(Foo), and features/support/bar.rb ending in World(Bar), and both Foo and Bar will be part of World.

Jonah
2018-07-06 08:05:40

@mvz yes, i think thatâ€™s probably the right play. i was reluctant to do that because it couples the definition of the helpers to the act of calling World to actually add them to world. But I suppose in most cases thatâ€™s not a problem, and in any case that appears to be the intended design.

Jonah
2018-07-06 08:16:21

Is there a way to get your project root directory (ie, the dir cucumber is invoked from)? I want to be able to add it to my $LOAD_PATH so that instead of loading the rails environment with: require ::File.expand_path('../../../../../config/environment', __FILE__) in env.rb I can just do require 'config/environment'.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-07-06 08:32:52

Jonah: Dir.pwd

Just for clarity I wasnâ€™t trying to require the World construct â€” i had just put my â€œworldâ€ helpers in a file called world.rb in that example.

mvz
2018-07-06 10:58:12

@Jonah rails generate cucumber:install will put the necessary lines in your env.rb. After that you just invoke cucumber in the usual way. I think it also sets up a rake task for you.

ðŸ‘ Jonah
luke
2018-07-09 00:49:26

@Jonah I'd personally disagree with your statement RE world. I actually invoke World(**Modules) inside env.rb

luke
2018-07-09 00:49:46

Reason being is in that file I create everything that needs instantiating procedurally (Driver / Environment)

mvz
2018-07-09 05:51:37

@luke I would consider World(SomeModule) to be declarative rather than procedural, but I guess it depends a bit on what that does behind the scenes. I always picture it as a kind of include.

luke
2018-07-09 06:01:42

Fair point. but then when you trigger the very first line of your first scenario, anything inside the World "should" be usable. So you shouldn't have it conditionally included. Or if so, the condition is, when I start.

luke
2018-07-09 06:06:31

and to answer your question, it is basically an include. With a bit more than that, but a good analogy.

Jonah
2018-07-09 06:39:59

@luke so thatâ€™s how i had it originally, but because env.rb gets loaded first, i was needing to require '&lt;file with helper&gt;' in env.rb so that I could then World(FileWithHelper) below. That seemed to me to defeat the purpose of the auto-loadingâ€¦

Jonah
2018-07-09 06:41:36

which is what led me to the belief that the intended design was just to put the World(FileWithHelper) calls at the bottom of file_with_helper.rb. Also Iâ€™d seen that pattern in a few snippets. If Iâ€™m still missing something though Iâ€™d love to know.

luke
2018-07-09 06:43:02

nah that's again a valid point. So for my env.rb i just have it requiring a bucketful of stuff and then run one method (create_driver) - as i run browser automation

luke
2018-07-09 06:43:18
 
# frozen_string_literal: true

require 'dotenv'
Dotenv.load('.env')
require_relative 'all'

World(
  Helpers::CustomMatchers,
  WaitFor,
  Helpers::Methods,
  Helpers::EnvVariables,
  Helpers::SeleniumInteractions,
  Helpers::Spinners,
)

Capybara.default_driver = :selenium

Drivers::Driver.new.create_driver
luke
2018-07-09 06:43:53

require_relative 'all' uses activerecord style auto-requires in each folder - to ensure the load order is forced.

Jonah
2018-07-09 06:54:36

@luke interesting. would you mind pasting in a snip from all? fwiw, i normally do prefer to have all my dependencies explicitly listed, so the cucumber autoloading (which afaict assumes a design that doesnâ€™t depend on load order, and like rails takes a â€œload everythingâ€ approach) goes against my preferred way of designing, but at the same time my default is to try to use tools as intended when possible. hence all my questions around recommended cucumber best practices.

luke
2018-07-09 06:57:41
 
# frozen_string_literal: true

require 'bundler/setup'
require 'selenium-webdriver'
require 'site_prism'
require 'rspec'
require 'capybara'
require 'capybara/rspec'
require 'capybara/cucumber'

require_relative 'helpers/all'

require_relative 'folder1/all'
require_relative 'folder2/all'
require_relative 'folder3/all'
ðŸ‘ Jonah
luke
2018-07-09 06:57:55

the folders are obviously named differently.

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 07:57:33

@luke ooh that looks cool. Iâ€™ve been using the require_all gem to do similar. Does all require recursively?

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 07:57:54

if I require_relative 'lib/all' would it do all sub folders, to clarify

luke
2018-07-09 07:58:01

no it wouldnt.

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 07:58:24

Gotcha, thanks

luke
2018-07-09 07:58:34

so the all inside folder1 for example would either require the all files in all of the folders below, or once you're at a directory that only contains files. you just require each file.

luke
2018-07-09 07:58:57

so one of my folders looks like

# frozen_string_literal: true

require_relative 'bags'
require_relative 'departure_date'
require_relative 'filters'
require_relative 'graph'
require_relative 'results'
require_relative 'search'
require_relative 'stage2'
Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 07:59:35

I see, thanks ðŸ™‚

Jonah
2018-07-09 08:03:09

@luke where is that â€œallâ€ functionality coming from?

luke
2018-07-09 08:03:39

I'm not sure what you mean.

Jonah
2018-07-09 08:07:03

@luke is it a gem, or defined by rails, or defined by cucumber itself? or is it just something built into ruby that iâ€™ve somehow never seen before?

luke
2018-07-09 08:07:12

none of the above. I just do it.

luke
2018-07-09 08:07:24

It's based off 1 of the 2 ways of doing file path requirements / namespacing.

luke
2018-07-09 08:07:45

the alternative way is to have a file the same name as your folder. and in that file, you require everything inside that folder.

luke
2018-07-09 08:08:01
 
lib
  folder1
  folder1.rb
luke
2018-07-09 08:08:06

and in folder1.rb you have

luke
2018-07-09 08:08:22
 
# frozen_string_literal: true

require_relative 'folder1/file1'
require_relative 'folder1/file2'
luke
2018-07-09 08:08:48

and your structure is

lib
  folder1
    file1.rb
    file2.rb
  folder1.rb
Jonah
2018-07-09 08:14:06

@luke how do you handle requires of files above the folder? two major cases come to mind that iâ€™ve been struggling with:

  1. you are using cucumber profiles (each one has the normal cucumber folder structure but inside a folder with the profile name) and some step definitions are shared among the profiles. I was considering a cucumber/shared folder, but then in your scheme iâ€™d need to do require_relative '../shared/whatever' to get at them.
  2. you need to use stuff from the rails lib folder. my solution for this atm is to rely on loading the rails env.
luke
2018-07-09 08:16:24

I'm running a browser automation framework. Not a rails app. But once you require something once it is loaded into your environment for that ruby process.

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 08:25:16

@luke require_all gem allows you to do require_rel '../../lib/helpers/**.rb', if thatâ€™ll save you some lines?

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 08:25:45

I guess you can do the dir.pwd method too, but I havenâ€™t changed that yet ðŸ™‚

luke
2018-07-09 08:25:50

it would possibly save us some lines yes. but in some instances the load order matters we don't know the load order of that gem.

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 08:25:59

understood

luke
2018-07-09 08:26:04

because cucumber by default autoloads all ruby files.

luke
2018-07-09 08:26:19

So if you don't care about the load order, you don't need require_all, just leave everything blank and cucumber works its magic.

Ryan Chapman
2018-07-09 08:27:14

Iâ€™ve segregated the page objects from the features, so had to require the into the env

Jonah
2018-07-09 08:29:07

@luke thanks. are you turning off the cucumber autoloading by using -r or some other way?

luke
2018-07-09 08:31:38

Neither. We just require our files.

luke
2018-07-09 08:33:19

obviously that loads them in twice. but it's not really a concern.

Jonah
2018-07-09 10:48:02

i was going to upgrade our cucumber to version 3, and one of my co-workers said that heâ€™d tried before but had problems because aruba didnâ€™t work with cucumber 3 (and we use it heavily in our tests). is this a known issue and is there a solution?

Gem
2018-07-09 11:01:05

Do you know what specifically they thought didn't work?

mvz
2018-07-10 00:49:31

We have one repo with related subprojects, each a cucumber profile. is that not the intended use of profiles? (in any case, that might be an interesting discussion to have, but it would be a side discussion, because pracctically speaking i donâ€™t have the authority to refactor our whole dev process and organization of the repos across teams even if i wanted to. so you can take that structure as a given, for the purposes of this convo. although it is a discussion iâ€™m interested in)

if rotator?
  require_relative './rotators/all'

  require_relative './api/all'

luke
2018-07-11 06:59:39

luke
2018-07-11 06:59:47

luke
2018-07-11 07:00:00

luke
2018-07-11 07:00:17

but you can require files using a recursive structure (such as all.rb) and then you have your problem solved.

luke
2018-07-11 07:00:33

you can't "overrequire" files. So if you require it twice, no harm is done.

2018-07-13 12:09:36

If you want the contents you'd need to do row[0]

      fruit[0] is apple and class is: String
      fruit[0] is banana and class is: String
      fruit[0] is cranberry and class is: String

luke
2018-07-16 00:30:22

ðŸ‘ Gem, Paul_N
luke
2018-07-30 01:04:23

As the post is no longer available (but is pinned â‰ï¸ ) - I'm going to copy and paste (Without formatting here, and re-pin with updated info)

luke
2018-07-30 01:06:59

RubyMine officially has issues with cucumber 3. These are "meant" to be fixed in RubyMine 2018.2 - Which was cut and released last Thursday. If you are using RubyMine, can you upgrade to the latest version (2018.2), and see if using Cucumber3 works sweetly. That includes things like

  • Running a test without a step -> Should offer a generated step -> As of RubyMine < 2018.1, this blew up with a huge stacktrace
  • Inside a feature, ctrl+click (Or ctrl+b), should take you to the step -> As of RubyMine < 2018.1, this suggested the step was undefined
  • (Same as above, but when the feature had a cucumber expression in it)
luke
2018-07-30 01:07:15

Old tracker reference: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/RUBY-20444

YouTrack
RUBY-20444: Step definitions with ParameterType aren't recognized
Check the project attached: * Temp.feature can be run successfully; * the line Given ISO "somekey" has already been boarded is marked with Undefined step reference.
Original URL: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/RUBY-20444
luke
2018-07-30 01:31:07

Aaaand... 15 minutes later I'm an idiot. It's globally broken for running features. But at least the bugs with cucumber3 from before have been solved.

Gem
2018-07-30 10:56:13

Ryan Chapman

luke
2018-08-09 03:12:04

@Paul_N Being brutal, they're trying to re-invent the wheel. That 2nd example is wrong, plain wrong.

luke
2018-08-09 03:12:38

And yes, some people see CR as an attack, at my current company (Albeit it's my penultimate day today), people see CR as a way to improve and love it when people suggest better ways / improvements.

luke
2018-08-09 03:13:10

If what JS says is true, other people above monitoring the CR. Then either make them private, or ask them, do they want CR's. If they don't then ask why. It's a chance to improve.

Jason Koelewyn
2018-08-09 06:33:50

@Paul_N first, both examples are really bad. There should never be code in your step defs! That said example 1 is much better than 2. If they take offense at your comments when they asked for a CR, that is a cultural issue ðŸ˜‰

luke
2018-08-09 06:50:01

â˜ï¸ This is true, but I disagree with the first sentiment. You can have code in your step defs, if it's then calling your support files. As it kinda needs to.

Paul_N
2018-08-09 06:51:41

You have to have a least one line of code in your step def. the assertion! I would humbly suggest that the first example is about as lean as it could possibly be?

Jason Koelewyn
2018-08-09 06:53:44

I humbly disagree. Calls to methods (support files, POs, whatever) are fine. But an assertion should be encapsulated, not in the step

Paul_N
2018-08-09 06:56:37

The method call is wrapped in an assertion which I always thought was best practice for a Then step? I would be interested to know how other people do this though.

Paul_N
2018-08-09 07:03:12

In fact if anybody has examples of encapsulating assertions I would like to see them. I was always under the impression that verifications can reside in PO but not assertions.

Paul_N
2018-08-09 07:03:23

Interesting discussion!

enkessler
2018-08-09 07:11:47

Page Objects are merely tools. They can know true and false but they cannot know right and wrong. Step refs are still part of the test and a test can know right and wrong. Therefore, stick your asserts in the step def or in helper methods that are mixed into the step defs (not mixed into the POs).

Jason Koelewyn
2018-08-09 10:56:48

I still totally disagree. Asserts should be encapsulated in the PO. All the business logic should be in the PO. In part, this is because in general, if a step is doing an assert (this field should have this value) the step is at the wrong abstraction level. Our POs validate blocks of fields based on named datasets. This does a number of things for us. We can have complicated validations covered with high level Gherkin that is much more meaningful to non technical people. We also have abstracted out all of our output so that any time we change how we do reporting, we have a central place to make those updates instead of hunting out all the places in the code where output takes place.

luke
2018-08-10 01:05:37

I disagree with that, and in fact the way cucumber and ruby is designed, the assertions should be in the step definition.

Cucumber auto-mixes in (when required), rspec assertions. So the first one is the best way to do it.

You shouldn't be mixing in rspec assertions into page objects, that's not their responsibility. I know Jason disagrees with me, but the facts kinda speak for themselves.

ðŸ‘ mvz, Aslak HellesÃ¸y, Ayethin
Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-08-11 12:37:19

I agree with @luke. A pattern I have found to work well is for page objects to transform whatâ€™s on a page into a simple data structure (lists, maps, strings, numbers and booleans). Then the stepdefs can make assertions on those objects. Separating page interpretation from assertions makes test code more reusable and maintainable.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2018-08-11 12:41:48

I call these objects â€œtest viewsâ€.

dtran
2018-08-12 08:55:26

@dtran has joined the channel

Ryan Chapman
2018-08-13 03:59:57

Would you then extract common assertions into a helper or just have them all in their individual step definitions?

Paul_N
2018-08-13 05:58:15

@Ryan Chapman I try to use helper methods for common assertions. I would have thought that this is a sensible approach but I am interested to hear what others think.

ðŸ‘ Ryan Chapman
matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:32:26

I like using RSpec for assertions and extracting custom assertions as rspec matchers.

ðŸ‘ Gem
matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:37:29

@luke @Jason Koelewyn Iâ€™ve seen both work. SRP would say to not have page objects actually doing assertions, but equally you can get feature envy if a step def has to ask the PO loads of questions to make its own assertions. Trade offs. Key thing is to try and bury the details away behind an abstraction that describes user intent, not UI implementation.

matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:38:23

Page objects are dead anyway ðŸ™Š

Gem
2018-08-13 13:38:28

Mmm talking about SRP and Feature Envy. Makes me happy

Gem
2018-08-13 13:38:46

What's the successor to page objects?

matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:39:52

Screenplay

matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:40:01

Or something like it anyway

matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:40:45

Little compose-able actions / queries you can run against your app

Jennifer
2018-08-16 00:14:48

When I run cucumber scenario then i want it'll launch chrome browser by default full screen ..?

Ryan Chapman
2018-08-16 00:42:39

@Jennifer you can setup the size it opens up in your env.rb I use capybara, so itâ€™ll be something like

    browser_options = ::Selenium::WebDriver::Chrome::Options.new()
    browser_options.args &lt;&lt; '--window-size=1920,1080'
    Capybara::Selenium::Driver.new(app,
      browser: :chrome,
      options: browser_options
    )
Jennifer
2018-08-16 00:52:17

okay..

2018-08-16 09:46:41

aida

aida

*Thread Reply:* Opened this issue, not sure itâ€™s right https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/465

aidamanna (https://github.com/aidamanna)
#465 cucumber-expressions-ruby: Multiline regexp not allowed in ParameterType class
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>When creating a parameter type, it doesn't allow to define multiline regexp.</p> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p>You can define a multiline regexp with <code>/m</code> when creating a parameter type.</p> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <p>If using <code>/m</code> regex modifier to create a multiline regexp when defining a new parameter type, cucumber complaints with <code>ParameterType Regexps can't use option Regexp::MULTILINE</code></p> <p><strong>Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)</strong></p> <ol><li>Create the following parameter type:</li> </ol> <pre><code>ParameterType( name: 'color', regexp: /(red|blue|pink|green |orange|yellow|)/m, transformer: -&amp;gt;(color) { color } ) </code></pre> <ol start="2"><li>Run test that uses this parameter type</li> </ol> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p>When having a very long line, being able to break it makes code more readable (+ Rubocop doesn't complaint)</p> <h2>Failing test</h2> <p>/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/ruby/spec/cucumber/cucumber<em>expressions/parameter</em>type_spec.rb</p> <pre><code>it 'allows multiline flag on regexp' do expect do ParameterType.new('multiline', /[a-z]+/m, String, lambda {|s| s}, true, false) end.not_to raise_error(CucumberExpressionError end </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
mvz
2018-08-23 05:52:16

*Thread Reply:* I thought you wanted to use /x but the issue mentions /m?

aida
2018-08-22 00:59:09

mvz
2018-08-22 07:08:19

Regexp::MULTILINE corresponds to /m, not /x.

aida
2018-08-22 07:38:52

mvz
2018-08-22 07:53:19

*Thread Reply:* Then it's very odd that Cucumber complains about Regexp::MULTILINE.

brasmusson
2018-08-22 10:13:38

*Thread Reply:* Regex flags are not allowed in parameter types, see https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1531331777000130?thread_ts=1531331154.000287&cid=C60TKS3SL

aslak (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/U59QQHPCY)
<p>Oh yes thatâ€™s right. Regexp flags are not allowed in parameter types because a bigger (case sensistive) regexp is built from the parameter typesâ€™ regexps.</p>
Original URL: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C60TKS3SL/p1531331777000130?thread_ts=1531331154.000287&amp;cid=C60TKS3SL
Thread in Slack Conversation

2018-08-23 00:23:18

mvz
2018-08-23 01:22:18

*Thread Reply:* I think there's room for improving to something more subtle than just blanket disallowing them.

Gem
2018-08-22 08:12:25

I feel like trying to key off a multi-line set of data is a scenario smell and should probably prompt you to rethink how you're trying to write things.

Gem
2018-08-22 08:13:56

What are you trying to accomplish here? If you're just trying to send in multi-line data to a step to be used, you can use heredoc for that.

Gem
2018-08-22 08:14:03

Example: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/features/docs/events/test_case_finished_event.feature

features/docs/events/test_case_finished_event.feature
<pre><code>Feature: Test Case Finished Event This event is fired after each scenario or examples table row (generally named a Test Case) has finished executing. You can use the event to learn about the result of the test case. See [the API documentation](&lt;http://www.rubydoc.info/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/Cucumber/Events/TestCaseFinished&gt;) for more information about the data available on this event. Scenario: Test case passes Given the standard step definitions And a file named "features/passing.feature" with: """ Feature: A feature Scenario: A scenario Given this step passes """ And a file named "features/support/events.rb" with: """ AfterConfiguration do |config| config.on_event :test_case_finished do |event| config.out_stream.puts "Results" config.out_stream.puts "-------" config.out_stream.puts "Test case: #{event.test_case.name}" config.out_stream.puts "The result is: #{event.result}" end end """ When I run `cucumber` Then it should pass with: """ Results ------- Test case: A scenario The result is: âœ“ """ </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
aida
2018-08-23 00:26:16

No is not the case, the thing is that I need to accept as a expression a long list of parameters. In my regexp I could just put (.**) and accept everything but prefer to specify it even if it is long.

aida
2018-08-23 00:27:47
 
Given('a typeform with a {block_type} block') do |block_type|
 # create the typeform
end
aida
2018-08-23 00:30:15
 
ParameterType(
  name:        'block_type',
  regexp:      /(date|dropdown|email|file upload|legal|long text|multiple choice|number|opinion scale|picture choice|rating|short text|statement|website|yes no)/,
  transformer: -&gt;(block_type) { block_type }
)
aida
2018-08-23 00:30:27

this is how it looks

Gem
2018-08-23 10:09:39

@aida Can you give us an example of what a Feature file using this looks like so we're able to understand more around how you're trying to use it?

aida
2018-08-24 00:48:29

yes, we use this step in many features, sometimes with examples, sometimes without. This are some examples:

  Scenario Outline: Commit a valid answer for an implicit commit block
    Given a typeform with many &lt;block type&gt; blocks
    When I select the first option
    Then the first option should be selected
    And the typeform should scroll to the second block

    Examples:
      | block type         |
      | multiple choice |
      | rating                 |

Scenario: Navigate up using the shift+tab keys
    Given a typeform with many short text blocks
    And I scroll to the second block
    When I press shift+tab keys
    Then the typeform should scroll to the first block

  Scenario: Navigate up through the form
    Given a typeform with many dropdown blocks
    And I scroll to the second block
    When I click the navigation up button
    Then the typeform should scroll to the first block

mvz
2018-09-25 00:04:08

@Paul_N if that's the entire content of a step I would definitely not bother moving that code unless it is duplicated in some other step.

Paul_N
2018-09-25 05:53:20

@mvz hi Matijs, it is not quite the step as I have to flag failures and then do the assertion after the loop but it does rankle me the fact that I have to have code littering a step def like this. I just donâ€™t like putting code up for a PR that I am not entirely happy with

mvz
2018-09-25 06:02:51

@Paul_N I guess I just don't see the point of abstracting code out of the step def if it's only used in that particular one. If it's not vastly more code than you would have in, say, an RSpec spec or in a regular method, forcing the extra indirection is just make-work.

ðŸ‘ Paul_N
mvz
2018-09-25 06:03:48

TL;DR: I'm not sure that 'best practice' is actually a good practice ðŸ¤·

Andy
2018-09-26 09:20:17

@Andy has joined the channel

Andy
2018-09-26 09:20:21

Hello everyone. I'm using Cucumber with Ruby and while we were upgrading from 3.0.X to 3.1.X, I noticed the html.rb formatter has been removed. My team had a custom implementation of it and I'm looking into the proper way to upgrade it. Is the "Custom Formatters" wiki page up to date, or is there another guide? Thanks!

brasmusson
2018-09-26 09:24:14

No, in v3.1.2 which is the latest v3.1.X release the html.rb still exist.

brasmusson
2018-09-26 09:32:29

Which "'Custom Formatters' wiki page"? If it is up to date it describes the Event API described in the announcement of v3.0.0: https://cucumber.io/blog/2017/09/27/announcing-cucumber-ruby-3-0-0

cucumber.io
Announcing Cucumber-Ruby v3.0.0Â·Cucumber
Cucumber. Simple, Human Collaboration
Original URL: https://cucumber.io/blog/2017/09/27/announcing-cucumber-ruby-3-0-0
ðŸ‘ Andy
Andy
2018-09-26 10:45:38

Thanks, I was looking at: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki/Custom-Formatters

lib/cucumber/formatter/html.rb
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Andy
2018-09-26 11:00:44

In the past, we had a class that inherited from Cucumber::Formatter::Html, what would I inherit from now that uses the new API?

brasmusson
2018-09-27 03:52:17

As you can see, the whole wiki has been deprecated https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki

Andy
2018-09-27 06:22:11

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for that note! I came upon the Custom Formatters page directly from Google and unfortunately never saw a "page moved" notice. Thanks for the heads up! Maybe all of the pages in that wiki that still have content should have that warning at the top?

brasmusson
2018-09-27 03:59:57

You should not inherit at all. Define and initialize that accepts config and use config.on_event to register for the event your formatter needs.

Andy
2018-09-27 06:23:18

Okay, I suppose we could go that route. We really like the HTML format, but simply need to add some extra information to it. If I take the approach above, wouldn't we need to re-implement the HTML formatter? (Thanks again for your assistance on this!)

emcoding
2018-09-28 03:14:03

@emcoding has joined the channel

brasmusson
2018-09-28 11:44:23

@Andy I make a set of comments here with the intention of making things as clear as I can. â€¢ In Cucumber-Ruby v3.1.X the html formatter still exists. However it is highly unlikely that the will be another release in v3.1.X (v3.1.2 is the current release). â€¢ The master branch is targeting v4.0.0, which is stated in the CHANGELOG.md. The general practice in Cucumber-Ruby is to update the version data in the repo on release, therefore if using the cucumber gem from github it might look like the master branch is targeting v3.1.X, but it isn't. â€¢ The html formatter is removed in v4.0.0 because it was still using the legacy api, which was deprecated when v2.0.0 was released in mars 2015 (so it was in a desperate need of a rewrite to the new API). The legacy api was blocking important work like change to use the gherkin library compiler and pickles, and also the upgrade to gherkin v6, therefore it and the html formatter are removed in v4.0.0. â€¢ The intention is that the html formatter will come base as a standalone formatter. Standalone formatters is the current strategy of the Cucumber OSS project to achieve formatters usable for all Cucumber implementations, see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/dots-formatter. It is most likely that v4.0.0 is released before anyone has implemented a standalone html formatter. â€¢ To get your custom html formatter working in v4.0.0 you basically have to implement it from scratch.

Andy
2018-09-28 12:11:42

@brasmusson Thank you so much for your very detailed response. It helped a lot!

mlvandijk
2018-09-29 21:56:27

@mlvandijk has joined the channel

mvz
2018-09-30 02:34:07

What are the plans for JRuby support for Cucumber 4?

brasmusson
2018-09-30 03:44:03

From what I have seen on the CI-systems, there is a problem with installing google-protobuf on JRuby, so it looks like when google-protobuf can be install in JRuby, Cucumber-Ruby v4 will be available on JRuby also.

mvz
2018-09-30 05:12:43

I think that may be a long wait since this has been a problem since 2016: https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/1594.

blowmage (https://github.com/blowmage)
#1594 Unable to install google-protobuf gem on JRuby
<p>The glcoud-ruby project has an issue opened by a user (<a href="https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-ruby/issues/712">googleapis/google-cloud-ruby#712</a>) that is unable to install the latest version due to the dependencies on the grpc and google-protobuf gems not installing on jruby. I am not able to get the google-protobuf gem to install using versions 9.1.1.0 or 9.0.0.0.</p> <p>Here is the install on mac:</p> <pre><code>$ ruby -v jruby 9.1.1.0 (2.3.0) 2016-05-19 fe84e89 Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 25.91-b14 on 1.8.0_91-b14 +jit [darwin-x86_64] $ gem install --ignore-dependencies google-protobuf -v 3.0.0.alpha.5.0.5.1 Building native extensions. This could take a while... ERROR: Error installing google-protobuf: ERROR: Failed to build gem native extension. current directory: /Users/blowmage/.gem/repos/jruby-9.1.1.0-grpc/gems/google-protobuf-3.0.0.alpha.5.0.5.1/ext/google/protobuf_c /Users/blowmage/.rubies/jruby-9.1.1.0/bin/jruby -r ./siteconf20160524-43044-1fuqmwb.rb extconf.rb NotImplementedError: C extensions are not supported &amp;lt;top&amp;gt; at /Users/blowmage/.rubies/jruby-9.1.1.0/lib/ruby/stdlib/mkmf.rb:1 require at org/jruby/RubyKernel.java:944 (root) at /Users/blowmage/.rubies/jruby-9.1.1.0/lib/ruby/stdlib/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:1 &amp;lt;top&amp;gt; at extconf.rb:3 extconf failed, exit code 1 Gem files will remain installed in /Users/blowmage/.gem/repos/jruby-9.1.1.0-grpc/gems/google-protobuf-3.0.0.alpha.5.0.5.1 for inspection. Results logged to /Users/blowmage/.gem/repos/jruby-9.1.1.0-grpc/extensions/universal-java-1.8/2.3.0/google-protobuf-3.0.0.alpha.5.0.5.1/gem_make.out </code></pre> <p>Here is the install on linux:</p> <pre><code>$ ./bin/jruby -v jruby 9.1.1.0 (2.3.0) 2016-05-19 fe84e89 OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 24.95-b01 on 1.7.0_95-b00 +jit [linux-x86_64] $ ./bin/jruby -S gem install --ignore-dependencies google-protobuf -v 3.0.0.alpha.5.0.5.1 Building native extensions. This could take a while... 2018-10-01 05:20:24

@matt-SmartBear The blocker for JRuby is that Gherkin 6 is using protobuf, not that the standalone formatters are using it.

Bruce
2018-10-11 02:15:50

hi folks, this may not be a cucumber thing, but I need to test the visibility of a button in responsive web pages...

Bruce
2018-10-11 02:16:08

I've got a group of browser sizes and I need to know what is actually visible on the page

Anuj
2018-11-07 17:11:45

*Thread Reply:* SitePrism provides a method elements_present which returns all the elements visible. This is based on the fact that you already have those elements defined in a page class or a section class.

Bruce
2018-10-11 02:16:26

I'm using Watir for this, and I was hoping element.visible? would do the trick

Bruce
2018-10-11 02:16:32

but it seems not.

Bruce
2018-10-11 02:16:57

I'm sure this stuff is done a lot of the time, so can someone give me pointers as to what general approach to take?

Arnab
2018-10-17 06:39:16

Can't you just try clicking the elements (or interacting in some way)? Capybara ~seems to throw~ throws an error when the element I'm trying to interact with is not visible...Maybe Watir has something similar?

Bruce
2018-10-17 23:50:52

Actually, I solved this with help from the community, by running a piece of javascript which calculated where the element was on the page and whether it fit in the viewport.

Bruce
2018-10-17 23:53:19

Charan
2018-11-07 17:32:08

after this one https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1310

brasmusson (https://github.com/brasmusson)
#1310 Let the Rerun Formatter handle flaky scenarios
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Let the Rerun Formatter handle flaky scenarios.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>Let the Rerun Formatter detect the retry of scenarios, and only with the <code>--strict-flaky</code> options, include the flaky scenarios in the output.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>The Rerun Formatter output should be empty if the exit code is zero. Without the <code>--strict-flaky</code> option flaky scenarios do not make the exit code non-zero.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>The automated test suite has been updated to verify this behavior.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>â˜ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) â˜‘ï¸Ž Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) â˜ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) â˜ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>â˜‘ï¸Ž I've added tests for my code â˜ My change requires a change to the documentation. â˜ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>

luke
2018-11-20 12:39:25

The thing with CLI's and having automated tests is you'll find they slow you down. Better just to use a bunch of ENV vars.

We used to use things like gets.chomp and you'd type 1 for smoke tests, 2 for Luke's Admin test e.t.c. But yeh required the human interaction.

phebus
2018-11-20 12:45:28

yeah it's less about running the automation from a REPL interface and more about using it to drive a browser to do repetitive tasks on demand and keeping state

luke
2018-11-20 12:59:14

If you're using Ruby, the Jenkins API gem allows you to craft your own sub-project. That could just consist of 12 buttons for 12 different build triggers that all do different repetitive tasks.

So your program could be press 1 to queue up X, press 2 to queue up Y

2018-11-28 10:33:13

Jason Koelewyn
2018-11-28 10:38:02

*Thread Reply:* Are there any details on that I could pass on to the parallel_test team?

enkessler
2018-11-28 11:55:23

*Thread Reply:* It looks like they are using the gherkin gem directly in â€˜parallel_tests/cucumber/scenarios.rbâ€™. A change to the AST generated by gherkin could break them. Which is to say: they would have to update for every major version of gherkin (and 6.0 just came out).

â€˜cuke_modelerâ€™ would remove that problem because it sits between the gherkin gem and you and handles the AST changes itself.

Jason Koelewyn
2018-11-28 11:59:33

*Thread Reply:* will let them know, thx

Anuj
2018-12-10 19:18:30

We have a lot cucumber tests that are tagged depending on the feature in the application. Weâ€™ve put in a logic to skip the test if that feature is not available or turned on in the application. However, skipping such tests take a lot of time i.e. around 10 seconds. Is there any way that we could make this faster i.e. skipping tests faster ?

mlvandijk
2018-12-10 22:03:24

@Anuj do you mean your tests are determining whether or not to run themselves? If you know which features you want to run or not you can use tags / tag expressions for this

Anuj
2018-12-11 11:59:26

@mlvandijk we have a before hook which determines whether the scenario should be skipped or not based on the tag. this happens at run time therefore Iâ€™m assuming it takes a bit of time to determine whether it needs to be skipped or not.

Jason Koelewyn
2018-12-11 12:26:19

How are you executing your tests? this is all built in stuff if you are using rake, cucumber or any of the parallel gemsâ€¦..

Anuj
2018-12-11 12:28:21

We use a gem to run our tests in parallel

mlvandijk
2018-12-12 01:26:01

@Anuj why not just use tags to specify which features to run? Alternatively, is it possible to run the logic though a debugger to find out what's taking so long?

gijs.p
2018-12-12 02:00:53

An example for @mlvandijkâ€™s comment: In my projects, we define profiles in cucumber.yml like follows:

staging: TEST_ENV=staging  -t ~@disabled_on_staging -t @staging,@all_env -x
production: TEST_ENV=production -t ~@disabled_on_production -t @production,@all_env -x

So we can filter features, scenario's or outlines by using tags @all_env to always run, @disabled_on_staging to exclude a single scenario or @staging if it is only relevant for that environment. This way you don't need custom code in the after-hook.

enkessler
2018-12-12 04:05:02

@Anuj you can force a test to skip itself and move on based on a tag, yes. Iâ€™ve made hooks for that purpose before but, if each of your skipped tests are eating up 10 seconds even when being skipped, then youâ€™ve likely got other time consuming hooks or steps that are still occurring before you finally get to your test skipping logic. Try to skip the test right away instead of doing other stuff first.

ðŸ‘ Gem
Anuj
2018-12-12 12:14:37

*Thread Reply:* Thank you ! We do have a number of hooks but yes youâ€™re right, I should try and know before hand which test to run instead of finding out at run time. One of the other potential problems is that we have a large number of step def files as well

enkessler
2018-12-12 16:32:44

*Thread Reply:* A large number of step def files is not inherently a problem and, in any case, would be a factor of how quickly or slowly skipped tests run because Cucumber will load the same step files whether you run just 1 test or run 1000 tests.

Anuj
2018-12-12 16:37:57

*Thread Reply:* Good point. Iâ€™m going to try and find how much total time it takes to skip the scenarios in our suite.

Jason Koelewyn
2018-12-12 06:38:16

the methodology @gijs.p shows does not take any time for skipped scenarios. this can also be specified at runtime too

luke
2019-01-10 05:36:56

mini thought dump @enkessler or other rubyists here?

How hard would it be to do the following.

  • Write say 5 common steps into a gem?
  • Require the gem
  • Have those steps loaded at runtime.

I'm confident the first step is easy enough, but then the requiring / loading I think sounds a bit funky.

It's not something I need to do yet. Was just curious as to if it's a good thought experiment.

luke
2019-01-10 05:38:50

the use case (Not sure if realistic).

I have 8 small apps which are all by and large similar in terms of coding requirements to test.

Instead of coding one big repo, code 8 small repos inside each app, so the devs can trigger the stuff off as and when. But then instead of me having to write the same steps 8 times, write the steps once in a gem package and then pull them in??

2019-01-10 07:33:46

enkessler
2019-01-11 08:02:48

@luke Regarding loading step definitions at runtime, they are just plain old Ruby code. You can require it from a file, package it into a gem for portability and then load it from that gem as you would any other gem functionality, or just about anything else. The only difficult part about the gem solution is knowing how to write a gem in the first place. ðŸ™‚

ðŸ‘ Gem
luke
2019-01-11 08:03:17

ah oki, fair does. I manage site_prism so I'm reasonably comfortable on that front.

Gem
2019-01-11 08:14:05

@luke The Cucumber School stuff has a good example of loading different steps into the world based on a flag but that use the same step defs

enkessler
2019-01-11 08:51:35

I used site_prism on a project once. It was handy.

ðŸ‘ Steve G
Anuj
2019-01-14 14:21:42

Just looking at the cucumber-ruby github repo at https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/ and the description contains Cucumber is a tool for running automated tests written in plain language. Because they're written in plain language, they can be read by anyone on your team.

Is this technically true though ? My understanding is that Cucumber is a collaboration tool which can also be used for running automated tests written in the gherkin syntax (and not just any plain language). This is probably just nit picking but IMO the semantics here makes a lot of difference in the interpretation.

I might have got the wrong end of the stick here so please correct me if Iâ€™m wrong.

enkessler
2019-01-14 14:24:25

Gherkin is the collaboration portion. Your team could just write features file in order to facilitate understanding. If they want to 'execute' those files, however, then they need Cucumber.

Gem
2019-01-14 14:25:34

Cucumber is still considered a collab tool. That particular line in the readme is 6 years old. ðŸ˜›

luke
2019-01-23 00:13:07

enkessler
2019-01-24 07:58:53

@Charan the cuke_slicer gem could get you the file and line number of every test in your suite and then you could parallel-ize at a very granular level. If you just want the file and line number for each Feature:, then the cuke_modeler or cql gems should be useful in whipping up a quick script that could spit out that list for you.

Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-05 08:59:50

Hello â€“ looking for a bit of help with screenshots after failed steps.

Cucumber 3.1.0 Ruby 2.5.1

If I have the following code: After do |scenario| if scenario.failed? name_of_scenario = Time.now.strftime('%H_%M_%S_%L') file_path = "./screenshots/#{name_of_scenario}.png" $driver.save_viewport_screenshot(file_path) embed(file_path, 'image/png') end end The screenshot is successfully taken and itâ€™s embedded into the After hook section of the JSON report. In the Cucumber Jenkins report, this looks like this:

Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-05 09:00:18
Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-05 09:00:23

I would like instead for the image to be embedded in the report in the Steps section so that anyone who is looking at the report does not need to know that they need to click to expand the After hook section to see the image. So I tried the following code:

AfterConfiguration do |config| config.on_event :test_step_finished do |event| if event.result.failed? name_of_scenario = Time.now.strftime('%H_%M_%S_%L') file_path = "./screenshots/#{name_of_scenario}.png" $driver.save_viewport_screenshot(file_path) embed(file_path, 'image/png') end end end This wonâ€™t create a Cucumber report when ran Jenkins as it states that a valid JSON couldnâ€™t be found, but when running locally with the -f json -o ./report.json -f pretty args, it results in two screenshots being taken and saved (approximately one second apart) to the file_path and the following error in the console output: undefined method `embed' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError) /Users/{...full_path_to...}/android/support/hooks.rb:112:in `block (2 levels) in &lt;top (required)&gt;'

When I comment out the embed(file_path, 'image/png') line, I see that only one screenshot results so Iâ€™m assuming that if I can solve the exception that embed is throwing, the duplicate screenshot problem will solve itself.

Why is it that embed works when itâ€™s in the After hook but throws the NoMethodError when itâ€™s in an AfterConfiguration block? And how can I fix this so that the screenshot is embedded in the Steps section rather than the After hook section? Thanks in advance for your help.

2019-02-05 09:13:48

Iâ€™m seeing that the screenshot of the screen where the failure exists is being taken and saved to the specified file path so Iâ€™m sure that it is running after the failed step, itâ€™s just that itâ€™s not able to embed it into the JSON report after itâ€™s been taken.
