Yeah youâ€™re rightâ€¦ html does put it in the right spot. Probably in part bc html doesnâ€™t show Hooks sections in the report.

Thanks for weighing in and confirming what Iâ€™m seeing (you as well @Jason Koelewyn)! Much appreciated.

If anyone is more familiar with AfterConfiguration and could at least explain why embed throws the undefined methodembedâ€™ for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError)` error so we can all at least sleep at night, that would be great!

phebus
2019-02-05 09:51:31

yeah iâ€™m interested in that too, not having used it before

brasmusson
2019-02-05 10:31:20

@Andrew Bardallis Can you try this with Cucumber v4.0.0.rc.1, where the LegacyApi module finally is removed. The most likely suspect of these kind of reporting problems (like embed throwing an undefined method exception) is always the LegacyApi module which is far to complex for its own good.

Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-05 10:48:59

@brasmusson I see the same issue with Cucumber v4.0.0.rc.1

Console output:

Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-05 10:49:08
Untitled
Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-05 10:50:32

And when I step into the embed method in RubyMine, I no longer see any references to Legacy_Api

brasmusson
2019-02-05 13:17:15

@Andrew Bardallis I read the channel a bit to fast previously, now I have a better answer. It comes down to the cucumber architecture.

  Listeners   &lt;- events --  Cucumber  -- hooks and step definitions -&gt; SUT

It is in the "hooks and step definitions" side it is possible to call embed to pass data to be included in reports. The event steam from Cucumber is intended for listeners (like formatters for instance) to get information of what happened during the Cucumber test run. The event side of Cucumber is not intended to take part in the test case execution (interacting with the SUT etc), therefore it is not possible to call embed (in fact in Cucumber-JVM performing embed in a hook will fire an embed event with the embedded data which for instance the JSON formatter registers itself for).

Another problem with trying to do things like taking screenshots in response to events, is that events conceptually are asynchronous (this is a strong personal belief of mine). Listeners for events will be notified after an event has been fired, but there is no guarantee that the firer of the event has not moved on when the listeners receives the notification. Since Cucumber-Ruby is (currently) single threaded, maybe taking screenshots from event listeners will work fairly acceptable (in terms of delay etc). But should Cucumber-Ruby in the future support parallel execution natively that might change. The latest release of Cucumber-JVM does support parallel execution natively, so the events from different scenarios can be received interleaved by the event listeners (like formatters), to not break existing third party listeners there is a (default) backward compatible mode, where the listener receives the events nicely serialized, but then all events are received afters the whole test run has finished. That does not affect any report produced from the event stream, but it does invalidate any assumption about that the delay between event firing and listener event reception.

ðŸ‘ Gem, Andrew Bardallis
luke
2019-02-06 00:49:00

The thing is (Looking at your comments yesterday), is I think images in the report look clunky, so I have them as jenkins artefacts.

luke
2019-02-06 00:50:32

Obviously you seem to have all sussed out what to do. So that's fine.

Andrew Bardallis
2019-02-06 07:36:59

@brasmusson Thank you very much for such a detailed description and the education. Very helpful and I definitely learned something!

Anuj

enkessler
2019-02-18 12:04:15

Iâ€™m not Matt but the answer is â€˜yesâ€™.

matt-SmartBear
2019-02-18 14:29:34

How @enkessler - I wouldnâ€™t know how to do that!

Dana Scheider (they/he)
2019-02-18 20:39:13

I would use the parallel_tests gem but wouldn't know how to do it otherwise

enkessler
2019-02-19 06:23:40

I too use the parallel_tests gem for running Cucumber/RSpec in parallel. Currently (because https://github.com/grosser/parallel_tests/issues/511 is not yet resolved), the only extra burden of running failures in parallel is that you have to take the file created by the rerun formatter (e.g. '@rerun.txt') and break it up into individual lines that you then append the to the end of the command line. So, you end up with something like this

bundle exec parallel_cucumber --test-options '-t @foo' -- failing.feature another_failing.feature:33:120 etc.feature

si-mikey (https://github.com/si-mikey)
#511 Rerunning failed cucumber scenarios in parallel
<p>It seems that there is not obvious way to get this accomplished. Is there something built into parallel_tests to run scenarios in parallel?</p>
Comments
28
<a href="https://github.com/grosser/parallel_tests">grosser/parallel_tests</a>
luke
2019-02-19 06:31:52

question.

Usually the number of failures is a fraction of a % of the original run.

Why not just for the re-run run the entire file in 1 thread. Because that would save a lot of hassle?

enkessler
2019-02-19 06:33:34

A % of large number can still be a large number. I may only have to rerun 30 tests out of 3000 but I'd still rather run them 5 at a time rather than one by one.

luke
2019-02-19 06:33:42

so bundle exec parallel_cucumber with the format --rerun Then on your next line

unless File.size('rerun.txt').zero?
  bundle exec cucumber @rerun.txt
end
luke
2019-02-19 06:33:47

ok, fair point.

luke
2019-02-20 04:40:25

Aha, I think I've got it. You don't "run" your steps. You run the feature file.

You're trying to run ruby code that has no understanding of what a World is. So you need to run the feature file which then instantiates that concept for the Ruby Thread to process.

LalithaR
2019-02-20 04:41:36

That's what I figured out :) I was running the steps instead of Feature file.

Thank you for directing me to include the right steps

luke
2019-02-20 04:50:45

no worries. Have your terminal setup to be in the tld - that is the one that contains features/

luke

luke

luke
2019-02-21 02:34:46

mlvandijk
2019-02-21 03:01:51

Ok, yeah sometimes people miss steps in tutorials.

luke
2019-02-21 03:07:09

it's perhaps "more" prevalent in ruby. Because you can literally do a run of a script in ruby, whereas you can't in Java / Kotlin.

So the following code can literally be "ran"

luke = "Hello I'm Luke"
puts luke
luke
2019-02-21 03:07:20

you'd just right click and run or type ruby myscript.rb

mlvandijk
2019-02-21 08:13:57

You need a main method in Java/Kotlin to do that ;)

luke
2019-03-05 01:17:29

at some point today matt could you or one of the other core members take a look at: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/561

luke-hill (https://github.com/luke-hill)
#561 Fix ruby issue 1337: Brackets/Integer/CukeExp compatibility
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>When using Integers captured using the {int} cucumber expression, issues crop up when trying to sanitize the brackets which are being read as an optional parameter.</p> <p>The issue is occurring due to interoperability between brackets being partially escapable (To represent these are brackets and not a capture group), and cucumber expressions (Which have a different meaning for brackets)</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>I've allowed brackets to be used in a very specific context (As notified by the constant definition), when being used inside a Cucumber Expression Generator method (Which would previously crash erroneously)</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>Fixes Ruby issue #1337 <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1337">cucumber/cucumber-ruby#1337</a></p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>This code is likely to need porting and is only meant as a first draft. It's probably going to need some stern eyes to work out if this is desired.</p>
Comments
4

@aslakhellesoy
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>

2019-03-05 10:49:42

Izaac Zavaleta

SMHA
2019-03-05 12:01:07

@SMHA has joined the channel

luke
2019-03-06 01:17:49

@CoryC there is a much easier way to do what you want

luke
2019-03-06 01:18:06

All you need is an AfterStep hook with a couple of lines in it.

luke
2019-03-06 01:18:28

forgetting the debate about Time.now e.t.c. simply do this.

luke
2019-03-06 01:21:43
 
AfterStep('@timer') do
  @end_of_current_step = Time.now
  @step_runtime = @end_of_previous_step - @end_of_current_step
  @end_of_previous_step = @end_of_current_step
end

Note that you can tidy this up even more, but it gives you the basics. This also will need @endofprevious_step initializing on suite execution

luke
2019-03-06 01:22:57

You've got something similar in your example I see, but there's lots of excess garbage you don't need.

CoryC
2019-03-06 04:14:24

Thanks @luke!

luke
2019-03-06 04:15:19

One thing you might want to do is store the value directly whilst in the AfterStep as once you leave that, you're possibly out of the World construct. So check where you are at each moment to ensure you've got access to the instancevars

CoryC
2019-03-06 04:17:19

Iâ€™ll try that out. Thanks a bunch!

luke
2019-03-06 04:18:27

no worries, it is a bit of a weird thing. And it's something I think going forwards it would be handy to maybe code as a self-contained gem extension.

:partyparrot: CoryC

Godwin
2019-03-14 10:23:37

Hello Team - Good morning. Currently, im using cucumber (ruby script) and passing my test data in Examples. But, test data is getting bigger now. So im planning to get test data from excel. Any suggestion on how to do that?

phebus
2019-03-14 10:25:07

personally i would look for a way to split up the tests based on functionality/data requirements and avoid going the excel route

phebus
2019-03-14 10:25:25

but there are several gems that can help with reading/writing excel files

phebus
2019-03-14 10:25:51

if you must use an external file for data i would suggest keeping it simple as a csv rather than excel

Godwin
2019-03-14 10:27:11

thanks @phebus for your quick reply.

Godwin
2019-03-14 10:27:39

can i get data from csv in feature file?

phebus
2019-03-14 10:27:48

you could get it in the step

Godwin
2019-03-14 10:28:27

got it. thank you @phebus

Godwin
2019-03-14 10:41:00

Another question - When i pass 25 "" parameters in 1 when statement in feature file, rubymine hangs. thoughts?

Jason Koelewyn
2019-03-14 12:25:08

@Godwin passing raw data in your steps is not ideal. Consider using named datasets and store your data in a file like Yaml

Godwin
2019-03-14 12:31:32

good idea. thanks @Jason Koelewyn

phebus
2019-03-14 12:32:30

oh yeah if itâ€™s not data directly related to the test at hand config files are the way to go

Jason Koelewyn
2019-03-14 12:37:16

@phebus even for test data, Storing the raw values in a secondary file like Yaml allows you to 1) abstract your steps to a higher, more maintainable level and 2) data drive your tests

ðŸ‘ Godwin
luke
2019-03-15 01:26:53

just for reference (I'm late to the party), but Ruby's CSV parser is incredibly fast and built in. So feel free to use that (or yaml)

ðŸ’¯ Dana Scheider (they/he)
ðŸ‘ Godwin
Jason Koelewyn
2019-03-15 07:31:01

*Thread Reply:* The CSV parser is great, I find that the structure of Yaml is far superior for test data. Personal preference, but having used both Iâ€™d take Yaml â€˜almostâ€™ every time ðŸ˜‰

luke
2019-03-15 08:16:54

*Thread Reply:* agreed. I think I used CSV once because we were given the data in csv file once. It was huge and we iterated over it.

Godwin
2019-03-18 16:41:51

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @luke

2019-03-29 14:28:46

2019-03-29 14:34:14

enkessler
2019-03-29 14:35:41

Youâ€™ll have to type in a value in the step instead of having it plugged in from an outline table but itâ€™s all the same.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:39:37

@Hugh McCamphill has joined the channel

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:39:55

hi, using cucumber with ruby. Got redirected here from twitter - thanks! Got a question on state between scenarios. Is it ever possible for state to leak between scenarios? eg if using instance variables? response got so far: "Instance variables in your steps shouldn't leak between scenarios, however, you can certainly have global state that leaks. The exact answer may depend on which Cucumber you are using. "

where would global state come in? sorry if this is a silly question

tooky
2019-04-18 04:41:53

Hey @Hugh McCamphill

tooky
2019-04-18 04:42:05

Can you provide an example of what youâ€™re seeing?

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:44:18

Hi! not seeing anything- basically just trying to understand any constraints. I think using instance variables (in the right situation) would be good for sharing some state in certain scenarios. The developers who set up the initial implementation are against using them as they think state will leak. I've asked if they have any examples of this happening but haven't heard back yet

luke
2019-04-18 04:48:09

dependent on what your issue is depends on whether we answer yes or no. Essentially the World construct will share state, but that only exists in the step definition portion of your tests.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:49:55

well I think that the suggestion from the devs is that there would be issues between scenarios.

luke
2019-04-18 04:52:12

Right, but what do you mean "issues"

luke
2019-04-18 04:52:21

if you run say 4 scenarios, then inside the 1 thread the 4 scenarios run.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:54:19

ok so it would be a question of developer error, ie if they didn't understand how a variable had been left

luke
2019-04-18 04:55:29

I'm still not 100% what you're asking.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:56:37

let me see what the devs come back with

luke
2019-04-18 04:56:55

if you explain the concern we can tell you the answer, or have a go. But so far I don't understand what the issue is?

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:57:48
Untitled
luke
2019-04-18 04:58:01

no they're not.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:58:23

thats the comment I got yesterday

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:58:32

in text above

luke
2019-04-18 04:58:39

Right so they're concerned about the state being passed from scenario.

The World will not share state between scenarios, it will share state between steps.

luke
2019-04-18 04:58:52

Because a single scenario could be though of as say a single rspec test.

luke
2019-04-18 04:59:18

If you want proof of this, examine the object_id of the World between 2 scenarios. It will be different.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:59:36

awesome thank you!

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 04:59:50

sorry for my garbled questions

luke
2019-04-18 04:59:51

Think of everything inside a scenario being ran on a single class instance.

luke
2019-04-18 05:00:50
 
Given I do something do
  @myvar = 'almonds'
end

When I want to see it do
  puts @myvar
end
luke
2019-04-18 05:01:03

if those are ran in the same scenario, they'll output the value, but in different scenarios they wont.

luke
2019-04-18 05:01:35
 
Scenario: One
  Given I do something
  When I want to see it # this outputs 'almonds'

Scenario: Two
  When I want to see it # this outputs '' or `nil`
Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 05:02:41

ðŸ‘

luke
2019-04-18 05:03:15

Does that answer your question? I hope it does.

luke
2019-04-18 05:03:44

Now for example (Just to confuse things). I actually want some state to share between scenarios. To do this you can use a global variable, but I use a better construct (Class Instance Variables or Singletons)

luke
2019-04-18 05:04:01

I.e. I have an expensive operation to create a user, and for 80% of my scenarios, I can re-use the same user.

luke
2019-04-18 05:04:48

and because all of cucumber runs in a single thread, the ruby engine caches this value and accordingly won't re-run the methods unless I tell it to.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 05:14:05

it does yes.

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 08:00:18

But that ONLY works if you run single threaded. If your execution model is parallel streams, that WONT work. Worse, it will work randomly for scenarios that end up in the same stream. It is better to avoid this all together. A scenario should really be a self contained unit.

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 08:07:38

we're running single threaded (they get distributed on AWS Lambda)

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 08:10:43

*Thread Reply:* How long does your suite take to execute?

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 08:14:03

*Thread Reply:* 9/10 minutes

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 08:14:56

*Thread Reply:* How many tests do you have?

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 08:15:04

*Thread Reply:* 450 or so

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 08:15:32

*Thread Reply:* and they are not running parallel?

Hugh McCamphill
2019-04-18 08:16:03

*Thread Reply:* well they are, but single threaded on each worker

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 08:16:52

*Thread Reply:* Ah, ok, you just have one execution nodeâ€¦

luke
2019-04-18 09:23:17

@Jason Koelewyn not sure if that was directed at me or not. But if I parallelize it, it would still work? It would just take a little bit longer if the thread didn't encounter the cache. Likewise if it wasn't parallelized and encountered the cache it would work.

The scenarios are all self-contained, but many of them don't "require" a fresh user every time. If they get a fresh user, it works, if they don't get a fresh user, it still works. All it cares about is there is a user - Hence the usage of Singletons

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 09:24:53

So it depends on â€˜how parallelâ€™ you run. in theory if you have a single control node, yeah it â€˜shouldâ€™ still work. You may hit sequence issues though.

Jason Koelewyn
2019-04-18 09:25:29

But if you expand and have multiple nodes, it will fail

ðŸ‘Ž luke
luke
2019-04-25 07:34:52

has anyone here got experience with appraisals? Every time I try run tests locally for one specific gemfile it complains somethings not bundled correctly and it's doing my nut in

I canâ€™t seem to figure out why this error is popping up: undefined method `render_template' for #&lt;Cucumber::Rails::World:0x007fbc9e592c40&gt; (NoMethodError) ./features/step_definitions/common.rb:64:in `/^I should be on "(.+)"$/' features/plain/account_suspension.feature:30:in `Then I should be on "account/login"'

Paul_N
2019-04-29 03:05:43

For those who use cloud testing. Is it necessary to quit browser after every scenario? I am getting multiple timeouts from BrowserStack that is largely eliminated when I quit after every scenario rather than at exit. Curiously SauceLabs appears happy with just quitting at exit

luke
2019-04-30 02:39:16

It is always advisable to quit after each test, so you don't get any latent cookies or anything affecting other tests. The time does increase obviously, but it keeps your tests wholly independent

ðŸ‘ Paul_N
Paul_N
2019-04-30 05:25:06

And you instantiate browser explicitly in the before do |scenario| block or just have a @browser = browser command in there and define browser once further up the env.rb - I am trying to work out what is best practice I have seen it done so many ways.

luke
2019-04-30 06:49:58

So for me it's slightly different. I've used site_prism shameless plug I know. And in there you actually directly set the ability to hit a specific url on certain pages.

luke
2019-04-30 06:50:43

So there is never a concept of a browser variable. Only a page object variable. You never directly talk to the browser. We use a Capybara::Selenium::Driver object which is set to a default then auto-loaded when you make your first get url call.

phebus
2019-04-30 06:50:46

i instantiate @browser in the before and quit in the after

phebus
2019-04-30 06:51:26

i also have a flag for keeping it persistent through tests that bypasses that

luke
2019-04-30 06:53:11

For setting the browsers capabilities, I do that in env.rb as that is always ran first and is the one area that you can be certain of (And specifying a browser can be a tricky business)

Paul_N
2019-04-30 07:00:30

Instantiating before each scenario and quitting in after do doubled the run time. Ouch!

phebus
2019-04-30 07:01:05

yeah thatâ€™s the danger. startup/teardown is costly timewise

phebus
2019-04-30 07:01:19

which is why parallelization is important

Paul_N
2019-04-30 07:01:27

@phebus do you run parallel tests?

phebus
2019-04-30 07:01:35

yeah

phebus
2019-04-30 07:02:33

the parallel_tests gem will give you parallel_cucumber which will allow you to run multiple feature files concurrently

Paul_N
2019-04-30 07:03:20

Yeah we use that. I thought that this is why the before scenario instantiate and after scenario quit was so important?

phebus
2019-04-30 07:04:41

possibly, but mainly itâ€™s because your test scenarios should be a fresh environment every time to avoid issues like leftover cookies/session info

Paul_N
2019-04-30 07:04:53

Doing it that way appears to be the only way cloud testing works for me.

Paul_N
2019-04-30 07:05:09

Otherwise I get timeouts

phebus
2019-04-30 07:05:12

yeah, the latency is rough, and you really do need it

Paul_N
2019-04-30 07:07:17

I keep hearing about sub 10 second end-end testing at conferences but it takes more than that to instantiate the bloody browser!

ðŸ˜† Paul_N
phebus
2019-04-30 07:19:15

true dat

Paul_N
2019-04-30 23:40:30

I thought that parallel_tests run features in parallel. Can it do scenarios as well?

phebus
2019-05-01 05:40:54

not that i know of

phebus
2019-05-01 05:40:57

i wish it could

phebus
2019-05-01 05:41:47

but what it at least does is train you to make your feature files not a crazy size, and think about how you organize things, because your longest feature file will hold up an entire process

enkessler
2019-05-01 05:49:10

@PaulN paralleltests can run by scenario, yes. Use the â€˜group-byâ€™ option.

enkessler
2019-05-01 05:50:40

It canâ€™t get as granular as individual rows of an outline, though . For that you would need something like the â€˜cuke_slicerâ€™ gem.

ðŸº Paul_N
phebus
2019-05-01 05:56:54

dang!

phebus
2019-05-01 05:57:16

how long have i been sleeping on that

Paul_N
2019-05-01 06:06:55

@enkessler I did try the group-by before but could not get the syntax correct. I will have another try

Paul_N
2019-05-01 07:17:18

@enkessler @phebus --group-by worked! 15% speed improvement on the whole suite compared to parallelizing by feature. As a bonus the reporting tool lists by scenario so management thinks we have just expanded our test suite by a factor of 6 ðŸ˜Š

phebus
2019-05-01 07:19:46

sweet!

enkessler
2019-05-01 07:27:34

Always glad to help. ðŸ™‚

phebus
2019-05-01 12:45:42

looking at a 7% improvement on our largest suite so thatâ€™s nice. thanks again!

ðŸ‘ Gem, Paul_N
enkessler
2019-05-01 13:42:17

Nice! If you have outlines with lots of rows, you might get even more improvement by going all the way down to that level of test distribution.

NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:32:25

Hi, Is there a way forcefully fail a test and proceed to next based on a condition in Cucumber?

NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:37:58

Im using rSpec by the way

enkessler
2019-05-04 08:39:10

What do you mean by â€˜forcefully failâ€™? A test fails if an exception is raised (usually via an assertion) and the framework goes on to the next test anyway because tests failing/passing is normal.

enkessler
2019-05-04 08:40:28

Are you wanting Cucumber and RSpec to interact in some way?

NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:42:15
Untitled
NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:42:18

Yeah. The current framework has bit of a problem. This has a method which rescues the exceptions and go forward. In this method I want to fail the case if retries == 30.

NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:42:42

This is a utility class called by Page Class

NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:43:22

There is no point in going forward if retries = 30

NaviHan
2019-05-04 08:43:40

And I want to fail the scenario if retries == 30

enkessler
2019-05-04 08:49:21

Oh. In that case, just go ahead and re-raise the caught exception or make a new one and raise it.

enkessler
2019-05-04 08:52:06
 
def wait_and_set_text element, value
  begin
    retries ||= 0
    Watir::Wait.until {element}.set value
  rescue Selenium::WebDriver::Error::UnknownError, Watir::Exception::UnknownObjectException =&gt; e
    if (retries += 1) &lt; $code_retry
      retry 
    else
      raise e
    end
  end
end
enkessler
2019-05-04 08:53:14

Alternatively,

    if (retries += 1) &lt; $code_retry
      retry 
    else
      raise("Couldn't set element to #{value} after #{retries} attempts!")
    end
enkessler
2019-05-04 08:54:18

Assuming that nothing else up the stack catches those raised exceptions, the test will fail and life will go on.

NaviHan
2019-05-04 09:05:22

Thats cool idea @enkessler ðŸ™‚

enkessler
2019-05-04 09:05:51

Glad to help. ðŸ™‚

ðŸ‘ NaviHan
NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:37:13

Im facing an issue with reading the innerText of an element.

NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:38:07
Untitled
NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:38:36

And here is the output of the two puts statements

NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:40:09
Untitled
NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:41:25

The issue is wait_and_get_text cod_error_message_element which calls the innertext function on the elements sometimes return Sorry, Cash On Delivery is not currently available with Click &amp; Collect.Please change your payment or delivery method.

NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:43:46

And sometimes return

NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:43:59
Untitled
NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:44:40

That is sometimes both sentences in one line and sometimes in two lines

NaviHan
2019-05-07 06:44:45

Any idea why?

luke
2019-05-07 07:32:14

What version of gems are you using. Also what environments.

luke
2019-05-07 07:32:33

Assuming you're using capybara, it does a lot of text normalization and some of that logic has changed between v2 and v3

luke
2019-05-07 07:33:43

there's a healthy amount of un-necessary code in your example too which obfuscates the issue. Diet it down massively.

All you should need is expect(page.code_tab_message).to include text or the other element. You don't need block elements.

luke
2019-05-07 07:34:19

also I don't know your page html / locators

2019-05-07 07:46:27

luke
2019-05-07 08:56:04

oki, well then you just need to ensure your locators are correct. I'm not familiar with Watirs policy on text node normalization.

I would hazard a guess it's something to do with the text rendering, that's all. But you can add a sanitization method at your end if you want, or monkeypatch it if it's causing you problems.

luke
2019-05-09 02:49:30

luke
2019-05-09 02:49:33

I use rubymine

luke
2019-05-09 02:50:01

NaviHan
2019-05-09 03:56:28

That's great. Could you please advice me on how to debug cucumber feature file that calls Ruby Step def and Ruby Page classes. For eclipse I put the break point and then do F6, F6 , F5 and F8... I checked in google and saw many articles on problems with debugging using Rubymine

NaviHan
2019-05-09 03:56:56

Hence assumed it difficult

luke
2019-05-09 05:45:38

All you do is add a breakpoint manually, and then when you go to run your cucumber feature, instead of clicking run you click debug.

luke
2019-05-09 05:46:00

Make sure to add your breakpoint BEFORE the code you want to test. It will stop ON the line you make your breakpoint at. Not before it.

luke
2019-05-09 05:46:52
 
#1 def my_method
#2   puts 'hi'
#3   puts 1+2
#4 end

Put a debug point on line2, would stop execution in the following script

# myscript.rb
puts 'starting'
my_method
luke
2019-05-09 05:47:17

and you'd be inside main::my_method

NaviHan
2019-05-09 06:20:53

Once I reach the break point how do I skip line by line?

luke
2019-05-09 06:44:54

There's a Play with a line next to it. That will go to the next breakpoint.

luke
2019-05-09 06:44:59

thats the way I debug.

luke
2019-05-09 06:45:06

line by line just run code in the interactive debugger

NaviHan
2019-05-09 06:47:49

Is this the one?

NaviHan
2019-05-09 06:50:00

NaviHan
2019-05-09 06:50:37

luke
2019-05-09 06:54:02

Icon below restart on the left pane.

luke
2019-05-09 06:54:10

Play one will continue to the next breakpoint

luke
2019-05-09 06:54:32

then the blue icons at the top of the bottom pane allow you to step through, step into e.t.c.

luke
2019-05-14 05:50:15

2019-05-14 05:50:54

2019-05-14 05:51:02

luke
2019-05-14 23:50:46

require_all is a gem I believe. I said you need to use either a file named the same as the directory or an all.rb file.

luke
2019-05-14 23:52:25

so for example inside your /support directory, create a file called all.rb In that file do

require_relative 'env.rb'
require_relative 'hooks.rb'
require_relative 'monkey_patch.rb'
....
luke
2019-05-14 23:53:01

then in your env.rb true underneath features/support simply add a line that does, require_relative '../support/all.rb' (Not sure on the exact path)

Nicole
2019-06-04 15:48:46

I have a couple of very basic questions that I'm trying hard to understand but have given up after googling most of the afternoon. I apologize in advance. Am I correct that env.rb is loaded once per cucumber test run (not once per scenario) and anything at that top level is run once before the feature files are ran? My other confusion is that https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/api/ says "Global Hooks A global hook will run once before any scenario is run. Simply put the code at the top-level in your env.rb file (or any other file under features/support directory)." but then also "Running a hook only once. If you have a hook you only want to run once, use a global variable: .." Is that just two ways of doing the same thing?

enkessler
2019-06-04 17:05:52

Barring any forced load-ing, yes, env.rb will only be read and executed (i.e. required) once per Cucumber process. Assuming that no -r flags are being used to explicitly require files, yes, env.rb will also be the first file to be required. Because of both of these things, there is no real global Before hook. If the code is in env.rb then it is executed exactly once and before any other code (such as a test scenario) is run. The use of a global variable to control the number of times a hook is executed, though similar, is not the same as a global hook. A global hook happens first. A one-shot hook could happen at whatever point in the hook order it was declared, but then never again.

enkessler
2019-06-04 17:10:26

Alternatively, a one-shot hook could be controlled by a tag. Let's say that seeding a database with test data is very time consuming but that the seeded data will be sufficient for any test that needs it. A Before hook that only applies to tests marked with @database and that has a global variable as a flag would allow for significant time saving by never being executed if no @database tests are being run but, if they are run, only having the hook execute once.

ðŸ‘ Nicole
Nicole
2019-06-05 06:27:42

*Thread Reply:* Thank you @enkessler! This was a super helpful explanation. I didn't think about FIRST versus ONCE. Really appreciate the clarification ðŸ™‚

enkessler
2019-06-05 08:38:43

*Thread Reply:* You are quite welcome.

mlvandijk
2019-06-04 21:52:18

So I gues this is not clearly explaining in the docs (cucumber.io/docs)? Anyone here willing to do a PR? (Can't do it myself as I don't use Ruby, but I know we do mention the env.rb somewhere)

luke
2019-06-05 00:10:15

This is something which is going to change a bit for v4 @mlvandijk (With an experimental new PR I'm doing, I've got it looked over by matt recently).

luke
2019-06-05 00:10:32

I'm writing a blog post on the past, the future and why it's being done. Just need to get round to writing it, the PR itself is nearly complete.

mlvandijk
2019-06-05 00:12:51

Good to know, thanks @luke

luke
2019-06-05 00:13:33

there's a PR which I've just tidied up here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349 it was from an issue (or bug if you like), from 2017 I finally got round to fixing. But it's taken a long time. Infact both my recent cucumber fixes have been quite lengthy.

luke-hill (https://github.com/luke-hill)
#1349 Spike/altered loading strategy
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Provide a way for cucumber to only load files once.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>Using a config switch, decide on whether cucumber should recurse through files potentially <code>n</code> times, or just once only.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>This fixes an old problem here: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> - Where the user had procedural code which was being instantiated twice. A user should be able to specify the load order of a file, and "not" have the file loaded twice.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>Unit Tests have been added in the appropriate file.</p> <p><strong>Screenshots (if appropriate):</strong> <strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>â˜‘ï¸Ž Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) â˜ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) â˜‘ï¸Ž New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) â˜ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>â˜‘ï¸Ž I've added tests for my code â˜ My change requires a change to the documentation. â˜ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p> <p>Outstanding questions FYI: <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> / <a href="https://github.com/roberts1000">@roberts1000</a></p> <p>â€¢ Should we use the top level config or the config level which requires flags. â€¢ How should we advertise this? â€¢ Is there anything missing?</p>

Bhargavi [4:21 PM] Feature: Site Search Scenario: Given We navigate to the homepage When We search for the word agile Then The results for the search will be displayed require 'selenium-webdriver' driver = Selenium::WebDriver.for :chrome

Given("We navigate to the homepage") do driver.navigate.to "https://www.google.com/" end

When("We search for the word agile") do driver.findelement(:id, 'searchform').sendkeys("agile") driver.find_element(:id, 'submit-button').click end

Then("The results for the search will be displayed") do wait = Selenium::WebDriver::Wait.new(:timeout => 20) # seconds begin element = wait.until { driver.find_element(:id => "search-title") } expect(element.text).to eq('Search Results for: agile') ensure driver.quit end end

Aslak HellesÃ¸y

luke
2019-06-05 08:55:13

What aslak is trying to hint is that the first error suggested the element (The name we give to things like buttons / radios / text boxes), wasn't interactable.

luke
2019-06-05 08:55:27

now the reason could be one of many, but usually it means you're doing something invalid or it is not visible.

luke
2019-06-05 08:55:42

the 2nd error is suggesting that the element you've asked for (:id, 'q').send_keys("agile")

luke
2019-06-05 08:55:48

doesn't actually exist. It cannot find it.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2019-06-05 08:55:49

Right, so you are trying to look up an element with id equal to q, and you get Selenium::WebDriver::Error::NoSuchElementError. What do you think that means? Is there a DOM element with id="q" on the page?

Bhargavi
2019-06-05 08:56:28

no. but there was no ID in <input> tag

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2019-06-05 08:56:47

Exactly!

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2019-06-05 08:57:10

So itâ€™s no surprise Selenium is telling you that there is no such element on the page

luke
2019-06-05 08:57:15

when locating elements, you don't always need to search by id, there are a multitude of ways you could possibly search for an element. For example it's class or maybe some other property (I'm not sure how familiar you are with how a web page is structured)

Bhargavi
2019-06-05 08:58:02

can i enter <name> or <class> instead of <id> ?

luke
2019-06-05 08:58:36

you certainly can.

luke
2019-06-05 08:58:53

If you are interested, there are some good resources to read on how to locate elements on a webpage at w3schools

luke
2019-06-05 08:59:02

https://www.w3schools.com/css/css_attribute_selectors.asp

w3schools.com
CSS Attribute Selector
Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
Original URL: https://www.w3schools.com/css/css_attribute_selectors.asp
luke
2019-06-05 08:59:47

Here is an easier "cheat-sheet" as well https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_selectors.asp

w3schools.com
CSS Selectors Reference
Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
Original URL: https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_selectors.asp
luke
2019-06-05 09:01:29

Just be careful with the syntax you use. You need to make sure you tell selenium "how" your locating the element, so in your example, when you type :id it tells selenium you want to use a specific id

luke
2019-06-06 04:32:39

a lot of this isn't cucumber questions though, it's selenium.

So when you create your browser capabilities, you simply create a 2nd set of caps, and then using that new driver instance, call goto (Or if you're using capybara, create a new capybara selenium driver)

Vilius Gudziunas
2019-06-06 10:01:22

Hey, this question has been asked on a couple places on google but it was mostly solved with java and there was no 'decent' ruby solution.

I want to make it so that if a step in a scenario fails, cucumber doesn't skip the other steps in that scenario, but rather executes them and then fails after the last step has run.

I know I could achieve this by using begin/rescue and recording the errors or I could also split the scenario into many singular step scenarios but these solutions don't look clean to me.

I was wondering if anybody knows of a neat, simple way to do this? Thanks

luke
2019-06-07 01:24:05

â˜ï¸ Million Dollar question.... Why?

â˜ï¸ Gem
luke
2019-06-07 01:24:23

This would be best solved with a monkeypatch over cucumber, but yeh it just seems odd, I'm not sure what you're trying to accomplish

Vilius Gudziunas
2019-06-07 01:36:27

I have a scenario in which each step is a specific check on a file - e.g. Scenario .. I test the header of a file I test the trailer of a file I test the rows of a file ... In case a step that tests trailer fails, I want it to go on and test the rows of a file.

luke
2019-06-07 03:03:14

that breaks TIL - Test Isolation Principle.

ðŸŽ¯ Gem
luke
2019-06-07 03:03:23

You should have 3 scenarios.

luke
2019-06-07 03:03:35

One that tests the header, One that tests the trailer, one that tests the rows.

luke
2019-06-07 03:03:51

also the phrase I test the rows of a file what does that mean? How are you testing them?

Vilius Gudziunas
2019-06-07 03:12:30

Those were just example steps.

So if going by TIL I would have a bunch of scenarios containing 1 step each?

Scenario header I test the header of a file

Scenario trailer I test the trailer of a file

Scenario rows I test the rows of a file ...

enkessler
2019-06-07 07:09:06

*Thread Reply:* Alternatively, if you do consider all of the different parts of the file to be one single concept that is being tested, you could test it using only one step instead of three different steps. Then it would be up to you to handle partial errors and raising a final, consolidated error message for the failed test.

mlvandijk
2019-06-07 07:31:27

*Thread Reply:* Also this seems more of a unit test to me. Why use Cucumber at all?

Certifying Software Testers Worldwide - ISTQBÂ® International Software Testing Qualifications Board

Gem

luke
2019-06-11 01:05:52

*Thread Reply:* in the uk nearly everyone has the foundation level.

The problem with it being the universally recognised standard is the costs are obscene. I got through my foundation with a training company before i became a tester but i'm pretty sure resources + tests + practices is like Â£500-Â£1000 for the foundation level.

Gem
2019-06-11 10:15:25

*Thread Reply:* That's pretty nuts, but if it actually matters and what they teach is solid, then it could also be considered worth it

luke
2019-06-12 01:08:17

*Thread Reply:* kind of.... The foundation level anyone who wants to be a good tester should pass.

For someone whose background was in maths I found it quite useful. I went into a company as a junior tester and was teaching people who'd done testing for years (But weren't testers), what exactly to test.

Gem
2019-06-12 04:34:29

*Thread Reply:* What about for someone whose background isn't in maths? :P

luke
2019-06-12 04:52:58

*Thread Reply:* if you're background is in something technical but not testing, then it's probably useful. It covers things like boundary analysis. It's quite a "soft skills" style accreditation. And the test is multiple choice out of 40 (Think you need 70% to pass)

luke
2019-06-07 05:48:19

most people do through the certified tester foundation level (the first qualification at the bottom)

â˜ï¸ Gem
luke
2019-06-07 06:46:15

As such you are best asking there, as that is the correct place to ask questions about browser automation. People here may use cucumber for browser automation, that is true, but cucumber can be used for api testing for example, amongst other things (Documentation tool as another example)

Trupti
2019-06-12 01:40:06

@Trupti has joined the channel

Trupti
2019-06-12 01:45:00

As the number of pages and features in the product go in increasing, what is the folder structure to be followed? Any guide on that?

luke
2019-06-12 02:25:46

I have a subfolder per main area. So in a previous company my folder structure was (Partially)

features
  e2e - All e2e tests
  personalisation - anything to do with how we customised the site to users
  accounts - log in / log out / reset pass
  post_booking - logging into the my bookings area
  basket_checks - verifying what we displayed in the basket (price / offers wise), was correct
luke
2019-06-12 02:26:22

currently i'm doing api tests, so my folder structure is

features
  api_name_one
  api_name_two
  api_name_three
enkessler
2019-06-12 07:32:05

@Trupti , aside from the presence of the â€˜features/supportâ€™ folder, folder structure has zero impact on how Cucumber behaves. It is purely an organizational issue, so, as @luke illustrated, it really comes down to the needs of the project and what makes the most sense to the people working in it.

luke
2019-06-12 07:44:20

cucumber has an auto-loader that loads every rb file it finds, so don't worry about how you structure your supporting code / step defs

enkessler
2019-06-12 07:49:31

Oh, right. I forgot about the auto-loading of Ruby files, due to not having put Ruby files under â€˜featuresâ€™ in years (because, you know, theyâ€™re not). The auto-loading would be something to keep in mind in case there are files that you need required in a particular order.

Matthias Carell
2019-06-13 05:07:18

@Matthias Carell has joined the channel

Trupti
2019-06-14 00:09:52

Thanks @enkessler @luke that helps! Another question I had was about making steps file understandable to a novice member in the team. Should I build a correlation in names of step_def file with the feature file ? Because the difficultly I have faced is - each member adds their own piece of steps without reusing the existing steps. While there is no issue with that, but it increases - 1. The cost of maintenance and 2. The cost of engineering

Trisha
2019-06-14 01:20:24

@Trisha has joined the channel

Matthias Carell
2019-06-14 03:13:15

@Trupti Did you know that cucumber -f stepdefs shows you which steps are used and the name of the associated step file? This might help you to refactor your steps.

Trupti
2019-06-14 03:18:50

Interesting

Trupti
2019-06-14 03:25:24

But the output in itself is a long list, again not easily readable

Trupti
2019-06-14 03:31:56

I'd really like some guideline like

- step_definitions
-- login_page_steps.rb
-- home_page_steps.rb
login.feature
home_page.feature

Or something like that, so I know the exact place to go to find something

mlvandijk
2019-06-14 10:48:28

@Trupti we recommend against feature-coupled step definitions (see cucumber.io/docs and look for anti-patterns). I'd recommend grouping them along to functionality, for instance domain objects (customer, account, order), or other systems you are talking to, or for UI page objects they are working with.

Matthias Carell
2019-06-17 01:03:56

@Trupti I would look for steps similar to each other but located on different step files. But this is refactoring already on a low level. So reflecting the general structure of your features and looking for anti-patterns like @mlvandijk recommended seems to be good idea for me. You could start here: https://cucumber.io/docs/guides/anti-patterns/ and here: http://www.thinkcode.se/blog/2016/06/22/cucumber-antipatterns I can also recommend https://www.manning.com/books/writing-great-specifications

Manning Publications
Writing Great Specifications
Does a great job taking concepts from good architectural practices and applying them to the world of collaborative specifications.
Original URL: https://www.manning.com/books/writing-great-specifications
Matthias Carell
2019-06-17 01:17:31

@Trupti one more thing - a feature named homepage.feature might be a good candidate for refactoring. E.g. if this is a homepage for a typical ecommerce system this page contains usually several features that can be mapped to different steps of a customer journey like advertisement banners, navigational elements or basket overview.

Trupti
2019-06-17 23:37:52

Thanks @Matthias Carell @mlvandijk! ðŸ‘ I will read up a bit and respond back if I have questions

ðŸ‘ Matthias Carell
mlvandijk
2019-06-18 00:18:24

Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-25 10:48:44

In the v4.0.0 gem, the Feature node on the Scenario object seems to be gone. Does anyone know where that data is available now?

Ukaza Perdana
2019-06-25 19:12:50

@Ukaza Perdana has joined the channel

brasmusson
2019-06-26 00:24:53

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/README.md#pickles @Jason Koelewyn The only data that can be available during the execution are the data of the pickle. To be able to successfully execute you really shouldn't need any data of feature.

gherkin/README.md
<pre><code># Gherkin Gherkin is a parser and compiler for the Gherkin language. Gherkin is currently implemented for the following platforms (in order of birthday): ** [.NET](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-dotnet&gt;) ** [Java](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-java&gt;) ** [JavaScript](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-javascript&gt;) ** [Ruby](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-ruby&gt;) ** [Go](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-go&gt;) ** [Python](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-python&gt;) ** [Objective-C](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-objective-c&gt;) ** [Perl](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-perl&gt;) See [`CONTRIBUTING.md`](CONTRIBUTING.md) if you want to contribute a parser for a new language. Our wish-list is (in no particular order): ** C ** PHP ** Rust ** Elixir ## Usage Gherkin can be used either through its command line interface (CLI) or as a library. It is designed to be used in conjunction with other tools such as Cucumber or Gherkin-Lint, which consume the output from the CLI or library. Other tools should use the library if there is a Gherkin library in the same language as the tool itself. If not, use the CLI in one of the implementations. The Gherkin CLI makes it possible to implement Cucumber for a new language, say Rust or Elixir, without having to implement a Gherkin parser too. ### CLI The Gherkin CLI `gherkin` reads Gherkin source files (`.feature` files) and outputs [ASTs](#ast) and [Pickles](#pickles). The `gherkin` program takes any number of files as arguments and prints the results to `STDOUT` as [Newline Delimited JSON](&lt;http://ndjson.org/&gt;). Each line is a JSON document that conforms to the [Cucumber Event Protocol](&lt;https://docs.cucumber.io/event-protocol/&gt;). To try it out, just install Gherkin for your favourite language, and run it over the files in this repository: gherkin testdata/****/**.feature Ndjson is easy to read for programs, but hard for people. To pretty print each JSON document you can pipe it to the [jq](&lt;https://stedolan.github.io/jq/&gt;) program: gherkin testdata/****/**.feature | jq ### Library Using the library is the preferred way to use Gherkin since it produces easily consumable AST and Pickle objects in-process without having to fork a CLI process or parse JSON. The library itself provides a **stream** API, which is what the CLI is based on. This is the recommended way to use the library as it provides a high level API that is easy to use. See the CLI implementations to get an idea of how to use it. Alternatively, you can use the lower level parser and compiler. Some usage examples are below: ```java // Java Parser&amp;lt;GherkinDocument&amp;gt; parser = new Parser&amp;lt;&amp;gt;(new AstBuilder()); GherkinDocument gherkinDocument = parser.parse("Feature: ..."); List&amp;lt;Pickle&amp;gt; pickles = new Compiler().compile(gherkinDocument) </code></pre> <pre><code>// C# var parser = new Parser(); var gherkinDocument = parser.Parse("Feature: ..."); </code></pre> <pre><code># Ruby require 'gherkin/parser' require 'gherkin/pickles/compiler' parser = Gherkin::Parser.new gherkin_document = parser.parse("Feature: ...") pickles = Gherkin::Pickles::Compiler.new.compile(gherkin_document) </code></pre> <pre><code>// JavaScript var Gherkin = require('gherkin'); var parser = new Gherkin.Parser(); var gherkinDocument = parser.parse("Feature: ..."); var pickles = new Gherkin.Compiler().compile(gherkinDocument); </code></pre> <pre><code>// Go // Download the package via: `go get &lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-go"&gt;github.com/cucumber/gherkin-go&lt;/a&gt;` import ( "strings" "&lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-go"&gt;github.com/cucumber/gherkin-go&lt;/a&gt;" ) reader := strings.NewReader(`Feature: ...`) gherkinDocument, err := gherkin.ParseGherkinDocument(reader) </code></pre> <pre><code># Python from gherkin.parser import Parser from gherkin.pickles.compiler import compile parser = Parser() gherkin_document = parser.parse("Feature: ...") pickles = compile(gherkin_document) </code></pre> <pre><code>// Objective-C #import "GHParser+Extensions.h" GHParser ** parser = [[GHParser alloc] init]; NSString ** featureFilePath; // Should refer to the place where we can get the content of the feature NSString ** content = [NSString stringWithContentsOfURL:featureFilePath encoding:NSUTF8StringEncoding error:nil]; if([content stringByTrimmingCharactersInSet:[NSCharacterSet whitespaceAndNewlineCharacterSet]].length == 0){ // GHParser will throw an error if you passed empty content... handle this issue first. } GHGherkinDocument ** result = [parser parseContent:content]; </code></pre> <pre><code># Perl use Gherkin::Parser; use Gherkin::Pickles::Compiler; my $parser = Gherkin::Parser-&amp;gt;new(); my $gherkin_document = $parser-&amp;gt;parse("Feature: ..."); my $pickles = Gherkin::Pickles::Compiler-&amp;gt;compile($gherkin_document); </code></pre> <h2>Table cell escaping</h2> <p>If you want to use a newline character in a table cell, you can write this as <code>\n</code>. If you need a '|' as part of the cell, you can escape it as <code>\|</code>. And finally, if you need a '\', you can escape that with <code>\\</code>.</p> <h2>Architecture</h2> <p>The following diagram outlines the architecture:</p> <pre><code>â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â•”â•â•â•â•— â•‘Feature fileâ•‘â”€â”€&amp;gt;â”‚Scannerâ”‚â”€â”€&amp;gt;â•‘Tokensâ•‘â”€â”€&amp;gt;â”‚Parserâ”‚â”€â”€&amp;gt;â•‘ASTâ•‘ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â• â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â•šâ•â•â•â• </code></pre> <p>The <strong>scanner</strong> reads a gherkin doc (typically read from a <code>.feature</code> file) and creates a <strong>token</strong> for each line. The tokens are passed to the <strong>parser</strong>, which outputs an <strong>AST</strong> (Abstract Syntax Tree).</p> <p>If the scanner sees a <code>#language</code> header, it will reconfigure itself dynamically to look for Gherkin keywords for the associated language. The keywords are defined in <code>gherkin-languages.json</code>.</p> <p>The scanner is hand-written, but the parser is generated by the <a href="https://github.com/gasparnagy/berp">Berp</a> parser generator as part of the build process.</p> <p>Berp takes a grammar file (<code>gherkin.berp</code>) and a template file (<code>gherkin-X.razor</code>) as input and outputs a parser in language <strong>X</strong>:</p> <pre><code>â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â•‘gherkin.berpâ•‘â”€â”€&amp;gt;â”‚berp.exeâ”‚&amp;lt;â”€â”€â•‘gherkin-X.razorâ•‘ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• â”‚ V â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â•‘Parser.xâ•‘ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• </code></pre> <p>Also see the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin/wiki">wiki</a> for some early design docs (which might be a little outdated, but mostly OK).</p> <h3>AST</h3> <p>The AST produced by the parser can be described with the following class diagram:</p> <p><img src="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/docs/ast.png" alt="" /></p> <p>Every class represents a node in the AST. Every node has a <code>Location</code> that describes the line number and column number in the input file. These numbers are 1-indexed.</p> <p>All fields on nodes are strings (except for <code>Location.line</code> and <code>Location.column</code>).</p> <p>The implementation is simple objects without behaviour, only data. It's up to the implementation to decide whether to use classes or just basic collections, but the AST <strong>must</strong> have a JSON representation (this is used for testing).</p> <p>Each node in the JSON representation also has a <code>type</code> property with the name of the node type.</p> <p>You can see some examples in the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/gherkin/testdata/good">testdata/good</a> directory.</p> <h3>Pickles</h3> <p>The AST isn't suitable for execution by Cucumber. It needs further processing into a simpler form called <strong>Pickles</strong>.</p> <p>The compiler compiles the AST produced by the parser into pickles:</p> <pre><code>â•”â•â•â•â•— â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â” â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â•‘ASTâ•‘â”€â”€&amp;gt;â”‚Compilerâ”‚â”€â”€&amp;gt;â•‘Picklesâ•‘ â•šâ•â•â•â• â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• </code></pre> <p>The rationale is to decouple Gherkin from Cucumber so that Cucumber is open to support alternative formats to Gherkin (for example Markdown).</p> <p>The simpler <strong>Pickles</strong> data structure also simplifies the internals of Cucumber. With the compilation logic maintained in the Gherkin library we can easily use the same test suite for all implementations to verify that compilation is behaving consistently between implemenâ€¦</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-26 06:19:28

*Thread Reply:* So:

  1. This is currently available data that is being removed. Please provide justification for removing this functionality.
  2. Execution is not the only concern. If all we care about is execution, I would not even use cucumber.
  3. Our entire reporting structure is predicated on having access to the Feature name. This has always been part of the record. This is a major breaking change for us.
brasmusson
2019-06-26 11:08:56

*Thread Reply:* From the Readme.mdof Gherkin (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/gherkin#pickles): "The AST isn't suitable for execution by Cucumber. It needs further processing into a simpler form called Pickles." As far as I understand, one of the major lessons from Cucumber-Ruby v1 was that the executing the scenarios by iterating over the AST make things very complex, error prone and brittle. From the Readme.md of Gherkin: "``` The rationale is to decouple Gherkin from Cucumber so that Cucumber is open to support alternative formats to Gherkin (for example Markdown).

The simpler Pickles data structure also simplifies the internals of Cucumber.```"

The Pickles concept has been in the Gherkin library since the release of v3 (the Gherkin3 gem) in July 2015. It is the update of Cucumber-Ruby from Gherkin v2.x that has been lagging.

It is indeed a breaking change, therefore it has been introduce at a major version update on Gherkin and Cucumber-Ruby.

Cucumber-Ruby has from the start had separate mechanisms for execution (which for instance includes hooks) and reporting (formatters). With the use of Gherkin v3 (or later) trying to use the mechanisms for execution for reporting has been harder or impossible. I delibertely used the phrase "To be able to successfully execute ..." since when a Cucumber implementation executes a Pickle two things should be achieved, the proper execution of the Pickle (which might include using hooks for set up, tear down etc), and firing events about what is happening to the event stream that formatters and other event listeners can subscribe to. In that event stream are also events with the full content for the feature file, the full AST parsed from the feature file available, so even though the Feature name is not available when the Cucumber implementation is executing a Pickle, the Feature name is available to the reporting mechanisms, like formatters, of the Cucumber implementation.

Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-26 12:06:19

Ok, so can you point me to where I can pull the feature name from within a beforeHook?

Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-26 12:09:14

othewise we will use the feature file path, which is still included and use that to extract the feature name

brasmusson
2019-06-26 12:27:05

No, the feature name is not available from within a (before-)hook.

enkessler
2019-06-26 12:28:30

So the preferred way to do reporting is through a custom formatter that listens to events rather than a hook based approach?

Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-26 12:30:28

We have several reasons why we need to set the name in the Before Hook. We will have to encapsulate a method to derive the name ourselves.

enkessler
2019-06-26 12:39:32

@Jason Koelewyn I'm curious as to what those reasons are.

Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-26 12:48:20

*Thread Reply:* So 1 is simple output, it helps make the reports more readable. But more important is the way we parallel run. We have a custom stack that splits the features down to scenarios to run across all available nodes, and then stitches the results back into reports by feature.

enkessler
2019-06-26 12:56:53

*Thread Reply:* All of that can be done without the hook mechanism. From what @brasmusson was saying, it sounds like, as of 4.0, it must be done without the hook mechanism.

Jason Koelewyn
2019-06-27 08:07:28

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, there are other ways, we are looking in to them now

Mahtab Bahman Nejad
2019-06-30 23:34:18

@Mahtab Bahman Nejad has joined the channel

Anuj
2019-07-11 17:14:52

A quick question, is it possible to use the default linters for features that have a certain tag ? It probably is possible but what Iâ€™m trying to ask is how.

enkessler
2019-07-11 21:18:18

Are you wanting to disable certain linters for certain features but otherwise use them by default?

Anuj
2019-07-11 22:02:31

Not exactly. Some of the features are tagged as @capybara and I want to be able to run the linter only for those features. I can use the cukemodeler to filter these out and pass the feature files to the cukelinter, but this seems like an overkill. Any ideas ?

enkessler
2019-07-11 22:23:15

No, that is pretty much the only way to do it, currently.

Linting occurs on models and file paths. I'm assuming that the @capybara files are not conveniently isolated such that you can simply pass the directory and be done with it. Therefore, yes, you would have to get the relevant models in isolation yourself. Some cql should do the trick:

require 'cuke_linter'
require 'cql'
require 'cql/model_dsl'

test_directory          = CukeModeler::Directory.new('path/to/your/test_suite')
capybara_feature_models = test_directory.query do
  select :model
  from features
  where { |feature| feature.tags.any? { |tag| tag.value == '@capybara' } }
end.collect { |result| result[:model] }

CukeLinter.lint(model_trees: capybara_feature_models)
Anuj
2019-07-23 18:56:52

*Thread Reply:* This does work after a bit of tweaking. However thereâ€™s another problem, not with the gem but with our test suite. We have feature files that has a mix of scenarios tagged with @capybara and some scenarios not tagged at all.

Can cuke_linter do its magic at a scenario level instead of at a file level ?

Anuj
2019-07-23 22:28:41

*Thread Reply:* okay I think I have a solution, will share it tomorrow.

enkessler
2019-07-11 22:24:27

Something like that. It might need some tweaking but that's the gist of it.

enkessler
2019-07-11 22:33:56

Disabling linters (or linting all together) via marking the Gherkin in some fashion (I'm leaning towards comments) is next on the feature list for the gem.

enkessler
2019-07-11 22:39:25

Anuj
2019-07-29 19:45:25

@luke Hi Luke ! I had a question related to loadvalidations for siteprism. Is there a way to expect on a load_validation error ?

Lets say we have this page

class ResetPasswordPage &lt; SitePrism::Page
  set_url '/customer/reset_password/{reset_code}'

  element :password, '#password'
  element :confirm_password, '#user_password_confirmation'
  element :submit, 'input[value="Submit"]'

  element :no_such_element, '#no_such_element'

  load_validation  { [has_no_such_element?, "No such element error message"] }

In our tests, how can we do this ?

expect(RestPasswordPage.new.load(:reset_code =&gt; 1234)).to raise_error(SitePrism::FailedLoadValidationError)

^ This returns a validation error anyways instead of the test passing.

luke
2019-07-29 23:50:51

right. So you've got it almost right.

luke
2019-07-29 23:52:05

I'll give you a clue.

RSpec can "trap" expectations, but in order to do this, the line must be ran in block context

i.e. look at the following two examples

Then('I fail') do
  # This will fail because of a standarderror
  expect(raise StandardError).to raise_error(StandardError)
end

Then('I fail') do
  # This passes
  expect { raise StandardError }.to raise_error(StandardError)
end
luke
2019-07-29 23:54:51

Also. I don't have an idea really "how" to do it. And it isn't clear in the docs. But avoid having any DSL item that is called no_xxx

luke
2019-07-29 23:55:00

I'll probably just add a warning or something,.

luke
2019-07-29 23:55:42

as it'll conflict with the whole has_xx? and has_no_xxx?

luke
2019-07-29 23:55:58

it'll work correctly, but it just is likely to throw issues down the line.

Anuj
2019-07-30 14:28:35

Thanks for this ! I did not know about this in RSpecs, so TIL. ðŸ™‚

luke
2019-07-31 00:54:05

If you've got any ideas for how to improve / add to site_prism feel free to open issues / PR's.

Things are fairly quiet at the moment, so I've got a bit more time on it.

Anuj
2019-07-31 14:09:48

>But avoid having any DSL item that is called no_xxx

Although I had the no_such_element as an example, but this is good to know. Maybe a linter for site_prism pages ?

luke
2019-08-01 01:44:59

perhaps yes. Or I'd prefer it to live inside the dsl code. Have a go at writing something which will warn users to start with perhaps?

2019-08-01 15:07:23

2019-08-12 00:07:45

luke
2019-08-12 00:08:12

luke
2019-08-12 00:09:06

@Anuj a very quick (And very much, use at your own caution monkeypatch would be)

def step(**args)
  puts 'Step called' # Or any other logging / counting logic here
  super(args)
end
Anuj
2019-08-13 13:57:05

*Thread Reply:* This unfortunately didnâ€™t work ðŸ˜ž Doesnâ€™t get called if a nested step definition is being worked on. I might have put it in the wrong place (not sure how I would that though), so Iâ€™ll try and tweak some things to make this work.

luke
2019-08-13 23:32:21

luke
2019-08-12 00:09:35

Anuj
2019-08-12 01:02:17

I would be quite happy (among many others) when the nested step defa feature is removed. Itâ€™s abused a lot and causes too much pain.

However, for now, we want to sort our scenarios based on the number of steps its going to execute so that our test runner can start with the longest one first. Iâ€™ll try the above and see how it goes. It will most likely not pass code review.

enkessler
2019-08-13 13:13:24

wakes from his slumber Eh? I'm being summoned by @Gem. Let's see...

@Anuj, no, cql would not be particularly useful in this case because, as you mentioned, it only operates at the Gherkin level and not the implementation language level of Ruby/Java/etc. If you knew which steps called other steps and how many they called (either by digging into them yourself or by doing some kind of run time patch like @luke mentioned) then you could use cql to find top level usages of those steps and do the math in order to know how many total steps were called.

To recommend a much simpler solution, however: just use the total run time of the test. If you are going through the effort of running your tests in a certain order so that the overall suite is more efficient or load balanced or whatever, then you likely (or should probably start) already save previous test results. Steps calling other steps may be an indicator of test length, but nothing will be as accurate or easy to get as just having the most recent duration of the test already saved somewhere.

<shamelessplug>Incidentally, if you aren't already persisting the results of test executions for later analysis or are having a difficult time isolating which test is which, do have a look at cuke_cataloger. ðŸ˜Ž</shamelessplug>

Anuj
2019-08-13 13:58:41

*Thread Reply:* All our test results get saved in Jenkins but that is not persistent (saves only for a certain number of days). We do plot the slowest tests though - that might be a good start. thanks for the tip !

^ combined with the cuke cataloger might work

enkessler
2019-08-13 15:06:37

*Thread Reply:* It's not persistent until it's in a database. ðŸ™‚

Until then it's 'only temporary' or 'not someplace that we can access with code' or 'in a really weird format'.

luke
2019-08-13 23:33:35

*Thread Reply:* alter jenkins to save the last n runs. And then justify which ones need more artifacts saving?

High throughput / important jobs have higher values of n

Marco Sanabria
2019-08-14 08:11:30

@Marco Sanabria has joined the channel

mvz
2019-08-15 01:54:57

Hi all, due to an issue in Aruba (https://github.com/cucumber/aruba/issues/662), I'm trying to figure out the intended behavior for Doc Strings when it comes to the final newline. It seems that the final newline is removed, at least in cucumber-ruby, but the Gherkin reference (https://cucumber.io/docs/gherkin/reference/#doc-strings) doesn't say anything about it.

luke-hill (https://github.com/luke-hill)
#662 Using `append to file` cuke can cause syntax errors
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Using <code>append to file</code> cuke, shouldn't cause</p> <pre><code>syntax error, unexpected end-of-input, expecting keyword_end (SyntaxError) </code></pre> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p>It wouldn't cause the error above</p> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <p>It does cause the error above. Code similar to this can be produced</p> <pre><code>def path_to(page_name) self.send(page_name.split(' ').push('path').join('_').to_sym) end Then('I should see {string}') do |text| expect(page).to have_content(text) endWhen('I go to the session establish page') do # This is the problematic line visit path_to('session establish') end </code></pre> <p><strong>Possible Solution</strong></p> <p>Check for newline characters. If one isn't found, add one.<br /> Adding an extra newline even in the worst circumstance, is just a bad style, but not adding one can occassionally cause issues concatenating <code>end</code> and <code>Given</code> or <code>When</code> for example.</p> <p><strong>Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)</strong></p> <ol><li>Use cuke <code>write to file</code></li><li>Use cuke <code>append to file</code> in the same scenario with an identical path</li> </ol> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p>This is present in both scenario and background -&gt; scenario contexts.</p> <p>I've tagged this as a bug because it does feel something that shouldn't happen</p>
Labels
bug
Comments
10
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/aruba">cucumber/aruba</a>
brasmusson
2019-08-15 03:13:06

*Thread Reply:* Yes, the Gherkin parser does not include any (trailing) newline for a one line docstring, see the acceptance test https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/61094c432165fb532ca1a7ff95add206c5e186fd/gherkin/testdata/good/docstrings.feature.tokens#L19 and its corresponding feature file.

gherkin/testdata/good/docstrings.feature.tokens:19
<pre><code>(19:1)Other:/wrongly indented line/ </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
mvz
2019-08-15 03:40:43

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the pointer, but I can't see anything about newlines there: Each line of the docstrings seems to produce a similiar kind of token, whether it's the last line or not.

mvz
2019-08-15 03:43:18

*Thread Reply:* Oh wait, the .ast.ndjson file shows the actual docstring contents ðŸ‘

luke

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1328

Githraine (https://github.com/Githraine)
#1328 Scenario outlines still don't support examples in title
<p>We finally got upgraded to the latest Cuke.<br /> This is NOT resolved. Given this scenario outline:<br /> @mm<em>calc</em>tvr_001 <a href="https://github.com/wip">@wip</a><br /> Scenario Outline: Traditional vs Roth Base tests - &lt;title&gt;<br /> Given I output "&lt;title&gt;"<br /> And I am on the "Traditional vs Roth Calculator" calculator page<br /> When I populate the calculator from "" and "calculate"<br /> Then the calculator results should match the "base" section of ""</p> <pre><code>Examples: | title | inputs | | Single Higher Roth Now Matches | single_higher_now_roth_matches | | Married Higher Roth Now Matches | married_higher_now_roth_matches | | Married Lower Roth Now Matches | married_lower_now_roth_matches | | Married Lower Roth Later Matches | married_lower_later_roth_matches | | Married Lower 401k Later Matches | married_lower_later_401k_matches | | Single Lower Roth Later Matches | single_lower_later_roth_matches | | Married Lower 401k Later no Match | married_lower_later_401k_does_not_match | | Single Lower Later 401k no match | single_lower_later_401k_does_not_match | </code></pre> <p>the results are showing:<br /> Feature: Calculators - Traditional Vs Roth, Scenario: Traditional vs Roth Base tests - &lt;title&gt;, Examples (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1">#1</a>)</p> <p><em>Originally posted by <a href="https://github.com/Githraine">@Githraine</a> in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/984#issuecomment-439983638">#984 (comment)</a></em></p>
Labels

Githraine (https://github.com/Githraine)
#1328 Scenario outlines still don't support examples in title
<p>We finally got upgraded to the latest Cuke.<br /> This is NOT resolved. Given this scenario outline:<br /> @mm<em>calc</em>tvr_001 <a href="https://github.com/wip">@wip</a><br /> Scenario Outline: Traditional vs Roth Base tests - &lt;title&gt;<br /> Given I output "&lt;title&gt;"<br /> And I am on the "Traditional vs Roth Calculator" calculator page<br /> When I populate the calculator from "" and "calculate"<br /> Then the calculator results should match the "base" section of ""</p> <pre><code>Examples: | title | inputs | | Single Higher Roth Now Matches | single_higher_now_roth_matches | | Married Higher Roth Now Matches | married_higher_now_roth_matches | | Married Lower Roth Now Matches | married_lower_now_roth_matches | | Married Lower Roth Later Matches | married_lower_later_roth_matches | | Married Lower 401k Later Matches | married_lower_later_401k_matches | | Single Lower Roth Later Matches | single_lower_later_roth_matches | | Married Lower 401k Later no Match | married_lower_later_401k_does_not_match | | Single Lower Later 401k no match | single_lower_later_401k_does_not_match | </code></pre> <p>the results are showing:<br /> Feature: Calculators - Traditional Vs Roth, Scenario: Traditional vs Roth Base tests - &lt;title&gt;, Examples (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1">#1</a>)</p> <p><em>Originally posted by <a href="https://github.com/Githraine">@Githraine</a> in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/984#issuecomment-439983638">#984 (comment)</a></em></p>

Scenario Outline: Search for my Name <Name> # features/Test.feature:4 When I navigate to Google # features/Test.feature:5

Examples:
  | Name  |
  | Marco |  test1o1
  | Polo  |  test1o1
  | Test  |  test1o1

3 scenarios (3 passed) 3 steps (3 passed) 0m0.118s

Marco polo
2019-08-22 11:42:11

*Thread Reply:* @brasmusson, thank you very much in advance for you assistance

brasmusson
2019-08-22 11:52:29

*Thread Reply:* The pretty formatter prints the scenario outline once and then each row in the example table color coded depending on the result of the execution of the pickle compiled from that example table row. Since it prints the scenario outline only once it cannot de any placeholder expansion there.

Try the summary formatter: -f summary

Marco polo
2019-08-22 11:57:46

*Thread Reply:* ok, that prints it out correctly in the logs, so I used

Marco polo
2019-08-22 11:57:47

*Thread Reply:* cucumber -f summary -f json -o "reports/report.json"

Marco polo
2019-08-22 11:58:45

*Thread Reply:* so the logs in the console are correct, is there something special needed to get that json output to print in that format

brasmusson
2019-08-22 12:12:49

*Thread Reply:* I would say that the json formatter has a bug with respect to the placeholder expansion in v4.0.0.rc.1

Marco polo
2019-08-22 12:15:04

*Thread Reply:* understood

Anthony Chu
2019-08-23 14:09:53

@Anthony Chu has joined the channel

Anthony Chu
2019-08-23 14:23:31

does anyone know if it is possible to query scenarios based on a given tag? i have tried executing --dry-run from the command line and it returns a skipped scenario, but this is not quite what i was trying to get at. is it possible to either retrieve the scenario name(s) or the number of scenarios matching the tag?

brasmusson
2019-08-24 01:52:37

*Thread Reply:* Cucumber-Ruby is not about querying, but about executing feature files making them living documentation. However using --dry-run -f summary --tags &lt;some tagexpression&gt; will get you the names of the test cases that matches the tag expression and in the summary the number of test cases that matches the tag expression

enkessler
2019-08-29 14:58:59

Try CQL. It is all about querying.

https://github.com/enkessler/cql

enkessler/cql
<p>A query language for Gherkin</p>
Stars
<p>15</p>
Language
<p>Ruby</p>
<a href="https://github.com/enkessler/cql">enkessler/cql</a>
Andrew Zah
2019-08-30 18:50:50

@Andrew Zah has joined the channel

Andrew Zah
2019-08-30 18:51:20

hey all, with cucumber ruby and the cli runtime, is it possible to programmatically run it multiple times? I get this issue when I try

Not a recognized gauntlt attack step: \"the output should contain:\"\nCheck available gauntlt steps with this command 'gauntlt --allsteps' (Cucumber::Undefined)\n./attacks/new-test.attack:7:in `Then the output should contain:'

I'm running Cucumber::Cli::Main.new with some adapters from the gauntlt wrapper. It works on the first run, then gives this error on any subsequent runs. is this due to World?

Andrew Zah
2019-08-31 10:53:20

@enkessler

enkessler
2019-09-02 14:43:27

@Andrew Zah I have never had occasion to use Cucumber from somewhere other than the command line. Even if I were to use the CLI object directly from a program, however, I would not do so multiple times from within the same process. As a simple person, I much prefer the certainty of completely unconnected executions which are ignorant of whether they are the 1st run or the 100th run. If the CLI has issues being run more than once, that only reinforces my preference.

In other words: Sorry, I don't know what's wrong. Have you tried having a common parent process kick off a series of child processes that are perhaps parameterized based on the output of the previous child process? What is it that you are trying to achieve?

Andrew Zah
2019-09-03 07:33:32

@enkessler i'm triggering the cucumber files from a rails endpoint. i'd also prefer unrelated executions, so I'm not sure why the namespace and step definitions are sticking around after being called

luke
2019-09-03 07:45:19

I mean if you wanted to run something multiple times on the cli, I'd again defer to some sort of programmatical method. So as you want CLI I'd use bash personally.

luke
2019-10-01 00:55:35

*Thread Reply:* this isn't a cucumber question, it's a selenium question.

luke
2019-10-01 00:56:16

*Thread Reply:* It's likely you've configured your default host either as nil or you've not set it at all.

When using selenium, use driver.get with an absolute url and you're fine.

Thiago Trentin
2019-10-21 07:46:11

Hi All, I'm trying to improve my scenario outlines removing unnecessary columns from my examples used on datatables, so I'd like some tips or ideas for it I have multiple scenarios like this: ``` @test Feature: test

Scenario Outline: Example Given sample step | line1 | <col1> | | line2 | <col2> |

@tag1
Examples:
  | col1 | col2 |
  | ex1  |      |
  | ex2  |      |

@tag2
Examples:
  | col1 | col2 |
  |      | ex1  |
  |      | ex2  |

```I am thinking about to remove this "blank" columns to be easyer to read the gherkin but when I do it the datatable receives a value like this "<col2>" insted of a blank or nil value Have you been in this situation before? what's the best thing to do in this case?

Thiago Trentin
2019-10-22 04:32:17

*Thread Reply:* sent it on #help too

Thiago Trentin
2019-10-22 04:32:29

Thiago Trentin (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/UP7PMJR6X)
<p>Hi All, I'm trying to improve my scenario outlines removing unnecessary columns from my examples used on datatables, so I'd like some tips or ideas for it I have multiple scenarios like this:</p> <pre><code>@test Feature: test Scenario Outline: Example Given sample step | line1 | &amp;lt;col1&amp;gt; | | line2 | &amp;lt;col2&amp;gt; | @tag1 Examples: | col1 | col2 | | ex1 | | | ex2 | | @tag2 Examples: | col1 | col2 | | | ex1 | | | ex2 | </code></pre> <p>I am thinking about to remove this "blank" columns to be easyer to read the gherkin but when I do it the datatable receives a value like this "&lt;col2&gt;" insted of a blank or nil value Have you been in this situation before? what's the best thing to do in this case?</p>
