Nicole
2019-10-24 15:56:28

Hi everyone, I have a question about the "retry" functionality. I've tried to code this on my own but haven't had any luck yet. I want to be able to retry only those scenarios that fail with a certain error rather than ALL of the failures. I tried with an Around hook, but that didn't work (and searching tells me that is due to how the around hook works, which is fine). My thought was to catch it in the after hook, but I'm wondering how I tell the program to retry that particular scenario it just got done running? I was thinking if somehow I could set retry_required to true, it would work, but not sure how to do that. Any thoughts?

enkessler
2019-10-24 16:40:41

If you want to get any degree of fancy, my suggestion is to not use the 'retry' functionality. Add an additional formatter (e.g. JSON), extract the failures that you care about from that output, and then feed those in a file to the next Cucumber run. Or parallelize them or however else you want to run them because, at that point, it's just data and you can play with it however you like.

Richard Lawrence
2019-10-24 16:58:01

@Richard Lawrence has joined the channel

luke
2019-10-25 00:28:56

use the regular rake with --format rerun that's gonna give you the most customisable ability.

luke
2019-10-25 00:29:32

So what you want to do is look at the format for the file that is stored (I believe it's path/filename:filenumber)

luke
2019-10-25 00:29:48

Then manually write that line to a file when your error (ErrorTypeOne) is thrown

Nicole
2019-10-25 07:23:28

Thank you both!

enkessler
2019-10-26 15:56:23

@Nicole You are quite welcome.

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 05:35:59

This may be a bash scripting issue rather than cucumber, but I'll try here anyway. I have a bash script that is taking parameters and generating the right command to run cucumber. The echo'd $CMD at the end looks right, and it works if I run it on the command line by itself, but when executing the command from inside the bash script, it seems to be 'splitting' the -t options (maybe because there are spaces in there?) and the effect of that is it is treating part of the -t option as features. (hope this makes sense - slack isn't the cratest for this sort of complicated formatting!

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 05:36:13

*Thread Reply:* part of the run_cukes.sh script (#!/bin/bash)

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 05:36:49

*Thread Reply:* Running the script

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 05:36:56

luke
2019-11-05 06:11:16

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:11:40

*Thread Reply:* Many thanks! no rush at all ðŸ™‚

luke
2019-11-05 06:13:12

*Thread Reply:* Can you diet down your shell script so what you run is what is echoed (You're passing variables in from multiple places)

Are you escaping your backslashes? On command execution from bash, speechmarks and quotes and special symbols play a bit iffy when it comes to autoexecution.

luke
2019-11-05 06:13:37

*Thread Reply:* also can you remove some of the vars, so we've got say 1/2 vars, makes it easier to triage.

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:20:55

*Thread Reply:* Certainly! stripped right down, this would reproduce the problem for me:

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:21:19

*Thread Reply:*

Untitled
Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:23:14

*Thread Reply:* dang - no - wait - the quites are disappearing- it's going to be escaping issues or something silly

luke
2019-11-05 06:23:38

*Thread Reply:* my gut was it was something like that. I've had issues before with jenkins scripts not quite doing what i expected.

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:30:52

*Thread Reply:* Doh - was simple fix. instead of just $CMD, I needed eval $CMD

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:31:14

*Thread Reply:*

Untitled
Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:31:28

*Thread Reply:* All working now! Thank you for your time!

matt-SmartBear
2019-11-20 04:08:16

*Thread Reply:* \o/

Martin Phillips
2019-11-05 06:36:37

OK, next question. In some of my step implementations I am outputting useful text using 'puts'. Unfortunately, when I run cucumber with formatters the 'puts' stuff all still comes to std_out, which looks really silly on 'progress' formatter. Is it possible to make use of cucumber/ruby's logging to put useful information out to the 'pretty' formatter, but make sure it doesn't go to the 'progress' formatter ?

luke
2019-11-05 07:12:18

right, so with cucumber, you need to be very careful with :puts

luke
2019-11-05 07:12:55

in short, cucumber overloads this method, and returns the same methodology, but at a different time/place. I only half get why.

With the html formatter, I think it looks quite nice. I know with the progress formatter it appears at an odd time.

luke
2019-11-05 07:13:12

My advice to anyone doing anything with cucumber/selenium ruby, is use your own custom logger.

luke
2019-11-05 07:13:38

Create an instance or eigenclass that subclasses ::Logger and for each time you want some info, fire it there.

luke
2019-11-05 07:14:04

you could even make them output to two diff locations e.t.c.

I'd really get some buy in on logging and spend a good few days getting it right, it'll save you time in the long run.

phebus
2019-11-05 07:17:23

i use Kernel.puts if i want to bypass the weirdness of cukeâ€™s puts

luke
2020-01-07 00:24:08

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#added-1 - there's a better auto-loader that has now been released, and a blog post is pending for it (Once we release v4 properly it'll be released, as it needs some small tweaks / cleanups)

CHANGELOG.md
<p>```</p> <h1>CHANGE LOG</h1> <p>All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.</p> <p>This project adheres to <a href="http://semver.org">Semantic Versioning</a>.</p> <p>This document is formatted according to the principles of <a href="http://keepachangelog.com">Keep A CHANGELOG</a>.</p> <p>Please visit <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">cucumber/CONTRIBUTING.md</a> for more info on how to contribute to Cucumber.</p> <hr /> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.3...master">In Git</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.2...v4.0.0.rc.3">4.0.0.rc.3</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Update to cucumber-wire 1.1.</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.1...v4.0.0.rc.2">4.0.0.rc.2</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* There is a new methodology in Cucumber for how the auto-loader works *</em> The old <code>load</code> behaviour is now replaced with a newer <code>require</code> behaviour <em>* Cucumber will (From version 4), now auto-load files using the <code>require</code> method *</em> If you wish to alter this, then you can set a top level config option: <code>Cucumber.use_legacy_autoloader</code> <em>* Like most config options, setting this inside a <code>spec_helper.rb</code> or <code>env.rb</code> file is advised *</em> For more information on this change, including why it was made. Please read this <a href="a href=&quot;http://www.google.com&quot;&gt;www.google.com&lt;/a">Blog Post</a> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349">#1349</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Going forward the minimum ruby version for all cucumber based gems is 2.3 (<a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** Removed Travis publish job for cucumber-pro(a.k.a. jam) (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1350">#1350</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <p>** Drop support for JRuby. We may add this back if new versions of protobuf for JRuby start working, or if someone can make the build pass with an older version. All this means is we're ok to make releases while the jruby CI job is failing.</p> <p>(<a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">aslakhellesoy</a>)</p> <p>** Remove <code>dots-formatter introduced in</code>4.0.0rc1`</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Fix the placeholder expansions in the json formatter (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1361">#1361</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Fix seed printed in cucumber UI to match the seed that was actually used. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1329">#1329</a> <a href="https://github.com/deivid-rodriguez">deivid-rodriguez</a>) ** Make SIGINT/<code>Ctrl+c</code> behavior consistent with SIGTERM/<code>kill</code> behavior - now first invocation causes existing scenario to stop running and jump to <code>at_exit</code>, second invocation causes immediate exit. Before that first invocation only instructed Cucumber to exit after scenario and second invocation caused immediate exit skipping <code>at_exit</code>. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1353">#1353</a> <a href="https://github.com/akostadinov">akostadinov</a>)</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Filter out any lines containing <code>site_ruby</code> from stacktrace</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v3.1.2...v4.0.0.rc.1">4.0.0.rc.1</a> (2018-09-29)</h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Added support for new <code>Rule</code> keyword. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/CHANGELOG.md#6013---2018-09-25">Read more here.</a> *</em> Added new <code>dots</code> formatter. This is the first step of a larger strategy to move the formatters to a new architecture where they delegate to shared executables via messages.</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p><em>* Use Gherkin v6. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1313">#1313</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Do not apply Before and After Hooks to Test Cases with no Test Steps. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1311">#1311</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Pass the registry to the Wire plugin. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Adapt to using the Gherkin compiler and Pickles in the core. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Let the Pretty Formatter use events. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1305">#1305</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Use single quotes in generated template steps (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1323">#1323</a> <a href="https://github.com/acant">acant</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p><em>* Remove the support of old style tag expressions. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1314">#1314</a>, <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Remove the Legacy API for Formatters. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1230">#1230</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/839">#839</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Remove the JSON Pretty Formatter (which was the same as the JSON formatter). (<a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Remove the HTML Formatter. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1306">#1306</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>)</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Wire protocol compatibility for docstrings. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1183">#1183</a>) *</em> Let the Rerun Formatter handle flaky scenarios. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1310">#1310</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>)</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Code style changes completed as per backlog of Rubocop TODO file. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1021">#1021</a> <a href="https://github.com/jaysonesmith">@jaysonesmith</a>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v3.1.1...v3.1.2">3.1.2</a> (2018-07-13)</h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p><em>* Upgraded to <code>cucumber-core</code> 3.2.0 *</em> Change to use the gherkin step location in the Json formatter. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1243">#1243</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1108">#1108</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>)</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p>** Support ParameterType with empty capture group. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/404">#404</a> <a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">aslakhellesoy</a>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v3.1.0...v3.1.1">3.1.1</a> (2018-06-03)</h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p><em>* Add Rubocop to default Rake task (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1256">#1256</a> <a href="https://github.com/jaysonesmith">@jaysonesmith</a>) *</em> Upgraded <code>cucumber-expressions</code> dependency to ~&gt; 6.0.0 (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1299">#1299</a> <a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">@aslakhellesoy</a>) ** Upgraded to <code>gherkin</code> 5.1.0 (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1299">#1299</a> <a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">@aslakhellesoy</a>)</p> <h3>Deprecated</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Make <code>--fail-fast</code> play nice with <code>--retry</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1283">#1283</a> <a href="https://github.com/yrral86">@yrral86</a>) *</em> Fix incompatible encodings error in JUnit formatter (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1244">#1244</a> <a href="https://github.com/NickAb">@NickAb</a>) (except on JRuby, see <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1259">#1259</a>) <em>* Fix the handling of failed hooks in the JUnit Formatter (<a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">@brasmusson</a>) *</em> Fixed lengthy stacktrace when running <code>cucumber -f stepdefs</code> when steps aren't defined. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1286">#1286</a> <a href="https://github.com/xtrasimplicity">@xtrasimplicity</a>) ** Fixed an error with HTML snippet generation when <code>frozen_string_literal</code> is enabled and the <code>Syntax</code> gem is not installed. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1287">#1287</a> <a href="https://github.com/xtrasimplicity">@xtrasimplicity</a>â€¦</p>

Thomas Stuttard
2020-01-29 09:02:25

@Thomas Stuttard has joined the channel

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 07:27:42

Hi all, I'm trying to make a step definition in ruby a bit more flexible. At present we have:

When /^I do something with description:$/ do |description| ... end

This matches the feature file content:

When I do something with description: """ my text over multiple lines """

For occasions where the text is short, I'd love to be able to express it in the feature file as follows

When I do something with description "my text"

Does anyone know how I could modify the step in ruby to allow the same step definition to service both feature file statements?

luke
2020-01-30 07:31:02

So what you've got here is 2 different requirements, and as such, should probably use 2 different steps.

luke
2020-01-30 07:31:36

the triple quote, is known as a doc-string. And comes from internals within cucumber designed for working with large documents. For instance in aruba (a offshoot cucumber gem), we use docstrings that are sometimes 20 lines long

luke
2020-01-30 07:32:28

now what cucumber will also do, is allow your arity of the regex to be 1 less than the desired block params, if you have a : at the end and then your docstring.

phebus
2020-01-30 07:42:50

+1 on redundancy over complexity

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 07:47:31

okey dokey - thanks guys

luke
2020-01-30 08:12:16

For the 2nd one, I didn't mention, but if it's on one line just capture using {string} or write a custom parameter type

Marco Sanabria
2020-01-30 08:13:39

*Thread Reply:* Correct, that would be with cucumber expressions, and I see Martin is using regex

Marco Sanabria
2020-01-30 08:13:54

*Thread Reply:* he would need to switch

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:20:21

*Thread Reply:* We generally use regex's because they are a lot more powerful

luke
2020-01-30 08:21:35

*Thread Reply:* You know that at runtime cuke-exp is converted right. So the idea behind cuke-exp is just to give you more flexibility for less code.

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:21:45

*Thread Reply:* I've ended up pulling the content of the step out into it's own method, and then defining 2 steps that are almost, but not quite identical, that call the new method

luke
2020-01-30 08:21:51

*Thread Reply:* It also allows you to do common captures a lot easier in the step code.

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:21:54

*Thread Reply:* When /^I (shelve|submit) a? files? "([^"]**)"(?:| as user "([^"]**)") with change description:$/ do |command, files, user, description| shelve_submit_files(command, files, user, description) end When /^I (shelve|submit) a? files? "([^"]**)"(?:| as user "([^"]**)") with change description:? "([^"]**)"$/ do |command, files, user, description| shelve_submit_files(command, files, user, description) end

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:23:03

*Thread Reply:* We are porting behat (php cucumber) to ruby because behat/mink is so badly supported (can't test any new browsers)

luke
2020-01-30 08:23:46

*Thread Reply:* I know Behat is under active development at the moment with regards to the new gherkin support. @ciaranmcnulty is one of the main guys on it.

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:23:53

*Thread Reply:* but behat did seem to support regular expressions much betetr

ciaranmcnulty
2020-01-30 08:24:23

*Thread Reply:* Active is overstating it

ciaranmcnulty
2020-01-30 08:24:54

*Thread Reply:* 'can't test any new browser' - I'm not going to try and lure you back, but which?

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:25:34

*Thread Reply:* Well, at present our behats only work with an ancient firefox. The business wants us testing with Edge, firefox and Chrome

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:26:20

*Thread Reply:* and there seemed so little activity on Behat that we decided to jump ship - it's a huge cost to us as we are migrating nearly 1000 tests from php to ruby

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:27:02

*Thread Reply:* (huge cost = 4-6 months work of work for our test team, full time)

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:27:11

*Thread Reply:* (there are only 3 of us!)

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:28:00

*Thread Reply:* how soon do you expect to have behat/mink up and going with modern browsers? Is it worth us stopping this port?

luke
2020-01-30 08:28:02

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-01-30 08:29:34

*Thread Reply:* That cost shouldnâ€™t come as a surprise though. There is significant risk in depending on an open source project without any financial backing. Maintainers can jump ship at any time.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-01-30 08:31:27

*Thread Reply:* The only way to reduce that risk is to offer financial support to the contributors.

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:32:01

*Thread Reply:* Absolutely! any moving to ruby (as it seems to be more updated/active) seemed like a snesible option for us

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:32:30

*Thread Reply:* that is also true - I'll see what i can do to encourage management to donate, but they are tight buggers!

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-01-30 08:33:01

*Thread Reply:* Tight buggers with an appetite for high risk investments ðŸ™‚

luke
2020-01-30 08:33:07

*Thread Reply:* Whilst I don't want to get drawn into a big language A vs language B debate. I think one area ruby does better than most/all is in open source. I'm not sure what you're testing (API's / websites / something else), but the support for testing / documenting using ruby gems is quite extensive, compared to a lot of other languages.

Obviously there are drawbacks too. But I'm biased ðŸ¤·

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-01-30 08:33:43

*Thread Reply:* Itâ€™s almost always best to write tests in the same language as the system under test.

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:34:08

*Thread Reply:* definitely - and the product was php

luke
2020-01-30 08:36:24

Martin Phillips

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-01-30 08:37:33

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:37:54

*Thread Reply:* it's a really interesting thing with all these open source frameworks - they are 'free', so no company produces a paid for one that's properly supported, so there is no alternative to the open source

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:37:57

*Thread Reply:* 2 edged sword

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:38:15

*Thread Reply:* I love a good discussion ðŸ™‚

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:39:28

*Thread Reply:* In the discussions I've heard from Development about which framework to use, the amount of activity is definitely a major factor in the choice

Martin Phillips
2020-01-30 08:40:19

*Thread Reply:* We in QA seem to have much less choice - there are fewer test frameworks than development ones, and they all seem to be significantly less funded/resourced

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-01-30 08:40:19

*Thread Reply:* Well - Cucumber has financial backing. Two people are paid to work on it full time, and one part time. Plus our open collective to support more occasional contributors. That reduces the risk for users.

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-03 14:01:05

@Martin Phillips you can also delegate directly to the method by passing a symbol to the step definition instead of a block:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/features/docs/defining_steps/one_line_step_definitions.feature

features/docs/defining_steps/one_line_step_definitions.feature
<pre><code>Feature: One line step definitions Everybody knows you can do step definitions in Cucumber but did you know you can do this? Scenario: Call a method in World directly from a step def Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ module Driver def do_action @done = true end def assert_done expect(@done).to be true end end World(Driver) When /I do the action/, :do_action Then /The action should be done/, :assert_done """ And a file named "features/action.feature" with: """ Feature: Scenario: When I do the action Then the action should be done """ When I run `cucumber` Then it should pass Scenario: Call a method on an actor in the World directly from a step def Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ class Thing def do_action @done = true end def assert_done expect(@done).to be true end end module Driver def thing @thing ||= Thing.new end end World(Driver) When /I do the action to the thing/, :do_action, :on =&amp;gt; lambda { thing } Then /The thing should be done/, :assert_done, :on =&amp;gt; lambda { thing } """ And a file named "features/action.feature" with: """ Feature: Scenario: When I do the action to the thing Then the thing should be done """ When I run `cucumber` Then it should pass </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Martin Phillips
2020-02-04 09:03:12

*Thread Reply:* That looks truly horrendous! ðŸ™‚

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-05 06:42:50

Martin Phillips
2020-02-05 06:43:37

Martin Phillips
2020-02-05 06:44:13

*Thread Reply:* (at least, that's my understanding of the intended architecture)

Martin Phillips
2020-02-05 06:47:30

*Thread Reply:* Not saying it isn't cool and technically great - but i'd throw a fit if my testers put that in without an exceedingly good reason. ðŸ™‚

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-06 03:08:22

*Thread Reply:* You misunderstand ðŸ™‚

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-06 03:08:48

*Thread Reply:* itâ€™s a way to write your step defs so they donâ€™t have any code in the block - just a symbol that maps to a method on the World

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-06 03:08:57

*Thread Reply:* doesnâ€™t change your features

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-06 03:09:08

*Thread Reply:* What I linked to is the acceptance test for this feature within Cucumber itself.

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-06 03:09:14

*Thread Reply:* Itâ€™s an example of how to use it.

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-06 03:09:40

*Thread Reply:* Hereâ€™s what youâ€™d put in your step defs: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/features/docs/defining_steps/one_line_step_definitions.feature#L20

features/docs/defining_steps/one_line_step_definitions.feature:20
<pre><code> When /I do the action/, :do_action </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-17 09:39:45

*Thread Reply:* I think itâ€™s just the method name you can pass

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-17 09:40:19

*Thread Reply:* but e.g. if you captured â€œActionâ€ that could be a parameter to the assert_done method

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-17 09:40:52

*Thread Reply:* itâ€™s designed to solve the problem of people writing too much crap inline in their step def blocks, instead of refactoring it into helper methods.

Hello. I'm trying to build a relatively simple Sinatra app that demonstrates some of cuke's features. Or is there a way to get cucumber to launch a SUT version of the app itself?

enkessler
2020-02-05 12:21:22

Starting the app just once but getting a fresh browser instance for each test is a pretty common pattern, yes. Both could be done as hooks.

luke
2020-02-11 07:10:14

what are you looking to achieve? I.e. what is the problem you're looking to overcome.

Cucumber stores all failures after a feature run / execution run and displays them back to the user.

Fabricio Bedin
2020-02-11 08:22:51

*Thread Reply:* If I execute cucumber without aggregatefailures, I'll see the line where the expect failed. But, when I execute with aggregatefailures I just see the line where aggregate_failures is located, and not the lines of the expects.

Looking at the documentation, it should show the lines of the failures too. https://relishapp.com/rspec/rspec-core/docs/expectation-framework-integration/aggregating-failures

luke
2020-02-11 08:26:22

*Thread Reply:* are you wrapping the aggregate failures in a block in your step?

Fabricio Bedin
2020-02-11 08:52:29

*Thread Reply:* yes.. my code is like this example ```35. Then ... do

  1. aggregate_failures do
  2. expect ...
  3. expect ...
  4. expect ...
  5. end
  6. end``` when I execute, it should return error on lines 37, 38 and 39. But, I'm only seeing the error on line 36. ( RSpec::Expectations::MultipleExpectationsNotMetError )
luke
2020-02-11 08:56:40

*Thread Reply:* ah hang on though. The error code suggests something is working correctly.

luke
2020-02-11 08:57:19

*Thread Reply:* I would also open an issue on rspec/expectations. This may be cross-compatibility between the 2, or it could directly be cucumber. But it's not completely broken.

Fabricio Bedin
2020-02-11 09:08:56

*Thread Reply:* yeah, it's working partially. I saw a strange thing that I didn't understand, the method aggregate_failures is in RSpec Core and RSpec Expectations and has different behavior. Do you know why?

https://relishapp.com/rspec/rspec-expectations/docs/aggregating-failures

https://relishapp.com/rspec/rspec-core/v/3-9/docs/expectation-framework-integration/aggregating-failures

I think the problem is because my code is getting the aggregate_failures from RSpec Expectations and not from RSpec Core. Do you know how can I execute this method from RSpec Core?

Thank you a lot for your help ðŸ™‚

luke
2020-02-11 09:10:30

*Thread Reply:* I've never used this method before, But I know a reasonable amount of the cucumber-ruby area as I am doing a bit of stuff on it atm.

Cucumber captures all failures and then defers them to a later time. It might be that we're assuming this error looks a certain way and for aggregate failures it looks different to how we expect. But again I'm not sure.

2020-02-11 09:16:58

Jonah
2020-02-28 13:14:06

My custom ParameterTypes are not transforming the content of DocStrings. Are they supposed to? Is there a way to make them too? If not, what is the preferred approach?

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-02-28 16:50:11

Hi @Jonah - parameter types are picked based on the name of the parameter in the cucumber expression. Since DocStrings donâ€™t have a name, Cucumber has no way to pick the right parameter type.

Here is an idea: We could change Cucumber to look it up using a custom media type?

LHR

or, more rigourous, but also more verbose: text/x.cucumber.parameter.airport+plain LHR What do you think @mpkorstanje @Vincent Pretre?

@Jonah in the meanwhile you can extract the transform block to a separate declaration and use it from both your parameter type definition and your step definition.

mpkorstanje
2020-02-28 18:56:04

*Thread Reply:* I'd make it a separate doc string type like I did in Cucumber jvm. Doc strings don't have a regex to match and the transformers for parametertypes assumes that their input matches a certain regex

mpkorstanje
2020-02-28 18:56:34

*Thread Reply:* Fewer edge cases to worry about and explain that way.

Jonah
2020-03-01 17:36:40

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak HellesÃ¸y > in the meanwhile you can extract the transform block to a separate declaration and use it from both your parameter type definition and your step definition. Thanks, this is exactly the path I took, but I felt like I was â€œdoing it wrong.â€ If thatâ€™s the intended design, though, thatâ€™s fine and Iâ€™ll take this path.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-03-02 03:52:09

*Thread Reply:* @mpkorstanje what do you think about my suggestion to look up a parameter type using a DocStringâ€™s media type following the ```

2020-02-28 18:54:41

Nicoleta Cajvan
2020-04-28 04:56:41

*Thread Reply:* Not sure if this is what you're looking for, but I managed to use diff parameter_types in the same step: When("I fill in the {string} and {int} fields") do |user,pass| fill_in 'email', with: "#{user}" fill_in 'password', with: pass end

Julius Titiloye
2020-05-30 07:44:45

@Julius Titiloye has joined the channel

enkessler
2020-06-01 05:30:43

Ponder of the day: what does one do when one uses Cucumber to test their project but their project relies on dependencies for which their is no version of Cucumber which is compatible?

To be a little more specific: I have a project that relies on the gem for Gherkin and Cucumber relies on that same gem. Gherkin 2-9 all had a corresponding version of Cucumber that could use them** but some newer versions of Gherkin have no Cucumber release that uses them. Although I am almost fully confident in the accompanying RSpec suite for the project (I've been in QA too long for me to be 100% confident in anything), I was rather hoping that my executable documentation could remain...executable.

**Strictly speaking, Gherkin 7 and 9 did not have a Cucumber version that used them but some witchery or other was allowing Cucumber to get by by using the old gherkin3 gem without conflicting with the also loaded gherkin gem.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-01 06:26:43

*Thread Reply:* Bootstrapping problems.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-01 06:28:26

*Thread Reply:* I'd ignore the unused gems.

enkessler
2020-06-01 13:18:03

*Thread Reply:* The problem is not that dependencies are unused. The problem is that there are two separate libraries (the one being the project that is being tested and the other being Cucumber, which is doing the testing) that insist on the same dependency but want different versions of it.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-01 13:38:38

*Thread Reply:* Owh. Are you testing a range versions?

enkessler
2020-06-01 13:42:51

*Thread Reply:* Even with ranges, their respective ranges do not have any overlap.

enkessler
2020-06-01 13:44:42

*Thread Reply:* There exist versions of Gherkin (which my gem supports, and therefore must be tested against, every major version thereof) for which there exists no version of Cucumber capable of using it.

enkessler
2020-06-01 13:45:42

*Thread Reply:* It is those 'missing' versions of Cucumber that are my dilemma.

enkessler
2020-06-01 13:54:24

*Thread Reply:* For example: cucumber jumps from using cucumber-gherkin 10.x to 13.x. So when I need to test my project against cucumber-gherkin 11.x or 12.x, I won't be able to run my Cucumber tests because Cucumber will insist on a different version of that dependency.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-01 14:56:42

*Thread Reply:* Aah. I would skip those versions. I doubt they'll be used much.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-01 14:57:24

*Thread Reply:* Currently Gherkin depends on messages. And messages goes through a large number of major updates.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-01 14:57:57

*Thread Reply:* As a result Gherkin also gets major updates with little actual changes.

enkessler
2020-06-01 14:58:36

*Thread Reply:* And cucumber can't be bothered to not force upgrades on its users?

enkessler
2020-06-01 14:59:34

*Thread Reply:* If the changes are so minor, then surely cucumber could support multiple versions at the same time.

enkessler
2020-06-01 15:09:31

*Thread Reply:* On the one hand, the rapid 'releases' of cucumber are all release candidates and so not the final, official release of the next major version of the library. In that light, it could be given a little more leeway in changing things up because it's not officially stable yet.

On the other hand, that same reasoning means that the last official and 'stable' release of cucumber is several years ago and 8 major versions of Gherkin behind the current version. In that light, my problem is highlighted even more because that would mean that I wouldn't be able to run any of my high level specifications for the majority of the versions of the very dependency that I claim my tool supports.

slackbot
2020-06-01 05:30:44

Did you know Cucumber is a specification tool, not a testing tool?

enkessler
2020-06-01 05:36:35

I did know that, Slackbot. You foolish mortal, you. In a sense, however, a side effect of a specification being executable is that it is, by the very act of it being executed, also being tested. Cucumber is a tool that has many uses and testing is among them. In your defense, though, there are enough users out there who will use a hammer to pound in a screw that your unsolicited advice is likely to be applicable more often than not.

ðŸ’¯ Dana Scheider (they/he), Matthias Carell
ðŸ˜‚ Jo Laing
MarkSweetlove
2020-06-05 14:42:50

Not entirely sure how to ask this question, butâ€¦ iâ€™d like to use embed to add screenshots from somewhere other than in the hooks. Iâ€™m extending the Cucumber::Glue::Dsl and then calling stuff in other modules and iâ€™d like to add screenshots to all formatters from there. Is that possible?

luke
2020-06-08 01:29:36

In Ruby theoretically anything is possible. ðŸ˜„ But yes this new embed functionality Vincent has been working a lot on, and I know the idea was to get the new formatters to be as extensible as possible.

MarkSweetlove
2020-06-08 15:54:44

Iâ€™m happy in theory then ðŸ˜„ Any idea how i can get the instances of the formatters to call embed on them?

luke
2020-06-09 01:08:36

SO embed should be directly available as a method inside the cucumber world. Typically used inside before/after hooks.

luke
2020-06-09 01:08:45

But I've not used the new formatter. I'm still using cucumber3 regualrly.

mlvandijk
2020-06-09 04:12:05

@mlvandijk has left the channel

MarkSweetlove
2020-06-09 05:24:33

I donâ€™t think iâ€™m explaining what iâ€™m doing very well ðŸ˜„ I am using Cucumber 3 and i want to access embed outside of the hooks. module MyModule module Hooks extend(Cucumber::Glue::Dsl) After do |scenario| Core.after_scenario(scenario) end end end Then i want to do stuff with the formatters, like embed an image from inside MyModule::Core: module MyModule module Core class &lt;&lt; self def after_scenario(scenario) embed(some_file, 'image/png', 'View') end end end end embed wonâ€™t work here. How do i get it to? ðŸ˜„

luke
2020-06-09 05:38:00

right so as mentioned I believe embed is accessible inside the cucumber world. Which consists of the step definitions, as well as the hooks construct at the point of execution.

luke
2020-06-09 05:38:18

so why don't you just pause execution at any time then, and check to see if you can use embed?

phebus
2020-06-09 07:47:40

did ruby cucumber 4 intentionally remove the auto-require of everything under the support dir?

tooky
2020-06-10 01:21:28

*Thread Reply:* @phebus I wonder if its related to this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#added-3

cc @Vincent Pretre

CHANGELOG.md
<p>```</p> <h1>CHANGE LOG</h1> <p>All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.</p> <p>This project adheres to <a href="http://semver.org">Semantic Versioning</a>.</p> <p>This document is formatted according to the principles of <a href="http://keepachangelog.com">Keep A CHANGELOG</a>.</p> <p>Please visit <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">cucumber/CONTRIBUTING.md</a> for more info on how to contribute to Cucumber.</p> <hr /> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0...master">In GIT</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.5...v4.0.0">4.0.0</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** <code>log</code> method can now be called with non-string objects and will run <code>.to_s</code> on them. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1410">#1410</a></p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Display snippet when using undefined parameter type <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1411">#1411</a></p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.5...4.0.0.rc.6">4.0.0.rc.6</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Code snippet for an undefined step with a Doc String will ouput <code>doc_string</code> instead of <code>string</code> in block params (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1401">#1401</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1402">#1402</a> <a href="https://github.com/karamosky">karamosky</a>)</p> <p>** Updated monorepo libraries:</p><ul><li>cucumber-gherkin ~&gt; 13</li><li>cucumber-html-formatter ~&gt; 6</li><li>cucumber-cucumber-expressions ~&gt; 10</li> </ul> <p>** Use <code>cucumber-ruby-core</code> 7.0.0</p> <p>** Use <code>cucumber-ruby-wire</code> 3.0.0</p> <p>** Use <code>body</code> field of attachments</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p><em>* <code>--out url</code> updates: *</em> supports redirects <em>* use <code>PUT</code> method by default *</em> use a cURL like options (for example: <code>cucumber --out '&lt;http://example.com&gt; -X POST -H Content-Type: json</code>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.4...4.0.0.rc.5">4.0.0.rc.5</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** New html formatter enabled by option <code>--format html --out report.html</code>.</p> <p>** Accept <code>--out URL</code> to POST results to a web server If a URL is used as output, the output will be sent with a POST request. This can be overridden by specifying e.g. <code>http-method=PUT</code> as a query parameter. Other <code>http-</code> prefixed query parameters will be converted to request headers (with the <code>http-</code> prefix stripped off).</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.3...4.0.0.rc.4">4.0.0.rc.4</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Add <code>message</code>formatter which produces <code>Cucumber::Messages</code> ndjson output. *</em> Comply with [<code>cucumber-compatibility-kit](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/compatibility-kit&gt;) ** Methods</code>log<code>and</code>attach` can be used in step definitions to attach text or images</p> <h3>Deprecated</h3> <p><em>* <code>--format=json</code> in favor of the <code>message</code> formatter and the stand-alone JSON formatter *</em> <code>puts</code> in step definitions in favor of <code>log</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/897">cucumber#897</a>) ** <code>embed</code> in step definitions in favor of <code>attach</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/897">cucumber#897</a>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.2...v4.0.0.rc.3">4.0.0.rc.3</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Update to cucumber-wire 1.1.</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.1...v4.0.0.rc.2">4.0.0.rc.2</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* There is a new methodology in Cucumber for how the auto-loader works *</em> The old <code>load</code> behaviour is now replaced with a newer <code>require</code> behaviour <em>* Cucumber will (From version 4), now auto-load files using the <code>require</code> method *</em> If you wish to alter this, then you can set a top level config option: <code>Cucumber.use_legacy_autoloader</code> <em>* Like most config options, setting this inside a <code>spec_helper.rb</code> or <code>env.rb</code> file is advised *</em> For more information on this change, including why it was made. Please read this <a href="a href=&quot;http://www.google.com&quot;&gt;www.google.com&lt;/a">Blog Post</a> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349">#1349</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Going forward the minimum ruby version for all cucumber based gems is 2.3 (<a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** Removed Travis publish job for cucumber-pro(a.k.a. jam) (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1350">#1350</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <p>** Drop support for JRuby. We may add this back if new versions of protobuf for JRuby start working, or if someone can make the build pass with an older version. All this means is we're ok to make releases while the jruby CI job is failing.</p> <p>(<a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">aslakhellesoy</a>)</p> <p>** Remove <code>dots-formatter introduced in</code>4.0.0rc1`</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Fix the placeholder expansions in the json formatter (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1361">#1361</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Fix seed printed in cucumber UI to match the seed that was actually used. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1329">#1329</a> <a href="https://github.com/deivid-rodriguez">deivid-rodriguez</a>) ** Make SIGINT/<code>Ctrl+c</code> behavior consistent with SIGTERM/<code>kill</code> behavior - now first invocation causes existing scenario to stop running and jump to <code>at_exit</code>, second invocation causes immediate exit. Before that first invocation only instructed Cucumber to exit after scenario and second invocation caused immediate exit skipping <code>at_exit</code>. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1353">#1353</a> <a href="https://github.com/akostadinov">akostadinov</a>)</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Filter out any lines containing <code>site_ruby</code> from stacktrace</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v3.1.2...v4.0.0.rc.1">4.0.0.rc.1</a> (2018-09-29)</h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Added support for new <code>Rule</code> keyword. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/CHANGELOG.md#6013---2018-09-25">Read more here.</a> *</em> Added new <code>dots</code> formatter. This is the first step of a larger strategy to move the formatters to a new architecture where they delegate to shared executables via messages.</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p><em>* Use Gherkin v6. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1313">#1313</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Do not apply Before and After Hooks to Test Cases with no Test Steps. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1311">#1311</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Pass the registry to the Wire plugin. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Adapt to using the Gherkin compiler and Pickles in the core. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Let the Pretty Formatter use events. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1305">#1305</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Use single quotes in generated template steps (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1323">#1323</a> <a href="https://github.com/acant">acant</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p><em>* Remove the support of old style tag expressions. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1314">#1314</a>, <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Remove the Legacy API for Formatters. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1230">#1230</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/839">#839</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Remove the JSON Pretty Formatter (which was the same as the JSON formatter). (<a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Remove the HTML Formatter. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1306">#1306</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>)</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Wire protocol compatibility for docstrings. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1183">#1183</a>) *</em> Let the Rerun Formatter handle flaky scenarios. ([#1310](<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumbeâ€¦</p>

*Thread Reply:* ok so something weird is happening and not sure why. maybe i was taking advantage of things in the wrong way previously, and now with this change itâ€™s been exposed. so it appears that even after putting Cucumber.use_legacy_autoloader = true at the top of my env.rb it is loading the files in reverse order? so while i was taking advantage of thing going alphabetically before (as a lot of people seem to do with using _ or 00 prefixes on file names, itâ€™s going in reverse so things are complaining about not knowing classes etc. iâ€™ve stepped through this with current 3 and 4 and i can see in 3 it starts with env.rb and then goes through the rest alphabetically. with 4, it starts with env.rb and then starts from the bottom

does this make any sense?

luke
2020-06-11 00:52:41

*Thread Reply:* so alphabetically was never exactly the case. And some rework to the "order" of files was done as a bugfix late in the 3.x series.

So it always loads env.rb then other env.rb then it just uses the Dir mechanic, which is a ruby mechanic.

luke
2020-06-11 00:54:10

*Thread Reply:* So if you set use_legacy_autoloader to true. Then nothing is changed from the code I wrote.

luke
2020-06-11 00:58:07

*Thread Reply:* This is likely the issue - https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1343

fourpastmidnight (https://github.com/fourpastmidnight)
#1343 Fixes env.rb and support files load order
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Fixes the load order of <code>env.rb</code> files</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>According to The Cucumber Book on pp. 129-130:</p> <p>&gt; Just like <code>features/step_definitions</code>, Cucumber will load all Ruby files it finds in <code>features/support</code>. This is convenient, because it means you don't need to pepper <code>require</code> statements everywhere, but it does mean that the precise order in which files are loaded is hard to control. In practice, this means you can't have dependencies between files in the <code>support</code> directory, because you can't expect that another file will have already been loaded. There is one exception to that, a special file called <code>env.rb</code>. &gt; &gt; The file <code>features/support/env.rb</code> is always the very first file to be loaded when Cucumber starts a test run.</p> <p>This is also extened such that any <code>env.rb</code> file located in descendant <code>support</code> folders are <em>also</em> loaded before other <code>**.rb</code> files in <code>support</code> folders.</p> <p>However, when attempting to create a better port of Cucumber in the Pester PowerShell testing framework, I found this load ordering to not be correct.</p> <p>This commit fixes the order in which files in <code>support</code> folders are loaded so that:</p> <ol><li>the <code>features/support/env.rb</code> file is always loaded first, if found</li><li>other <code>env.rb</code> files located in descendent <code>support</code> folders under <code>features</code> are loaded second</li><li>all other <code>**.rb</code> files in descendant <code>support</code> folders are loaded</li> </ol> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>For one, the most authoritative, canonical reference, <em>The Cucumber Book</em> states that this is how Cucumber behaves. But in addition to that, the book states a very good reason for this behavior: in order to help control the load order of files (through the use of <code>require</code>).</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>A new unit test has been added to ensure that <code>env.rb</code> files are loaded in the correct order.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>â˜ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) â˜ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) â˜ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) â˜ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p>I'm actually not sure if this should be categorized as a breaking or non-breaking change. Changing the load order of files could potentially break tests which depend on the current behavior. The question is, how many tests would be written to depend on the load order, since that would in most cases, be a bad idea. It's probably best to label this as a breaking changeâ€”but ultimately, I'll leave this decision up to the maintainers.</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>â˜‘ï¸Ž I've added tests for my code â˜ My change requires a change to the documentation. â˜ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>

*Thread Reply:* this was something that also went in recently.

2020-06-11 00:59:23

*Thread Reply:* I bet that's the issue as the #reverse code will show. The test there was written to show different levels of nesting of env.rb files, but perhaps we need an additional spec or tweak.

luke
2020-06-11 01:01:09

*Thread Reply:* And co-incidentally, it was released in the same cucumber version (4.rc2), and there's no changelog entry. So well done for making me dig into this @phebus

2020-06-11 05:47:21

luke
2020-06-12 08:33:03

*Thread Reply:* No probs, I worked a lot on this, and I remember the other PR a lot. By pure co-incidence were both released inside the same rc

luke
2020-06-12 08:33:50

*Thread Reply:* As for "should" it go in reverse. I mean, I'm happy to revert back to going alphabetically.... However, we also need the "fix" the OP did, which was alphabetically is not the designed way (purely), but env.rb names must always go first.

phebus
2020-06-12 09:42:35

*Thread Reply:* iâ€™m totally willing to change my setup to accommodate, but iâ€™m not sure i understand how outside of adding a bunch of requires that are unfortunately the last thing i want to do. i guess i could add my own mass recursive require in env.rb but that kind of defeats the purpose

phebus
2020-08-19 12:24:46

*Thread Reply:* hey @luke, was wondering if we could revisit this. if use_legacy_autoloader isnâ€™t working for me is there something iâ€™m doing wrong or was i just taking advantage of something that only happened to work but wasnâ€™t meant to (that of requiring everything under support without needing to explicitly do so unless it was not in order). should i just do a custom recursive require?

luke
2020-08-20 00:25:03

*Thread Reply:* so the issue is actually 2fold. In 4.0.0.rc2-3 two things changed, but one of them wasn't documented.

I've been meaning to do a bug fix into this, but it's taken me ages to work out exactly what needs to change. I will get to it though.

For now though when you use the new autoloader, you shouldn't require on the load-order (You never should have). So you shouldn't need recursive requires, just explicit ones for files needed first (Modules e.t.c.).

phebus
2020-08-20 05:58:41

*Thread Reply:* is there an issue open? should i open one? mostly just want something to follow for when thereâ€™s a fix. thanks again, iâ€™ll update my classes and methods with explicit requires

luke

luke
2020-08-20 06:31:44

*Thread Reply:* I appreciate it's bus factor heavy.

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:16:25

Are encodings handled differently in the newer versions of Gherkin? I've got a feature file that fails to parse due to encoding issues but the file, platform, etc. remain unchanged from before when it worked fine except for the fact that I've switched from gherkin to cucumber-gherkin.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:25:29

*Thread Reply:* What is the encoding issue?

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:36:16

*Thread Reply:* As far as I know gherkin only supports UFT8

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:36:27

*Thread Reply:* Cucumber JVM had a little hack that allowed magic comments to be used

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:36:36

*Thread Reply:* Encoding::CompatibilityError - incompatible encoding regexp match (UTF-8 regexp with IBM437 string)

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:37:15

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, and UTF-8 is all that I ever use too and more or less assume that that's what is being used unless told otherwise but apparently that's not the case.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:37:38

*Thread Reply:* Anyway to check the encoding?

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:39:40

*Thread Reply:* I've opened it in a couple editors and it says that it's UTF-8. I've even converted it to something else and back again the file isn't marked as changed in source control, so presumably it was originally in UTF-8. When I have Ruby explicitly force it to be read as UTF-8 (e.g. File.read(file_path, encoding: 'UTF-8'), I don't get the parsing error.

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:40:44

*Thread Reply:* The fact that it is being treated as IBM437 isn't surprising from the point of view that I'm on a Windows machine but it is surprising that, presumably, that's what was going on before but it worked then.

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:41:49

*Thread Reply:* If Cucumber officially only support UTF-8 then, yeah, I could just force encode it in my own code and not have to worry. I would like to understand why this is happening, though.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:41:54

*Thread Reply:* Beats me. Perhaps the forced encoding was dropped from the parser

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:43:26

*Thread Reply:* For some of my use cases, that could be the case. This particular failure come from a case where I'm the one doing the file reading and then my code just hands off the string to Gherkin. So, in theory, the string is the same now as it was before but it is being handled differently down in cucumber-gherkin somewhere.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:45:51

*Thread Reply:* Any chance the reader assumes the encoding based on some platform default?

mpkorstanje
2020-06-11 12:45:57

*Thread Reply:* I get that in java allot

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:51:51

*Thread Reply:* I'm guessing that's happening, yes. I'm not telling Ruby that it's any particular encoding. I assume it is using some default that is not UTF-8 based on what platform it is running on.

enkessler
2020-06-11 12:52:04

*Thread Reply:* Not that those platforms have changed in years.

enkessler
2020-06-11 13:16:11

*Thread Reply:* I suppose that I'll just force UTF-8 on my end and release that change as a bug fix. Assuming, of course, that UTF-8 is the only valid encoding for Gherkin. Otherwise, I'll have to figure out how to tell Gherkin what encoding is being handed to them.

luke
2020-06-12 02:18:50

*Thread Reply:* There is a ruby top level constant you can force encoding at read/write level. I needed to do this to get umlauts e.t.c.

luke
2020-06-12 02:19:04

*Thread Reply:* Also you can place magic comments at the top of a gherrkin file, but thats only for language.

enkessler
2020-06-13 08:30:43

*Thread Reply:* The magic encoding comments do not prevent the errors and I will not have control over the feature files that users of my gem feed it anyway.

enkessler
2020-06-13 08:31:53

*Thread Reply:* After lots of reading up on encodings, I have arrived at two conclusions:

  1. This should not be my problem
  2. It wasn't my problem before and my library hasn't changed, so it even more so should not be my problem.
enkessler
2020-06-13 08:34:02

*Thread Reply:* And, lacking anything in Gherkin's changelog that indicates that encoding handling was intentionally changed, I'm going to consider this a bug.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-06-14 12:48:25

enkessler
2020-06-14 13:42:15

*Thread Reply:* I'll give it a try. Just a heads up, though: this problem only appears on Windows (I'm guessing that Ruby uses UTF-8 as the default encoding on Linux/OSX), so you'll need access to that OS to reproduce the issue.

Matthias Carell
2020-06-15 00:49:42

*Thread Reply:* I wonder if itâ€™s a OS specific or shell specific problem. You might run your code in Powershell, Cygwin bash or cmd.exe and see if it appear in all shells the same way.

enkessler
2020-06-16 02:40:15

*Thread Reply:* The problem presents in both Git Bash and the default cmd shell. It is, however, Windows specific. Ruby seems to default to opening files with IBM437 instead of UTF-8 on that OS.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-06-16 10:58:06

*Thread Reply:* Wherever we are opening files, the encoding should be explicit, i.e. this:

File.open(path, "r:UTF-8") Not this: File.open(path) # fall prey to whatever encoding the OS uses

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-06-16 10:58:17

*Thread Reply:* @enkessler maybe this will help you find the bug?

enkessler
2020-06-16 13:23:27

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak HellesÃ¸y Opening the source file with the explicit encoding does prevent the problem, yes. That being said, I don't want to arbitrarily limit encodings in my code unless I know that as certain encoding in mandatory. So my two open questions are:

  1. Does Cucumber only work with UTF-8?
  2. What changed that allowed it to work with non-UTF-8 encodings before now?
Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2020-06-16 14:45:08

*Thread Reply:* 1. Yes, although I think Cucumber-Ruby has some hack to specify feature file encoding with a # encoding: something header. Not sure how well it works. Have you tried it?

  1. No idea. If you know the last working version and first non-working version a diff might provide the answer!
enkessler
2020-06-16 16:10:47

*Thread Reply:* 1. The header doesn't seem to have any effect. Maybe I'm doing it wrong or maybe it no longer works. In any case, if UTF-8 is the only accepted encoding then I will simply force that encoding when my gem opens a file before handing off the text to cucumber-gherkin.

  1. It's moot now, given the upstream requirement clarification that cucumber-gherkin only accepts UTF-8. Thanks, @Aslak HellesÃ¸y!

enkessler (https://github.com/enkessler)
#1065 gherkin: Encoding issues on Windows
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>I recently upgraded from the <code>gherkin</code> gem to the <code>cucumber-gherkin</code> gem. My tests, which previously ran fine on Windows, are now encountering encoding problems on Windows in features files with 'special' characters. It appears to be because the text that I am giving to <code>cucumber-gherkin</code> is encoded as IBM437 but the gem is trying to treat it like UTF-8. The <code>gherkin</code> gem did not have this problem.</p> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p><code>cucumber-gherkin</code> would be able to handle IBM437 encoded text.</p> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <p>It does not.</p> <pre><code>Encoding::CompatibilityError - incompatible encoding regexp match (UTF-8 regexp with IBM437 string) </code></pre> <p>Full build here: <a href="https://ci.appveyor.com/project/enkessler/cuke-linter/build/job/5fasigic69qgaawu">https://ci.appveyor.com/project/enkessler/cuke-linter/build/job/5fasigic69qgaawu</a></p> <p><strong>Possible Solution</strong></p> <p>No idea. I didn't see anything in the Changelog that indicated encoding was being handled any differently for newer versions of the gem.</p> <p><strong>Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)</strong></p> <p>The feature file in question is this one: <a href="https://github.com/enkessler/cuke_linter/blob/master/testing/cucumber/features/linters/background_does_more_than_setup.feature">https://github.com/enkessler/cuke<em>linter/blob/master/testing/cucumber/features/linters/background</em>does<em>more</em>than_setup.feature</a></p> <p>and you can see the problem occur when using <code>cucumber-gherkin</code> on Windows (<a href="https://ci.appveyor.com/project/enkessler/cuke-linter/build/job/5fasigic69qgaawu">https://ci.appveyor.com/project/enkessler/cuke-linter/build/job/5fasigic69qgaawu</a>), as opposed to Linux/OSX (<a href="https://travis-ci.org/github/enkessler/cuke_linter/builds/698142017">https://travis-ci.org/github/enkessler/cuke_linter/builds/698142017</a>).</p> <p>If you have access to a Windows machine, simply clone the <a href="https://github.com/enkessler/cuke_linter">cuke_linter</a> repo and run the Cucumber tests (using <code>bundle exec cucumber</code>) and the problem will occur.</p> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p>While I understand that string encoding is a big, important <em>thing</em>, I did not, as a user of this gem, have to worry about it before and I would rather not have to start worrying about it now.</p> <p><strong>Your Environment</strong></p> <p>â€¢ Version used: <code>cucumber-gherkin</code> 13.0.0 â€¢ Operating System and version: Windows 10 â€¢ Link to your project: <a href="https://github.com/enkessler/cuke_linter">https://github.com/enkessler/cuke_linter</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>

luke
2020-06-24 00:08:22

luke
2020-06-29 01:31:05

*Thread Reply:* No you don't. If you have created rspec custom matchers, they're exposed as well providing you created them as a RSpec::Matchers.define

Erik Jacobs
2020-06-23 17:33:24

*Thread Reply:* with my existing rspec, that is

luke
2020-06-24 00:08:49

*Thread Reply:* hooks are global, in a sense that they are run inside the cucumber world construct (which is almost like main)

luke
2020-06-24 00:09:00

*Thread Reply:* and you can configure them to run how you want, by tags e.t.c.

Jason Borneman
2020-07-01 11:19:08

Hi all, long time Ruby Cucumber user (2.4) upgrading to 4.1. yeah. Big jump. I've got questions about Events. In our current situation we have a Framework gem that we use to import hooks to multiple Cucumber test projects. In that framework gem, it currently (for 2.4) looks like this (stripped down) (see comments, don't wanna flood the channel with a huge post):

Jason Borneman
2020-07-01 11:19:12

*Thread Reply:* ```include Cucumber::RbSupport::RbDsl module Framework module Support module OurHooks AfterConfiguration do # do stuff end

  Before do |scenario|
    # do stuff
  end

  After do |scenario|
    # do stuff
  end

  at_exit do
    <b>#do</b> stuff
  end
end

end end`` Then inÂ features/support/hooks.rbÂ we doÂ World(Framework::Support::OurHooks)`

This of course fails in 4.1. I tried changin gthe include toÂ include Cucumber::EventsÂ but that did not work. I keep gettingÂ undefined method 'AfterConfiguration'Â or 'Before'Â etc. Where have these hook types been moved to so I can define custom global hooks?

Jason Borneman
2020-07-01 11:30:15

*Thread Reply:* Huzzah, found it. Of course right after I post this. ðŸ˜„ It's Cucumber::Glue::Dsl now

Reyjie Mesias
2020-07-06 07:26:24

@Reyjie Mesias has joined the channel

Jason Borneman
2020-07-06 10:06:24

In Cucumber 4, (cucumber-core 7.1.0) is there a way to get the feature NAME off of the Scenario object (Cucumber::Core::Test::Case)? Used to do this: After do |scenario| feature_name = scenario.source[0].name but that clearly no longer works

brasmusson
2020-07-06 12:16:42

*Thread Reply:* Why do you want the feature name in a hook? If it is for reporting, the answer is to use an event listener (which all formatters are now), which can monitor the event stream and do any reporting you need (hooks have never been intended for reporting)

Jason Borneman
2020-07-06 12:17:57

*Thread Reply:* yeah it's used sorta for reporting to a homegrown internal-to-us web service that stores test results for reporting.

Looks like I'll have to investigate event listeners for a long term fix.

Jason Borneman
2020-07-06 12:18:51

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

luke
2020-07-07 00:57:00

*Thread Reply:* So this was unintendedly removed. But there are a couple of tickets mentioning this.

brasmusson
2020-07-07 01:13:40

*Thread Reply:* @luke What do you mean, what was unintentionally removed? The consequence of not having all possible feature file data available in the hooks is a direct consequence of compiling feature files to Pickles - which was very intentional.

Jason Borneman
2020-07-07 07:54:03

Have a hunch I'm gonna be in here a lot in the coming week or so. So bear with me as we upgrade from 2.4 -> 4.1. I'm now on to formatters. It seems the --foramt json is being removed, to be replaced by https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/json-formatter#cucumber-json-formatter but heck if I can find a good useable example. I try to run it using the instructions there:

cucumber --format protobuf:cucumber-messages.bin cat cucumber-messages.bin | cucumber-json-formatter &gt; cucumber-results.json But it fails with the following message: cannot load such file -- protobuf:cucumber_messages.bin Error creating formatter: protobuf:cucumber-messages.bin (LoadError) Are there any good examples out there of how to get this working? In addition, we used to do this in our cucumber.yml to handle parallel execution with the paralleltests gem: parallel: --format progress --format ParallelTests::Cucumber::FailuresLogger --out Logs/cucumber_failures.log --format json --out Logs/cucumber_report&lt;%= ENV['TEST_ENV_NUMBER'] %&gt;.json --expand This allowed us to have a separate cucumberreport_#.json file for each parallel process. Is that going to even be possible with the new formatter strategy?

Thanks for all everyone's patience with my ???s. It's a big upgrade for us that we let slide far too long.

(This doesn't even include the fact that it would seem the Teamcity:: Cucumber::Formatter doesn't work anymore with 4.x ðŸ˜ž I've filed a report with Jetbrains about that one)

brasmusson
2020-07-07 09:24:31

*Thread Reply:* To me, the json formatter seems to be deprecated and not removed: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#deprecated

The changelog also says that the json formatter has been deprecated in favor of the --format message formatter.

I believe that "cucumber" in the instructions of the standalone json fromatter does not refer to the Cucumber-Ruby gem but the fake-cucumber utility. I recon that the data produced by the --format message formatter can be fed to the cucumber-json-formatter, but I have never tried it.

CHANGELOG.md
<p>```</p> <h1>CHANGE LOG</h1> <p>All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.</p> <p>This project adheres to <a href="http://semver.org">Semantic Versioning</a>.</p> <p>This document is formatted according to the principles of <a href="http://keepachangelog.com">Keep A CHANGELOG</a>.</p> <p>Please visit <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">cucumber/CONTRIBUTING.md</a> for more info on how to contribute to Cucumber.</p> <hr /> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.1.0...master">In GIT</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.1...v4.1.0">4.1.0</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Use <a href="https://rubygems.org/gems/cucumber-create-meta"><code>cucumber-create-meta</code></a> to produce the <code>Meta</code> message before the run.</p> <p><em>* Updated gems: *</em> <code>cucumber-wire</code> ~&gt; 3.1.0 <em>* <code>cucumber-core</code> ~&gt; 7.1.0 *</em> <code>cucumber-gherkin</code> ~&gt; 14.0.1 <em>* Fix issue with empty feature files <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1427">#1427</a> *</em> <code>cucumber-messages</code> ~&gt; 12.2.0 <em>* <code>cucumber-html-formatter</code> ~&gt; 7.0.0 *</em> Fix issue with Hook attachments <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1420">#1420</a></p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p>** <code>AfterStep</code> hook do not cause issue when running <code>message</code> formatter. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1433">#1433</a> - <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1434">#1434</a></p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0...v4.0.1">4.0.1</a></h2> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p>** force reference to <code>diff-lcs</code> to 1.3 as 1.4 introduced breaking changes.</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.5...v4.0.0">4.0.0</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** <code>log</code> method can now be called with non-string objects and will run <code>.to_s</code> on them. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1410">#1410</a></p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Display snippet when using undefined parameter type <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1411">#1411</a></p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.5...4.0.0.rc.6">4.0.0.rc.6</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Code snippet for an undefined step with a Doc String will ouput <code>doc_string</code> instead of <code>string</code> in block params (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1401">#1401</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1402">#1402</a> <a href="https://github.com/karamosky">karamosky</a>)</p> <p>** Updated monorepo libraries:</p><ul><li>cucumber-gherkin ~&gt; 13</li><li>cucumber-html-formatter ~&gt; 6</li><li>cucumber-cucumber-expressions ~&gt; 10</li> </ul> <p>** Use <code>cucumber-ruby-core</code> 7.0.0</p> <p>** Use <code>cucumber-ruby-wire</code> 3.0.0</p> <p>** Use <code>body</code> field of attachments</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p><em>* <code>--out url</code> updates: *</em> supports redirects <em>* use <code>PUT</code> method by default *</em> use a cURL like options (for example: <code>cucumber --out '&lt;http://example.com&gt; -X POST -H Content-Type: json</code>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.4...4.0.0.rc.5">4.0.0.rc.5</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** New html formatter enabled by option <code>--format html --out report.html</code>.</p> <p>** Accept <code>--out URL</code> to POST results to a web server If a URL is used as output, the output will be sent with a POST request. This can be overridden by specifying e.g. <code>http-method=PUT</code> as a query parameter. Other <code>http-</code> prefixed query parameters will be converted to request headers (with the <code>http-</code> prefix stripped off).</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.3...4.0.0.rc.4">4.0.0.rc.4</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Add <code>message</code>formatter which produces <code>Cucumber::Messages</code> ndjson output. *</em> Comply with [<code>cucumber-compatibility-kit](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/compatibility-kit&gt;) ** Methods</code>log<code>and</code>attach` can be used in step definitions to attach text or images</p> <h3>Deprecated</h3> <p><em>* <code>--format=json</code> in favor of the <code>message</code> formatter and the stand-alone JSON formatter *</em> <code>puts</code> in step definitions in favor of <code>log</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/897">cucumber#897</a>) ** <code>embed</code> in step definitions in favor of <code>attach</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/897">cucumber#897</a>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.2...v4.0.0.rc.3">4.0.0.rc.3</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Update to cucumber-wire 1.1.</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.1...v4.0.0.rc.2">4.0.0.rc.2</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* There is a new methodology in Cucumber for how the auto-loader works *</em> The old <code>load</code> behaviour is now replaced with a newer <code>require</code> behaviour <em>* Cucumber will (From version 4), now auto-load files using the <code>require</code> method *</em> If you wish to alter this, then you can set a top level config option: <code>Cucumber.use_legacy_autoloader</code> <em>* Like most config options, setting this inside a <code>spec_helper.rb</code> or <code>env.rb</code> file is advised *</em> For more information on this change, including why it was made. Please read this <a href="https://cucumber.io/blog/open-source/tweaking-cucumber-rubys-auto-loader/">Blog Post</a> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349">#1349</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Going forward the minimum ruby version for all cucumber based gems is 2.3 (<a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** Removed Travis publish job for cucumber-pro(a.k.a. jam) (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1350">#1350</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <p>** Drop support for JRuby. We may add this back if new versions of protobuf for JRuby start working, or if someone can make the build pass with an older version. All this means is we're ok to make releases while the jruby CI job is failing.</p> <p>(<a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">aslakhellesoy</a>)</p> <p>** Remove <code>dots-formatter introduced in</code>4.0.0rc1`</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Fix the placeholder expansions in the json formatter (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1361">#1361</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Fix seed printed in cucumber UI to match the seed that was actually used. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1329">#1329</a> <a href="https://github.com/deivid-rodriguez">deivid-rodriguez</a>) ** Make SIGINT/<code>Ctrl+c</code> behavior consistent with SIGTERM/<code>kill</code> behavior - now first invocation causes existing scenario to stop running and jump to <code>at_exit</code>, second invocation causes immediate exit. Before that first invocation only instructed Cucumber to exit after scenario and second invocation caused immediate exit skipping <code>at_exit</code>. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1353">#1353</a> <a href="https://github.com/akostadinov">akostadinov</a>)</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Filter out any lines containing <code>site_ruby</code> from stacktrace</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v3.1.2...v4.0.0.rc.1">4.0.0.rc.1</a> (2018-09-29)</h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Added support for new <code>Rule</code> keyword. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/CHANGELOG.md#6013---2018-09-25">Read more here.</a> *</em> Added new <code>dots</code> formatter. This is the first step of a larger strategy to move the formatters to a new architecture where they delegate to shared executables via messages.</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p><em>* Use Gherkin v6. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1313">#1313</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Do not apply Before and After Hooks to Test Cases with no Test Steps. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1311">#1311</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Pass the registry to the Wire plugin. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Adapt to using the Gherkin compiler and Pickles in the core. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) ** Let the Pretty Formatter use events. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1305">#1305</a> [brasmusson](<https://github.com/brâ€¦</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
