Vincent Pretre
2020-07-08 01:43:13

*Thread Reply:* Another note of interest about this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1439

andrcuns (https://github.com/andrcuns)
#1439 Can't generate json via standalone formatter from the output of message formatter
<p>Hei folks. Sorry if this should be created in monorepo rather than ruby specific repo, not entirely sure where the fault lies.</p> <p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> I am trying to generate json report via standalone json-formatter from the output of <code>message</code> formatter but I am getting an error.</p> <pre><code>â¯ cat message | ./cucumber-json-formatter-darwin-amd64 2020/07/01 18:53:07 ERROR: unexpected EOF </code></pre> <p>or</p> <pre><code>â¯ bundle exec cucumber --format message | ./cucumber-json-formatter-darwin-amd64 2020/07/01 19:07:00 ERROR: unexpected EOF </code></pre> <p>Contents of message also seem to be ok as far as I can tell, though I don't really know how exactly it should look like.</p> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> Steps to reproduce the behavior:</p> <p>Execute some test:</p> <pre><code>bundle exec cucumber --format message --out message cat message | ./cucumber-json-formatter-darwin-amd64 </code></pre> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong><br /> Should generate json I guess</p> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong><br /> Can't get rid of json formatter deprecation warning after upgrading to v4</p> <p><strong>Your Environment</strong></p> <p>â€¢ Cucumber 4.0.1, json-formatter 5.1.0 â€¢ Tried versions for linux and macos</p>
Comments
1
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Vincent Pretre
2020-07-08 01:43:33

*Thread Reply:* you should specify that the input is JSON, not binary when using the JSON formatter

luke
2020-07-07 08:17:59

For parallel tests, I prefer having a better chosen split strategy. Instead of using a random strategy. So split your run into several sub-rakes, and have those ran.

Jason Borneman
2020-07-07 09:05:09

*Thread Reply:* We've written a central framework for other development teams within our company to use to them implement Cucumber tests around a standard framework of execution (teamcity, blah blah blah) so I don't have a lot of granular control over what other people's features look like or even know what features to do in sub-rakes. Alas.

Maybe I could parse through their features directory and spin up sub calls to direct cucumber for each feature file found? But that functionality already exists in the parallel_tests gem, so I don't wanna re-invent the wheel ya know?

luke
2020-07-08 01:17:31

*Thread Reply:* so the usual reason people run in parallel is because their rake is long, like 10-15 mins

luke
2020-07-08 01:17:48

*Thread Reply:* So as such, simply splitting up gives you control and partioning ability that you lose by using parallel tests.

Martin Phillips
2020-08-18 06:56:28

Hi all. I have a Java background, and am trying to understand best practices on separation and structure of cukes and infrastructure in Ruby. We have the env.rb file with 'Before' and 'After' methods in it for things to happen before and after every scenario (env.rb doesn't define itself as a module or class). Features in .feature files and step definitions in step.rb files (both also neither module nor class). We have some xxxhelper.rb modules (all listed as 'required' by env.rb - these methods seem to be available pretty much everywhere). The PageObjects (SitePrism basd) are classes and these are initialized into @xxxx (Instance?) variables during 'Before' and seem to be available to every step/helper. There is also ENV (loaded from the .env file) which if modified is persistent between scenarios(?). I'm trying to work out the correct place to define/set up variables for scenarios that are available between steps for the lifespan of a scenario, but which will be 'reset' every scenario.

Martin Phillips
2020-08-18 06:57:05

I'm guessing they should be defined/initialized in the 'Before' step, and possibly modified for a test scenario by a specific step definition. Should they be $ (global?) @ (instance?), or some other sort of thing?

2020-08-18 07:01:16

luke
2020-08-18 07:01:26

2020-08-18 07:02:13

Martin Phillips
2020-08-18 07:07:43

architecture/runtime is exactly it. The specific 'issue' I'm trying to solve is enhancing the test framework to support the addition of a baseurl in addition to the hostname. We currently specify HOSTNAME in the .env file, and access is all over the place as ENV['HOSTNAME']. For one particular scenario I have a step that does "I configure the app to run under baseurl 'xxx'" So instead of accessing HOSTNAME, this scenario will access HOSTNAME/baseurl. We use this for both web pages, and API calls in various places. i'd initially updated ENV['HOSTNAME'} to also include the baseurl, that that then persisted over to the remaining scenarios in the suite and broke thm all.

2020-08-18 07:08:40

Jeremy
2020-08-19 17:19:14

Iâ€™m looking to upgrade from cucumber 3.1.2 -> cucumber 4.1.0 or 5.0.0. It looks like report output is the main change I will need to deal with to make this upgrade, and (being new), Iâ€™m having a little trouble figuring out exactly what the changes look like that I need to make. In general, our scripts are using output something like this: $ cucumber -f json -o test_output/file_name.json I see in the changelog that -f json is deprecated: > --format=jsonÂ in favor of theÂ messageÂ formatter and the stand-alone JSON formatter And I see this in the Cucumber JSON Formatter module: cucumber --format protobuf:cucumber-messages.bin cat cucumber-messages.bin | cucumber-json-formatter &gt; cucumber-results.json Does this mean my updated script should reflect the syntax above? $ cucumber -f protobuf:cucumber-messages.bin $ cat cucumber-messages.bin | cucumber-json-formatter &gt; test_output/file_name.json Thank you for any help!

brasmusson
2020-08-19 22:20:38

AFAIK "cucumber" in Cucumber Json Formatter does not mean Cucumber-Ruby but the Fake Cucumber utility. Use "cucumber -f message -o <file>"

luke
2020-08-20 00:23:05

basically in short, cucumber now outputs into 1 single format - messages. Then using these messages you can output into a multitude of formats, such as json/html e.t.c.

Whilst this is an extra step for the user, the benefits for coding are immense, all flavours (java/js/ruby e.t.c.) all output identical (or should do), messages, meaning the formatters now can be single use.

Jeremy
2020-08-20 11:34:42

@brasmusson and @luke â€” thank you for the help! This is starting to clear up my understanding of whatâ€™s going on. Iâ€™ve been able to run Cucumber 4.1 with $ cucumber -f message -o file_name.json â€¦ but clearly Iâ€™m missing a step, as I donâ€™t want to output the messages themselves as json â€” Iâ€™m still not quite wrapping my head around what step or command would reproduce what I got previously when Iâ€™d use $ cucumber -f json -o file_name.json

Edmilson
2020-08-20 18:32:52

@Edmilson has joined the channel

luke
2020-08-21 00:23:20

so there is 1 extra step. The new cucumber formats as "messages" these aren't json, they aren't html, they're language agnostic things that are quite clever made using protobuf

luke
2020-08-21 00:24:08

then using these "messages" you then convert to json or html or something else, using a custom formatter

This logic (Convert using a formatter), has been in place since cucumber2 iirc, but now we're wanting people to use this interim step, because then formatters can be used cross-flavour. Something previously impossible.

luke
2020-08-21 00:24:51

I'm currently not using this new logic, and I know the documentation isn't really robust yet, but they're still quite new (hence the legacy ones still existing for now0>

brasmusson
2020-08-21 00:44:42

@Jeremy After you have produced the message file I recon you should do "cat <file> | cucumber-json-formatter > cucumber-results.json"

Jeremy
2020-08-21 11:21:16

Jeremy
2020-08-24 10:10:37

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak HellesÃ¸y and anyone else looking into this, Iâ€™m pretty sure the problem has to do with the admin profiles on my work-administered Macbook. I discovered a workaround for this detailed here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60362018/macos-catalinav-10-15-3-error-chromedriver-cannot-be-opened-because-the-de

Using the $ xattr command worked for me, making cucumber-json-formatter available as a cli. So itâ€™s probably not worth the effort to try and notarize this little module when the problem is pretty fringe and isolated to the case of (poorly) managed MacOS devices, and when you can just point people for whom this is an issue to this workaround.

Stack Overflow
MacOS Catalina(v 10.15.3): Error: â€œchromedriverâ€ cannot be opened because the developer cannot be verified. Unable to launch the chrome browser
I have recently upgraded my mac machine to OS Catalina(v 10.15.3). After this upgrade I am unable to launch the chrome driver using selenium. I am facing the below error when I run the selenium co...
Original URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60362018/macos-catalinav-10-15-3-error-chromedriver-cannot-be-opened-because-the-de

Martin Phillips
2020-09-17 03:18:18

Hi all, I have a step I'm using in a scenario outline. In the table of data I sometimes have a filename to delete, and sometimes don't (the table cell is just empty/blank which makes the 'files' param ""). if there are no files to delete, I want to do nothing, but putting this return statement in causes a "unexpected return (LocalJumpError)" (I think because a step definition isn't a lambda/method, but something different). The alternative is to wrap the entire content of the method in an if statement, which I understand is not approved of in Ruby. Suggestions please for the 'right' way to do this?

Untitled
apremdas
2020-09-18 08:52:55

*Thread Reply:* I would rephrase this to Given there are no files and implement that as

Given 'there are no files do ensure_no_files end and implement that as

def ensure_no_files some_files? ? delete_files : ; end or something similar

A Given should be something you do or are doing, it should be something that is done ðŸ™‚

Martin Phillips
2020-09-21 01:17:27

*Thread Reply:* We are actively performing a file delete as part of the scenario. We are testing the code management system behaves correctly when files are deleted/edited/added/moved) as part of a commit.

Christophe Bliard
2020-10-07 05:19:40

*Thread Reply:* in a do â€¦ end block, return would return from the outer function, but thee are none here. To exit a block, you have to use break instead (1..10).each { |v| print v ; return if v == 5 } =&gt; LocalJumpError (1..10).each { |v| print v ; break if v == 5 } =&gt; outputs "12345" def print_numbers (1..10).each { |v| print v ; return if v == 5 } print "!" end print_numbers =&gt; outputs "12345" def print_numbers (1..10).each { |v| print v ; break if v == 5 } print "!!!" end print_numbers =&gt; outputs "12345!!!"

Christophe Bliard
2020-10-07 05:21:42

*Thread Reply:* But you may have solved your issue in another way by now ðŸ™‚

Martin Phillips
2020-10-07 05:23:25

*Thread Reply:* Useful to know for the future! I am still very unfamiliar with ruby, and the difference between 'break' and 'return' in this context would be great!

Martin Phillips
2020-10-07 05:23:59

*Thread Reply:* I think I just did the if-statement around the entire blocks

Martin Phillips
2020-10-07 05:24:33

*Thread Reply:* Many thanks for the info! I'll remember for next time :

Martin Phillips
2020-10-07 05:24:35

*Thread Reply:* ðŸ™‚

Christophe Bliard
2020-10-07 05:31:10

*Thread Reply:* well, Iâ€™ve been bitten by LocalJumpError many times before. The rule of thumb is that return is to return from a function, and break is to â€œreturnâ€ from a block. We are used to using break in loops like so in other languages like python: for val in "string": if val == "i": break print(val) or while loops: while true: if system.is_ready(): break sleep 1 and it works the same way in ruby, the syntax has simply been extended to exit any blocks (do ... end or { ... }). So in the step definition, break must be used because it is a block, not a function.

ðŸ‘ Martin Phillips
luke
2020-09-17 06:19:23

so is this something you want to do as an early step or late step? Is this something that should not bother running at all if this condition isn't met?

luke
2020-09-17 06:19:48

We used to have a scenario that cancelled an order. But step1 was login and validate it was pending. If it was already cancelled, we skipped the scenario and said all is well!

phebus
2020-09-17 06:20:58

i donâ€™t see anything wrong with using an if statement

phebus
2020-09-17 06:21:41

guard clauses are preferred in traditional methods/blocks but i think you get a pass in this instance if return breaks out completely

ðŸ‘ Martin Phillips
luke
2020-09-17 06:23:58

yeh. So you could do

unless files.blank? # do delete end But again I'd be intrigued to know if you "should" carry on. If files are blank

ðŸ‘ Martin Phillips
Martin Phillips
2020-09-17 06:43:09

Cool - I've gone with that unless files.blank?

Martin Phillips
2020-09-17 06:45:32

For this set of tests, we want to make a change (like a git commit) with some changes in it - the same scenario can test something whether files are added, edited, deleted or renamed. If the steps blow up when no filename is passed, we have to write most of the scenario again multiple times missing out the add, edit, delete etc that we don't want for that variation

Untitled
luke
2020-09-18 01:09:44

this is a huge scenario!! But if you're happy with it working then I'll leave you to it.

Martin Phillips
2020-09-18 01:54:11

Oh - this isn't a big one ðŸ™‚ We have a moderately complex system to test, and the setup of each scenario (as you can see here) can be lengthy to get is to the right state to 'test' one particular thing under various conditions.

Martin Phillips
2020-09-18 01:56:20

we could possibly merge some of the steps together to make it look smaller, but all those actions have to be performed and configurable.

mpkorstanje
2020-09-18 03:20:09

With a scenario like this, why bother with Cucumber? You can write a unit test that calls Cucumbers steps and it would be just as clear.

I don't know your system and after reading your feature file I know even less. How do any of these things done in the scenario relate to other?

phebus
2020-09-18 06:05:36

2020-09-18 06:24:02

mpkorstanje

2020-09-21 04:15:13

apremdas
2020-09-21 04:15:41

apremdas
2020-09-21 04:22:24

found solution - 1) Tag your scenario (or feature) with @allow-rescue - this is from the setup cucumber-rails provides.

Dinh Luong
2020-09-30 00:09:36

Hi all, Iâ€™m looking to upgrade fromÂ cucumber 3.1.2Â ->Â cucumber 4.1.0Â orÂ the current one 5.1.2 which uses the new Cucumber messages mechanism. Since I have used my custom HTML report from the previous version 3.1.2, with the new changes, i think most of them are deprecated and not supported anymore. I found out itâ€™s pretty struggle to figure out which changes i should apply to the current one to adapt the new Cucumber Message mechanism.

In general, my current custom HTML report output in v3.1.2 is: --format Integration::Formatter::Html -o build/report.html

And i have override the after_features method in v3.1.2 which using @builder from HTMLBuilder to insert the the failured summary into the html report if thereâ€™s any failure when running the test.

I see in the change log thatÂ -f html has turned into the standalone HTML formatter, which uses output_envelope method to write message and somehow render it through another standalone Cucumber-React.

My problem is i tried to send some message as HTML structure using @html_formatter.output_envelope but could not know how to get these message rendered into the report, and turning into the output of customized report is same as the default HTML formatter. So I wonder there is any instruction/ documentation to get the html report customized with the new Cucumber > v4.1.0.

Also another question is with the current HTML formatter, i can see the details test step (like action click, select, etc.) is hidden if the test step is passed. I wonder if that option can be turn on/off somehow, since sometime i think it would be benefit (for debugging) to get the detail test step showing in the report instead just knowing the step is passed.

Thank you all for any help!

Matthias Carell
2020-11-19 01:22:31

I was just playing around with the rule keyword in Cucumber 5.2.0 and tried to use tags in combination with a rule, e.g. to run only examples under this rule. Of course this didnâ€™t work. So Iâ€™m wondering if there is some good reason not to use tags on rules?

luke
2020-11-19 02:11:09

Yes and no. I actually asked this myself, and I'm a core contributor in ruby.

The simpler answer is. Will come.

ðŸ‘ Matthias Carell
luke
2020-11-19 02:12:01

Because gherkin is implemented as a parser, we need to get it updated in the gherkin core parser first. I think it was just one of the use cases we didn't originally foresee. It will come though, because I admit it's handy.

Matthias Carell
2020-11-19 02:17:49

Sounds cool! ðŸ™‚

luke
2020-11-19 02:32:07

Given you can't tag a background in a rule (By design, and unlikely to change), sadly you've just got to tag either a) every scenario under the rule or b the feature whole.

Matthias Carell
2020-11-19 02:38:29

Hmmm for my understanding a rule is just a feature inside another feature. So if a rule has a background this would be just a property of the rule. But this is just how I would model this structure. It seems to me Cucumber is following a different model. Would be nice if we had a drawing for this. ðŸ˜‰

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 03:02:20

Hello, Do you know some way to identify scenarios outline? The example below I have a tag to identify the whole scenario outline, but how can I identify each line of the Example table?

```@uniquescenariotag Scenario Outline: eating Given there are <start> cucumbers When I eat <eat> cucumbers Then I should have <left> cucumbers

Examples: | start | eat | left | | 12 | 5 | 7 | | 20 | 5 | 15 |```

If I do in this way it works, but I'm not proud of this solution ðŸ˜… Imagine in big scenarios outline that I have more then 100 lines in the table ðŸ˜“ ```Scenario Outline: eating Given there are <start> cucumbers When I eat <eat> cucumbers Then I should have <left> cucumbers

@uniquescenariotag_1 Examples: | start | eat | left | | 12 | 5 | 7 |

@uniquescenariotag_2 Examples: | start | eat | left | | 20 | 5 | 15 |``` Do you have a better idea?

ciaranmcnulty
2021-02-22 03:09:39

What's the use case for identifying it? To run just a single row?

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 03:12:48

exactly, imagine saving the results of the tests in a database to compare the executions in the future. If I add a new line in the table I'll lose all the references.

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 03:13:50

I would like to have a unique identifier each test, I don't know if there is some feature to do that

Matthias Carell
2021-02-22 03:24:12

If the identifier (id) helps to distinguish the example you could just add the id to the scenario steps and of course to the table as another column. This way the id will appear in the test results.

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 04:29:27

*Thread Reply:* It's a good idea, the problem is change the scenarios description to pass the ID parameter. Do you know if is there a way to put some column as metadata and it appears in the scenario report without describe a parameter? Example: @unique_scenario_tag Scenario Outline: eating Given there are &lt;start&gt; cucumbers When I eat &lt;eat&gt; cucumbers Then I should have &lt;left&gt; cucumbers Examples: | id | start | eat | left | | aaa | 12 | 5 | 7 | | bbb | 20 | 5 | 15 |

Matthias Carell
2021-02-22 05:32:57

*Thread Reply:* If the id does not add to the scenario description I wouldn't add it. Instead you could generate one out of the other values e.g. id='12-5-7'

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 08:44:48

*Thread Reply:* ahh thank you... I think is the same idea as @luke said in another thread, I'll tag you there

luke
2021-02-22 08:56:04

*Thread Reply:* why don't you just use the scenario name? that is something that is self-descriptive.I still don't understand why you need this random but not random ID?

If it's random or unique, use the feature-line If it's descriptive, use the scenario description It it's something else ðŸ¤· I don't know what else to say.

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 10:53:01

*Thread Reply:* ðŸ˜… I got the idea with your answers... I'm trying to find the better way to do what I need and after I'll share it here

Matthias Carell
2021-02-22 03:29:43

In your example I would assume that the combination of the three columns is already an unique identifier.

luke
2021-02-22 03:40:56

what you've just done seems fine. It's what I do when I have passing / failing scenarios.

luke
2021-02-22 03:41:34

Also remember that each run has a very easily accessible run-line. That is a unique identifier (Plus name e.t.c.)

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 04:37:12

*Thread Reply:* yeah, I'm using in this way right now but the problem is when we add a new line in the example table. It change the lines of the new execution and I can't compare with the previous execution ðŸ˜“

luke
2021-02-22 04:49:24

*Thread Reply:* yes, but each run line is still unique?

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 05:19:41

*Thread Reply:* yes, it's unique in the current execution but not unique if I compare with other executions, because the line can be changed

luke
2021-02-22 06:33:46

*Thread Reply:* any id would be of the same format. So you don't need an ID, what you need is the scenario name. That would be unique (or at least reasonably unique).

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 08:40:54

*Thread Reply:* uhmm.. now I got your idea. Yep, it really make sense I think we developed in a different way, we have some tags that change the execution behavior, for example, we have the same values in two executions but when I have @gateway the step creates a token to access the service

```Scenario Outline: eating Given there are <start> cucumbers When I eat <eat> cucumbers Then I should have <left> cucumbers

@gateway Examples: | start | eat | left | | 12 | 5 | 7 |

@ingress Examples: | start | eat | left | | 12 | 5 | 7 |```

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 08:41:54

*Thread Reply:* but I think I can create an ID using the information of the table and join with that tags

luke
2021-02-22 08:53:28

*Thread Reply:* You shouldn't even need to use cucumber tags. But you can if you want.

You can just pass in direct ENV params. Then go from there, it massively dries up your codebase.

luke
2021-02-22 08:53:57

*Thread Reply:* ```FOO=gateway bundle exec cucumber

then

FOO=ingress bundle exec cucumber```

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 09:06:15

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-02-22 09:43:38

@Fabricio Bedin if I understand correctly, you want to have a unique ID for a every line of code. If some content is added or removed from a file, those IDs should remain unchanged.

In other words, you want to be able to "track" the evolution of certain lines over time.

Did I understand correctly?

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 10:04:15

*Thread Reply:* I think it fits what I need ðŸ˜Š

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-02-22 10:05:10

*Thread Reply:* It's a non-trivial problem to solve, it's still an area of active research. This is a problem that has interested me for many years, and the paper I linked to is the best I have come across so far.

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 10:06:20

*Thread Reply:* uhmm.. interesting, I'll create an account there to read the paper

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-02-22 10:06:42

*Thread Reply:* Let me see if I can find a public version....

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-02-22 10:07:33

*Thread Reply:* https://www.cs.usask.ca/~croy/papers/2013/LHDiffFullPaper-preprint.pdf

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 10:08:20

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-02-22 10:10:05

*Thread Reply:* Implementing the algorithm is not a walk in the park though, and I'm not aware of any publicly available implementations.

I just wanted to highlight that this seemingly simple problem is actually very complex ðŸ™‚

Fabricio Bedin
2021-02-22 10:30:24

*Thread Reply:* yep, I'm at the beginning of the article you sent me and I already had an idea that is really really not simple ðŸ˜¨

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-02-22 09:44:30

Something like this? https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6676894

ieeexplore.ieee.org
LHDiff: A Language-Independent Hybrid Approach for Tracking Source Code Lines
Tracking source code lines between two different versions of a file is a fundamental step for solving a number of important problems in software maintenance such as locating bug introducing changes, tracking code fragments or defects across versions, merging file versions, and software evolution analysis. Although a number of such approaches are available in the literature, their performance is sensitive to the kind and degree of source code changes. There is also a marked lack of study on the effect of change types on source location tracking techniques. In this paper, we propose a language-independent technique, LHDiff, for tracking source code lines across versions that leverages simhash technique together with heuristics to improve accuracy. We evaluate our approach against state-of-the- art techniques using benchmarks containing different degrees of changes where files are selected from real world applications. We further evaluate LHDiff with other techniques using a mutation based analysis to understand how different types of changes affect their performance. The results reveal that our technique is more effective than language-independent approaches and no worse than some language-dependent techniques. In our study LHDiff even shows better performance than a state-of-the-art language- dependent approach. In addition, we also discuss limitations of different line tracking techniques including ours and propose future research directions.
Original URL: https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6676894
enkessler
2021-02-22 09:58:46

enkessler/cuke_cataloger
<p>A handy gem for adding identifier tags to Cucumber tests.</p>

luke
2021-02-26 04:57:09

Something I did many moons ago (This was in cucumber2 time), was doing a report where we obtained the runtime of each step and pushed it to a reporting endpoint.

We obtained this by a rudimentary feature whereby we used AfterSteps to grab the timestamp between each step.

Is there a more fully formed way of doing things now, to get this data. Or is this still the best approach? I've been out of the "timings" arena for a while.

brasmusson
2021-02-26 05:11:25

*Thread Reply:* AFAIK the result objects of the TestCaseResult/TestStepResult events have a duration attribute with the duration of the test case/step.

2021-02-26 05:48:52

phebus

this is how iâ€™m doing it image64 = @browser.screenshot.base64 attach("data:image/png;base64,#{image64}", 'image/png')

YouTrack
Support Cucumber 5.2 (testing) : RUBY-27294
1. What steps will reproduce the problem? Install/Use Cucumber 5.2 Run tests in RubyMine 2020.2.3 or IntelliJ with latest Ruby plugin. 2. What is the expected result? That the tests run. 3. What happens instead? .rbenv/versions/2.7.2/lib/ruby/2.7.0/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:72:in `require' .rbenv/versions/2.7.2/lib/ruby/2.7.0/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:72:in `require' -e:1:in `á¸mainá³' If I downgrade to Cucumber 5.1 this problem disappears. Cucumber 5.2 runs perfectly fine via the CLI, so I think the issue is in RubyMine.â€¦
Original URL: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/RUBY-27294
matt-SmartBear
2021-03-17 12:54:14

*Thread Reply:* No worries, thanks for looking that up, itâ€™s good to know theyâ€™re on the case.

luke
2021-03-18 03:19:18

*Thread Reply:* As an FYI

Jetbrains are always late to the party, as their formatter is often highly coupled to cucumber / gherkin versions.

Best way to mitigate this is to raise a support ticket.

luke
2021-03-18 03:19:56

*Thread Reply:* You can even see in the stacktrace, they're determining you're using cucumber4 (But you're not).

The issue is a lot of the time we break stuff, which they rely on

Jeremy
2021-05-26 18:26:50

When running $ cucumber --format pretty on a file that uses the â€œRuleâ€ keyword, with Cucumber 6.0, should I be seeing the Rules print out to the console along with the Features and Scenarios? I have my file formatted like this: Feature: ... Rule: ... Scenario: ... Given When Then But I am not seeing the Rules print out to the console.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-05-27 02:06:01

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Jeremy - we haven't updated the pretty formatter to print rules yet. The pretty formatter is one of the oldest and gnarliest parts of Cucumber, and it's pretty hard to maintain.

This probably won't get fixed until we rewrite it.

ðŸ‘ Jeremy
Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-05-27 02:07:02

*Thread Reply:* @AurÃ©lien Reeves / @matt-SmartBear - If/when we tackle this I think we should implement it over in https://github.com/cucumber/common, using a shared test suite so we can implement it consistently in different languages.

cucumber/common
A monorepo of common components - building blocks for implementing Cucumber in various languages.
Website
<https://cucumber.io/docs>

AurÃ©lien Reeves
2021-05-28 00:06:07

*Thread Reply:* Just open an issue: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1547

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1547|#1547 The pretty formatter does not report rules>
<p>From a Slack conversation here: <a href="https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C7676D8GN/p1622078810002700">https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C7676D8GN/p1622078810002700</a></p> <p>When running <code>$ cucumber --format pretty</code> on a file that uses the â€œRuleâ€ keyword, with Cucumber 6, should I be seeing the Rules print out to the console along with the Features and Scenarios? I have my file formatted like this:</p> <pre><code>Feature: ... Rule: ... Scenario: ... Given When Then </code></pre> <p>But I am not seeing the Rules print out to the console.</p> <p>Note: the pretty formatter is hard to maintain</p> <p>Suggestion: having the pretty formatter rewritten into the monorepo to use shared testdata and have a consistent behavior in different languages.</p>

ðŸ¦ debt, ðŸ› bug, âœ… accepted

Matthias Carell
2021-05-28 11:09:48

*Thread Reply:* I assume the feature should get some update as well. Could be a nice example mapping session. ;-)

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/features/docs/formatters/pretty_formatter.feature | pretty_formatter.feature>
<pre><code>Feature: Pretty output formatter Background: Given a file named "features/scenario_outline_with_undefined_steps.feature" with: """ Feature: Scenario Outline: Given this step is undefined Examples: |foo| |bar| """ Scenario: an scenario outline, one undefined step, one random example, expand flag on When I run `cucumber features/scenario_outline_with_undefined_steps.feature --format pretty --expand ` Then it should pass Scenario: when using a profile the output should include 'Using the default profile...' And a file named "cucumber.yml" with: """ default: -r features """ When I run `cucumber --profile default --format pretty` Then it should pass And the output should contain: """ Using the default profile... """ Scenario: Hook output should be printed before hook exception Given the standard step definitions And a file named "features/test.feature" with: """ Feature: Scenario: Given this step passes """ And a file named "features/step_definitions/output_steps.rb" with: """ Before do log "Before hook" end AfterStep do log "AfterStep hook" end After do log "After hook" raise "error" end """ When I run `cucumber -q -f pretty features/test.feature` Then the stderr should not contain anything Then it should fail with: """ Feature: Scenario: Before hook Given this step passes AfterStep hook After hook error (RuntimeError) ./features/step_definitions/output_steps.rb:11:in `After' Failing Scenarios: cucumber features/test.feature:2 1 scenario (1 failed) 1 step (1 passed) """ </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
matt-SmartBear
2021-05-28 12:54:25

*Thread Reply:* Well, the details of the behaviour of that formatter are down in the unit tests.

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/spec/cucumber/formatter/pretty_spec.rb | pretty_spec.rb>
<p>```</p> <h1>frozen<em>string</em>literal: true</h1> <p>require 'spec<em>helper' require 'cucumber/formatter/spec</em>helper' require 'cucumber/formatter/pretty' require 'cucumber/cli/options'</p> <p>module Cucumber module Formatter describe Pretty do extend SpecHelperDsl include SpecHelper</p> <pre><code> context 'With no options' do before(:each) do Cucumber::Term::ANSIColor.coloring = false @out = StringIO.new @formatter = Pretty.new(actual_runtime.configuration.with_options(out_stream: @out, source: false)) end describe 'given a single feature' do before(:each) do run_defined_feature end describe 'with a scenario' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Banana party Scenario: Monkey eats banana Given there are bananas FEATURE it 'outputs the scenario name' do expect(@out.string).to include 'Scenario: Monkey eats banana' end it 'outputs the step' do expect(@out.string).to include 'Given there are bananas' end end describe 'with a background' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE </code></pre> <p>Feature: Banana party</p> <p>Background: Given a tree</p> <p>Scenario: Monkey eats banana Given there are bananas FEATURE</p> <pre><code> it 'outputs the gherkin' do expect(@out.string).to include(self.class.feature_content) end it 'outputs the scenario name' do expect(@out.string).to include 'Scenario: Monkey eats banana' end it 'outputs the step' do expect(@out.string).to include 'Given there are bananas' end end describe 'with a scenario outline' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Fud Pyramid Scenario Outline: Monkey eats a balanced diet Given there are &amp;lt;Things&amp;gt; Examples: Fruit | Things | | apples | | bananas | Examples: Vegetables | Things | | broccoli | | carrots | FEATURE it 'outputs the scenario outline' do lines = &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-OUTPUT Examples: Fruit | Things | | apples | | bananas | Examples: Vegetables | Things | | broccoli | | carrots | OUTPUT lines.split("\n").each do |line| expect(@out.string).to include line.strip end end it 'has 4 undefined scenarios' do expect(@out.string).to include '4 scenarios (4 undefined)' end it 'has 4 undefined steps' do expect(@out.string).to include '4 steps (4 undefined)' end context 'when the examples table header is wider than the rows' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Monkey Business Scenario Outline: Types of monkey Given there are &amp;lt;Types of monkey&amp;gt; Examples: | Types of monkey | | Hominidae | FEATURE it 'outputs the scenario outline' do lines = &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-OUTPUT Examples: | Types of monkey | | Hominidae | OUTPUT lines.split("\n").each do |line| expect(@out.string).to include line.strip end end end end # To ensure &lt;https://rspec.lighthouseapp.com/projects/16211/tickets/475&gt; remains fixed. describe 'with a scenario outline with a pystring' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Scenario Outline: Monkey eats a balanced diet Given a multiline string: """ Monkeys eat &amp;lt;things&amp;gt; """ Examples: | things | | apples | FEATURE it 'outputs the scenario outline' do lines = &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-OUTPUT Given a multiline string: """ Monkeys eat &amp;lt;things&amp;gt; """ Examples: | things | | apples | OUTPUT lines.split("\n").each do |line| expect(@out.string).to include line.strip end end end describe 'with a step with a py string' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Traveling circus Scenario: Monkey goes to town Given there is a monkey called: """ foo """ FEATURE it 'displays the pystring nested' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT """ foo """ </code></pre> <p>OUTPUT end end</p> <pre><code> describe 'with a multiline step arg' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Traveling circus Scenario: Monkey goes to town Given there are monkeys: | name | | foo | | bar | FEATURE it 'displays the multiline string' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT Given there are monkeys: | name | | foo | | bar | </code></pre> <p>OUTPUT end end</p> <pre><code> describe 'with a table in the background and the scenario' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: accountant monkey Background: Given table: | a | b | | c | d | Scenario: Given another table: | e | f | | g | h | FEATURE it 'displays the table for the background' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT Given table: | a | b | | c | d | </code></pre> <p>OUTPUT end</p> <pre><code> it 'displays the table for the scenario' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT Given another table: | e | f | | g | h | </code></pre> <p>OUTPUT end end</p> <pre><code> describe 'with a py string in the background and the scenario' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: py strings Background: Given stuff: """ foo """ Scenario: Given more stuff: """ bar """ FEATURE it 'displays the background py string' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT Given stuff: """ foo """ </code></pre> <p>OUTPUT end</p> <pre><code> it 'displays the scenario py string' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT Given more stuff: """ bar """ </code></pre> <p>OUTPUT end end</p> <pre><code> describe 'with output from hooks' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Scenario: Given this step passes Scenario Outline: Given this step &amp;lt;status&amp;gt; Examples: | status | | passes | FEATURE define_steps do Before do log 'Before hook' end AfterStep do log 'AfterStep hook' end After do log 'After hook' end Given('this step passes') {} end it 'displays hoâ€¦ </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Matthias Carell
2021-05-31 06:27:35

*Thread Reply:* @matt-SmartBear It doesn't look like as if a quick fix could help here. ðŸ˜‰ Side note: For Senfgurke (my VBA clone) I wrote all the features from scratch because the original ones didn't feel right for me (e.g. missing description, missing rules and more). The report in verbose format feature should be the respective match for the pretty formatter feature. Note that Senfgurke still hasn't support for outline scenarios, so my feature won't tell about it.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-02 18:11:40

*Thread Reply:* Wow that's amazing that you've written a Cucumber for VBA!!!

ðŸ˜Š Matthias Carell
matt-SmartBear
2021-06-02 18:13:30

*Thread Reply:* For what it's worth, Cucumber's own features used to describe the details of the pretty formatter output with lots and lots and lots of scenarios, but we ended up with a "testing ice cream cone" that didn't give us good feedback when we had to TDD fixes to the formatter, and also didn't give us any design feedback about the protocol between the formatters and the rest of the app. So we gradually pushed the tests down to unit tests for all the cases.

Matthias Carell
2021-06-03 03:52:31

*Thread Reply:* Whenever I face the challenge of features with too many scenarios I try to to break it down into another sub-level. For example I started with a single parsesteps feature. When it grew too long I kept the most relevant scenarios in the originale parsesteps feature and moved the other scenarios into parsesteps/parsedocstring feature and parsesteps/parsestep_expression feature (see https://github.com/mckryton/senfgurke/tree/master/features/read_features/parse_features/parse_steps). Rules are essential for this approach. ðŸ˜‰ A nice side effect of this approach is that it works well with the Feature Indexer. This helps me to turn the features into living documentation.

Matthias Carell
2021-06-03 04:07:01

*Thread Reply:* In general I find that it's very difficult just to start a new project with example mapping (or just writing Gherkin scenarios) without any underlying visual map (aka a model for the problem space - not a model for the solution space in DDD terms ðŸ˜‰). I don't have one for Senfgurke, but if I had to draw a customer journey map it would show the touchpoints load features > parse features > run features > report results. I assume if Cucumber would follow such a model it would be more obvious where to align features and architecture.

Automate_Tests
2021-06-23 12:15:53

anyone have experience with running parallel_cucumber and reporting? When I run my tests with --format html --out report.html I see the report getting generated wonkily (looks like each threads tries to write to the same report and messes up the data). I've tried following the instructions at https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/parallel_cucumber. but also no luck. Any suggestions?

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-23 12:56:15

*Thread Reply:* I've not used parallel_cucumber myself so I'm not sure how it works.

FWIW, the HTML formatter works from a standardised message stream these days, so it should be possible to compile a report from across multiple runners. I'm just not sure of how parallel cucumber integrates with Cucumber. If it's just forking processes then I think the behaviour you're observing sounds likely.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-23 12:57:55

*Thread Reply:* Maybe worth asking on their GitHub repo, and see if they want to come over here for a chat? https://github.com/badoo/parallel_cucumber

badoo/parallel_cucumber
Stars
20
Language
Ruby
matt-SmartBear
2021-06-23 12:58:05

*Thread Reply:* (I assume that's the right repo?)

MarkSweetlove
2021-06-23 15:45:03

*Thread Reply:* Usually you can just append an environment variable that parallelcucumber sets to the filename: --format html --out report&lt;%= ENV['TEST_BATCH_ID'] %&gt;.html in the cucumber.yaml file. We use the paralleltests gem, which works very well and that works like this: --format html --out report&lt;%= ENV['ENV_TEST_NUMBER'] %&gt;.html . docs here: https://github.com/grosser/parallel_tests

grosser/parallel_tests
Ruby: 2 CPUs = 2x Testing Speed for RSpec, Test::Unit and Cucumber
Stars
2984
Language
Ruby
Automate_Tests
2021-06-24 06:13:37

*Thread Reply:* thanks for the suggestions. I wonder if by extra execution parameter is messing this up even more, as I'm still not getting any success. My full execution command is parallel_cucumber -n 4 -o "-f pretty -f html -o report.html" features/google_search.feature --group-by scenario

MarkSweetlove
2021-06-24 08:23:16

*Thread Reply:* if you specify the formatters you want in the cucumber.yaml file rather than in the command line then you can append the environment variable to generate multiple reports.

MarkSweetlove
2021-06-24 08:32:44

*Thread Reply:* so your cucumber.yml file would contain: default: -f pretty -f html -o report&lt;%= ENV['ENV_TEST_NUMBER'] %&gt;.html and you would execute on the command line: parallel_cucumber -n 4 features/google_search.feature --group-by scenario

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 12:34:07

*Thread Reply:* thanks, that worked perfectly for me!

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 12:40:03

so, I'm ran into issues trying to get my code to work on a remote hub. After reconfiguring my Before block, I can now run locally or on the remote based on passed in parameters. Unfortunately, the parallel_cucumber command errors out.

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 12:41:23

*Thread Reply:* my code block is below Before do |scenario| browser = (ENV['BROWSER'] || 'chrome') capabilities = case browser when 'firefox' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.firefox when 'edge' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.edge when 'safari' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.safari when 'ie' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.internet_explorer when 'opera' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.opera else Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.chrome end url = nil if ENV['REMOTE'] browser = 'remote'.to_sym url = ENV['REMOTE'] else browser = browser.to_sym end @driver = Selenium::WebDriver.for(browser, url: url, capabilities: capabilities) @wait = Selenium::WebDriver::Wait.new(timeout: 10) end When I run cucumber everything is fine, when I run REMOTE=<http://localhost:4444/wd/hub> cucumber everything is fine

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 12:44:28

*Thread Reply:* but when I run parallel_cucumber -n 4 features/google_search.feature --group-by scenarios or REMOTE=<http://localhost:4444/wd/hub> parallel_cucumber -n 4 features/google_search.feature --group-by scenarios unknown option: {:capabilities=&gt;#&lt;Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities:0x00007fb42a2cee68 @capabilities={:browser_name=&gt;"chrome", :version=&gt;"", :platform=&gt;:any, :javascript_enabled=&gt;true, :css_selectors_enabled=&gt;true, :takes_screenshot=&gt;false, :native_events=&gt;false, :rotatable=&gt;false, :firefox_profile=&gt;nil, :proxy=&gt;nil}&gt;} (ArgumentError)

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 12:45:09

*Thread Reply:* anyone ever run into something like this?

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 12:59:24

*Thread Reply:* as best I can tell it's a problem with my ruby syntax (I'm a java dev), but I can't seem to nail it down

Automate_Tests
2021-06-30 13:44:33

*Thread Reply:* ah, it was my ruby syntax. Got it worked out Before do |scenario| browser = (ENV['BROWSER'] || 'chrome') capabilities = case browser when 'firefox' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.firefox when 'edge' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.edge when 'safari' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.safari when 'ie' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.internet_explorer when 'opera' Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.opera else Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.chrome end url = ENV['REMOTE'] browser = (url ? 'remote' : browser).to_sym @driver = Selenium::WebDriver.for(browser, url: url, capabilities: capabilities) @wait = Selenium::WebDriver::Wait.new(timeout: 10) end

2021-07-05 11:13:21

*Thread Reply:* ðŸŽ‰

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 11:14:05

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 11:15:39

*Thread Reply:* The code is here: https://github.com/cucumber/common/tree/main/react/javascript

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 11:16:19

*Thread Reply:* We use a set of React components to render the HTML report from some NDJSON messages emitted by Cucumber as it runs.

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 11:17:31

*Thread Reply:* Maybe the problem is in here? https://github.com/cucumber/common/blob/main/react/javascript/test/components/gherkin/AttachmentTest.tsx

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/blob/main/react/javascript/test/components/gherkin/AttachmentTest.tsx | AttachmentTest.tsx>
<pre><code>import React from 'react' import Attachment from '../../../src/components/gherkin/Attachment' import ** as messages from '@cucumber/messages' import assert from 'assert' import { render } from '../utils' describe('&amp;lt;Attachment&amp;gt;', () =&amp;gt; { it('renders an image', () =&amp;gt; { const binary = new Uint8Array(10) binary.fill(255, 0, binary.length) const attachment: messages.Attachment = { mediaType: 'image/png', body: 'fake-base64', contentEncoding: messages.AttachmentContentEncoding.BASE64, } const { container } = render(&amp;lt;Attachment attachment={attachment} /&amp;gt;) const img = container.querySelector('img') assert.strictEqual(img.getAttribute('src'), 'data:image/png;base64,fake-base64') }) it('renders base64 encoded plaintext', () =&amp;gt; { const attachment: messages.Attachment = { mediaType: 'text/plain', body: Buffer.from('hello').toString('base64'), contentEncoding: messages.AttachmentContentEncoding.BASE64, } const { container } = render(&amp;lt;Attachment attachment={attachment} /&amp;gt;) const pre = container.querySelector('pre') assert.strictEqual(pre.textContent, 'hello') }) it('correctly renders ANSI characters', () =&amp;gt; { const attachment: messages.Attachment = { mediaType: 'text/x.cucumber.log+plain', body: '\x1b[30mblack\x1b[37mwhite', contentEncoding: messages.AttachmentContentEncoding.IDENTITY, } const { container } = render(&amp;lt;Attachment attachment={attachment} /&amp;gt;) const span = container.querySelector('pre &amp;gt; span') assert.strictEqual( span.innerHTML, '&amp;lt;span style="color:#000"&amp;gt;black&amp;lt;span style="color:#AAA"&amp;gt;white&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/span&amp;gt;' ) }) }) </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>
matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 11:17:40

*Thread Reply:* @David Goss knows this code pretty well

David Goss
2021-07-06 00:27:45

*Thread Reply:* Looking at the screenshots, cucumber-ruby might not be using the latest html-formatter. I'm fairly sure it doesn't do that now. To check though, are you able to upload the output of the message formatter for same/similar test run? We can then feed that into the test harness and see how it's coming out.

Oscar Barrios
2021-07-06 00:40:39

2021-07-06 00:40:56

<p>so, I'm ran into issues trying to get my code to work on a remote hub. After reconfiguring my <code>Before</code> block, I can now run locally or on the remote based on passed in parameters. Unfortunately, the <code>parallel_cucumber</code> command errors out.</p>

Thread in Slack Conversation
Automate_Tests
2021-07-08 11:21:11

*Thread Reply:* I don't see a lot of information, or whats to troubleshoot this, so any pointers would be wonderful

Automate_Tests
2021-07-08 11:21:46

*Thread Reply:* clearly something in my instantiation of the driver is a problem, i just don't know what

AurÃ©lien Reeves
2021-07-08 23:45:08

*Thread Reply:* Disclaimer: I do not know selenium ðŸ˜›

From what I can see in the doc here, there is no :capabilities argument but a desired_capabilities: one.

Also it seems to be required with a remote browser only. From what I can see in your code, you set those desired capabilities also for local browser, which is not required. It leads into difficulties into reading your snippet - I had to dig to understand what it does - and maybe it can causes issues.

luke
2021-07-09 01:26:38

*Thread Reply:* I've done a lot of work with selenium recently, I commit and fix some stuff there. Are you using a v4 driver or a v3 driver.

luke
2021-07-09 01:26:56

*Thread Reply:* Also I'm working on creating some auto-working drivers - in an open source repo here

www.github.com/citizensadvice/ca_testing/

Automate_Tests
2021-07-09 18:54:03

*Thread Reply:* v3, and yes, thanks @AurÃ©lien Reeves. that was it. I was using capabilities instead of desired_capabilities. the error now also makes sense

Automate_Tests
2021-07-09 18:54:06

*Thread Reply:* thanks so much!!!

yosukei3108
2021-07-10 20:42:33

@yosukei3108 has joined the channel

luke
2021-07-14 02:15:03

What ways have people structured parallelising stuff using jenkins in terms of reconciling the reports. I'm about to start experimenting with using more executors. But I know that since each executor will only a fraction of the tests, I'll end up with 4 html reports not one.

Automate_Tests
2021-07-14 04:20:26

*Thread Reply:* I used report builder to handle this. First off, I setup Selenium Grid to handle my tests in parallel using helm, and i saved all my reports to the reports directory. My jenkins code: try { sh "ENVIRONMENT=${environment} REMOTE=${grid-locastion}/wd/hub parallel_cucumber -n 10 ${features} --group-by scenarios" } finally { // save off our junit reports junit 'reports/junit****/**.xml' // build and collect our cucumber reports sh 'report_builder -s reports -o reports/index' publishHTML([ allowMissing : false, alwaysLinkToLastBuild: true, keepAll : true, reportDir : 'reports', reportFiles : 'index.html', reportName : 'Acceptance Test Report' ]) }

â¤ï¸ matt-SmartBear
luke
2021-07-16 03:00:31

*Thread Reply:* but hang on, you're using parallel cucumber, which won't then consume parallel executors on jenkins right? That uses the same jenkins executor but multiple threads inside it

Or am I wrong?

luke
2021-07-16 03:00:52

*Thread Reply:* Also you've not mentioned where report builder comes from?

luke
2021-07-29 06:53:49

*Thread Reply:* Hi there @Automate_Tests any updates on this? Coming round to this again, was wondering if you knew how to tackle this without me digging in too much

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:19:43

*Thread Reply:* sorry, I didn't see this thread. So, to your first question, yes, parallelcucumber uses threads within the same executor, not separate executors. I don't know why you'd want separate executors. That said, since I'm running everything through Selenium Grid, THOSE nodes are their own executors (I have a k8s setup to handle and scale this) For the logs, I'm just using the reportbuilder gem, which takes all reports from a folder and creates one nice one. I just added the gem to my Gemfile, and run bundle install before executing my tests. My cucumber.yml handles all of my outputs ```# config/cucumber.yaml

<% testbatchid = "#{ENV['TESTENVNUMBER']}" %>

default: > --publish-quiet --format pretty --format json --out reports/report<%= ENV['TESTENVNUMBER'] %>.json --format html --out reports/report<%= ENV['TESTENVNUMBER'] %>.html --format junit --out reports/junit<%= ENV['TESTENV_NUMBER'] %>/```

luke
2021-07-29 07:23:25

*Thread Reply:* Because that's the way jenkins runs. As the individual executors allow you to parallelise on multiple machines.

luke
2021-07-29 07:23:58

*Thread Reply:* parallel cucumber and other items are design to be ran on physical machines, not virtual machines. Consequently upping the core count and parallelism in that situation will just kill the nodes.

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:26:21

*Thread Reply:* not if you use selenium grid

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:26:44

*Thread Reply:* because those nodes are elsewhere

luke
2021-07-29 07:26:58

*Thread Reply:* yes but those nodes are also virtual machines, so running a higher core count won't help.

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:27:38

*Thread Reply:* depends on your setup. I am running everything in EKS, so scaling is trivial for us. Add more nodes, more machines come up as needed to support it

luke
2021-07-29 07:27:57

*Thread Reply:* yes we run in Amazon containers too, but we have to spin them up inside our jenkins invocations.

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:28:00

*Thread Reply:* it sounds like your real problem is your infrastructure

luke
2021-07-29 07:28:14

*Thread Reply:* not really, our infra is fine, we just spin up more virtual machines as/when required.

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:28:47

*Thread Reply:* so then what is the problem? you need to run more tests in parallel, you can spin up more machines?

luke
2021-07-29 07:29:00

*Thread Reply:* yes, and so we spin up more virtual machines.

luke
2021-07-29 07:29:08

*Thread Reply:* so we go from having 1 machine running 100% of the tests, producing 1 report.

luke
2021-07-29 07:29:16

*Thread Reply:* to 2 machines running 50% of the tests each, producing 2 reports.

luke
2021-07-29 07:29:49

*Thread Reply:* I've got a problem first trying to get both reports to save (This is proving problematic). Then once I have that, then I'll want to amalgamate them

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:31:21

*Thread Reply:* so, with my setup, one machine will launch all the tests, and no matter where they run, all the reports come back to the same machine. That's how both parallelcucumber and grid are setup. I have multiple reports in one folder, on one machine, and then reportsbuilder creates one report

luke
2021-07-29 07:32:26

*Thread Reply:* right yeh that's the issue then, so you've got a clever setup whereby all of the runs on all of the vms send their reports back to your one machine, so your solution is trivial.

Automate_Tests
2021-07-29 07:35:58

*Thread Reply:* it's just a default setup. I'm happy to share more of it if it'll help

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-16 01:19:21

@Daniel Vartanov has joined the channel

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-16 01:21:11

Hi everyone. I'm running scenarios with non-headless browser and thinking of having a step like Then I stop until further notice, i.e. a step which would halt the flow of scenario so that I could inspect the browser contents for debugging purposes. Any idea how to do that? I tried gets but it did not stop, perhaps Cucumber hijacks STDIN?

luke
2021-07-16 02:45:09

I don't "believe" it does. But that's a valid question.

Whilst I'm not answering the question the way you want, you should just use something like RubyMine IDE or byebug

luke
2021-07-16 02:45:15

I am now going to try it though!

luke
2021-07-16 02:51:27

so when I ran regular gets using RubyMine it was hijacked by cucumber. But looking into it, it's because rubymine was passing a truckload of stuff magically to the cmdline

luke
2021-07-16 02:51:37

Kernel.gets was the same. STDIN.gets did stop for me.

luke
2021-07-16 02:55:43

so yeh basically the issue you described, But I'd just use the rm debugger or byebug

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-16 03:15:28

Right, it seems like gets and puts are overrided, but STDIN.gets indeed worked as expected, thank you!

luke
2021-07-16 03:19:22

because those use Kernel commands, which might be why.

But yeh back to my original point. If you wanna live inspect, please please please don't do this, use byebug or rubymine debugger.

luke
2021-07-16 03:19:28

as you can do live inspect AND code execution

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-16 03:37:58

Good point, I better switch to just running a debugger

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-16 03:45:42

@luke hum, you know what, there turned out to be a difference. When I run STDIN.gets, the server continues to work, i.e. in browser I can browse, play with the ap and click everywhere, even though I an in the middle of a cucumber scenario paused by STDIN.gets, while when I do byebug the server stops, sometimes even before the async part of the previous step is done. I wonder why is that? Isn't Puma run in a separate process? How come byebug can impact a child process? I am confused what is happening

luke
2021-07-16 03:51:56

byebug is designed to stop the current active thread so you can play about in the current state. If you use RubyMine's debugger I (believe), that it continues all other processes.

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-16 04:00:36

Waiting for input stops the active thread too, but only the active thread. I am in doubt how it could stop Puma as well.

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-16 11:45:07

We used to have an ask helper method in the world by default. Is it still there?

Daniel Vartanov
2021-07-17 01:35:45

@matt-SmartBear yes, ask worked, thanks, I didn't know about it. It's good that it does not block the server either. Why though byebug stops the execution of the server code?

Charlan Bettiol
2021-09-02 13:43:25

Good afternoon, folks I have a problem, I would like to know if it would be possible for the cucumber or parallel cucumber to return the output code as 0 even if there are failed scenarios in the execution of the tests?

AurÃ©lien Reeves
2021-09-02 13:48:44

*Thread Reply:* Hi,

I'm not sure that is possible without an external script like a bash script, or a ruby script that would wrap the execution of cucumber

Why would you like to do so? What do you need to achieve exactly?

Charlan Bettiol
2021-09-02 13:50:58

*Thread Reply:* We have jobs on jenkins, and for some reason the parallel broke either due to lack of memory or another error, and when that happens the job is not failed, to solve this in the execution of the rake command I used system(command, exception:true) so any return that is different from 0 on executions is considered an error by the jenkins job.

Aslak HellesÃ¸y
2021-09-03 01:38:08

*Thread Reply:* If you want the build to pass when there are failures, what value do you get from running the tests in CI?

luke
2021-09-03 02:02:17

*Thread Reply:* So I've recently migrated to using parallel cucumber. We previously used rake tasks. You can't do this with parallel cucumber, so check you've unpicked your tasks first into their constituent parts.

luke
2021-09-03 02:02:44

*Thread Reply:* We always used to use system commands also, but yeh you need to use raw cucumber when using the parallel tests gem

Charlan Bettiol
2021-09-03 04:11:46

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak HellesÃ¸y failed tests are stored so that in the next iteration they are counted in the dryrun for rerun.

<https://github.com/rajatthareja/ReportBuilder/issues/98|#98 Embedded reports broken with image/png ("\\x89" from ASCII-8BIT to UTF-8 )>
<p>I'm getting encoding error while build a single report json file from a parallel execution with image/png embedded images.</p> <pre><code>/usr/local/bundle/gems/json-2.5.1/lib/json/common.rb:406:in `generate': "\\x89" from ASCII-8BIT to UTF-8 (Encoding::UndefinedConversionError) from /usr/local/bundle/gems/json-2.5.1/lib/json/common.rb:406:in `pretty_generate' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/report_builder-1.9/lib/report_builder/builder.rb:27:in `block in build_report' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/report_builder-1.9/lib/report_builder/builder.rb:26:in `open' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/report_builder-1.9/lib/report_builder/builder.rb:26:in `build_report' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/report_builder-1.9/lib/report_builder.rb:76:in `build_report' </code></pre> <p>My code:</p> <pre><code>page.save_screenshot(screenshot) attach(screenshot, 'image/png') </code></pre> <p>Already tried to change to base64 images, but after that CucumberReports not supported the mime type of the file.</p>

2021-10-18 08:34:40

You can add folders in there for your actions / tasks.

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-16 16:11:47

I've never used parallel testing - I prefer other ways to optimise my tests - but I've heard of others using the parallel_tests gem in Ruby I think?

luke
2021-11-17 06:00:49

Yip. I also pushed in a bugfix to that in 3.7.1 so I'm now more biased to it ðŸ˜„

phebus
2021-11-17 07:04:43

i hear about this screenplay pattern a lot. anyone have a good definitive rundown of what it is and whatâ€™s involved? iâ€™m at the point where i feel like iâ€™m in a rut with my approach

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:16:40

*Thread Reply:* I've written a few blog posts, let me find them

Danny Barrientos
2021-11-17 07:16:48

*Thread Reply:* https://cucumber.io/blog/bdd/understanding-screenplay-(part-1)/

SmartBear.com
Understanding Screenplay (part #1)
Once you've decided to invest in test automation, sooner or later you'll begin to realise that you need to care about the maintainability of that test automation code just as much as you do about the implementation code itself. Having tried several different approaches myself over the years, I've come to believe that the Screenplay pattern is the best technique we have today.
Original URL: https://cucumber.io/blog/bdd/understanding-screenplay-(part-1)/
matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:17:07

*Thread Reply:* ðŸŽ‰ you beat me to it Danny!

ðŸ˜„ Danny Barrientos
matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:17:53

*Thread Reply:* Those examples are in JS but it's pretty simple code to translate

Danny Barrientos
2021-11-17 07:23:18

*Thread Reply:* â€œIâ€™ve come to believe thatÂ the Screenplay patternÂ is the best technique we have today.â€ The Screenplay Pattern uses an actor-centric model This one diagram https://serenity-bdd.github.io/theserenitybook/latest/serenity-screenplay.html#fig-journey-actors

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:27:30

*Thread Reply:* There's links out to the original source material from Anthony Marcano and others

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:27:42

*Thread Reply:* I've always found that stuff a bit hard to follow which is why I wrote the blog posts

phebus
2021-11-17 07:29:32

*Thread Reply:* awesome thanks so much yall!

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:29:36

*Thread Reply:* The core idea of the pattern is that you represent every "action" against the system as an object, with a consistent API that inverts the dependencies on the things your automation needs to operate with.

Danny Barrientos
2021-11-17 07:30:48

*Thread Reply:* If I want to implement this pattern, but using Ruby, how can I do it? What strategy should I follow?

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:32:45

*Thread Reply:* I would start by factoring out those objects

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:36:19

*Thread Reply:* So if you have a helper method like this:

def log_in_as(username) @browser.click_on 'Log in' @browser.fill_in 'username', with: username @browser.fill_in 'password', with: 'password' @browser.click 'Log in' end You would refactor it into an object:

```class Login def self.as(username) def end

def initialize(username) @username = username end

def attempt(browser) browser.clickon 'Log in' browser.fillin 'username', with: @username browser.fill_in 'password', with: 'password' browser.click 'Log in' end end```

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:36:45

*Thread Reply:* Now you can invoke it like this from your steps:

<a href="http://Login.as">Login.as</a>('matt').attempt(@browser)

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:36:59

*Thread Reply:* Instead of calling your old helper method.

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:37:24

*Thread Reply:* Eventually, as you have moved more of your automation actions into this pattern, you can start to give the work of actually attempting them to Actor objects.

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:38:11

*Thread Reply:* The point is to unite all of your actions around this 'attempt' API call. So when they all have that same API, you can pass them around as lists of things to do, and have something that doesn't know what they specifically do invoke them.

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:38:16

*Thread Reply:* Or nest them

Danny Barrientos
2021-11-17 07:42:42

*Thread Reply:* If I want to run the same scenario several times, how would you save these results, what should I do in this case?

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:43:00

*Thread Reply:* That doesn't really have anything to do with screenplay

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:43:41

*Thread Reply:* This is just a pattern for organising your automation code

phebus
2021-11-17 07:44:53

*Thread Reply:* interesting. based on that example i actually have kind of implemented a bit of screenplay with some actions classes but not proper. definitely going to dig into this a bit. really appreciate the info

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:49:59

*Thread Reply:* Great! I'd love to see what you come up with @phebus. We need more knowledge pooling in this area I think.

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-17 07:50:14

*Thread Reply:* (that's why I wrote the blog posts!)

Failed to open TCP connection to 127.0.0.1:9518 (Connection refused - connect(2) for "127.0.0.1" port 9518), Falha ao capturar log do browser, Failed to open TCP connection to 127.0.0.1:9518 (Connection refused - connect(2) for "127.0.0.1" port 9518), /usr/local/bundle/gems/socksify-1.7.1/lib/socksify.rb:178:in `initialize': Failed to open TCP connection to 127.0.0.1:9518 (Connection refused - connect(2) for "127.0.0.1" port 9518) (Errno::ECONNREFUSED) from /usr/local/bundle/gems/socksify-1.7.1/lib/socksify.rb:178:in `initialize' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/net/http.rb:960:in `open' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/net/http.rb:960:in `block in connect' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/timeout.rb:95:in `block in timeout' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/timeout.rb:105:in `timeout' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/net/http.rb:958:in `connect' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/net/http.rb:1567:in `begin_transport' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/net/http.rb:1518:in `transport_request' from /usr/local/lib/ruby/2.7.0/net/http.rb:1492:in `request' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/selenium-webdriver-4.1.0/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/default.rb:124:in `response_for' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/selenium-webdriver-4.1.0/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/default.rb:77:in `request' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/selenium-webdriver-4.1.0/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/common.rb:59:in `call' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/selenium-webdriver-4.1.0/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/bridge.rb:588:in `execute' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/selenium-webdriver-4.1.0/lib/selenium/webdriver/chrome/features.rb:95:in `log' from /usr/local/bundle/gems/selenium-webdriver-4.1.0/lib/selenium/webdriver/common/logs.rb:32:in `get' from /automation/automation-code/workspace/automation-store/features/support/hooks.rb:55:in `add_browser_logs'

AurÃ©lien Reeves
2022-01-06 00:27:44

*Thread Reply:* Maybe something related to the following: https://swdandruby.wordpress.com/2013/05/11/headless-gem-causes-errnoeconnrefused/?

Selenium WebDriver and Ruby
bgoad (https://swdandruby.wordpress.com/author/bgoadrn/)
Headless Gem causes Errno::ECONNREFUSED
Have you ever gotten this error while trying to run simultaneous headless Firefox instances of WebDriver? Errno::ECONNREFUSED: Connection refused - connect(2) /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:762:in `initialize' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:762:in `open' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:762:in `block in connect' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/timeout.rb:54:in `timeout' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/timeout.rb:99:in `timeout' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:762:in `connect' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:755:in `do_start' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:744:in `start' /home/site/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p385/lib/ruby/1.9.1/net/http.rb:1284:in `request' This one was plaguing me for a while. I could not understand why Firefox could not run separate instances of itself, when&nbsp;the SWD documentation&nbsp;indicated that each run used an entirely separate temporary Firefox profile, and so the instances would not conflict with each other. But sure enough, if I started another job while one was already running, I would get the above error on the first job, while the second job hijacked the connection. After really delving into the issue, I finally realized that the issue was not the Firefox profiles conflicting. Instead, the issues came from my usage of the&nbsp;headless gem&nbsp;to run the jobs&nbsp;headlessly&nbsp;using&nbsp;Xvfb. I was not defining a specific display to use when my scripts ran, and so the headless gem would default to using the&nbsp;:99&nbsp;display. This was all fine and good when running the scripts individually. But if you run multiple scripts that try to use the same display, the first script gets disconnected from the headless session and the second script takes over. The solution to this problem is to explicitly define a display number to use for each script that runs. This works especially well if you are running your scripts in a CI environment like Jenkins, where each build is given its own number that you can easily access as an environmental variable such as &ldquo;BUILD_NUMBER&rdquo;. Other ideas are to generate a random display number on the fly, or use another means to generate any integer number. display = ENV['BUILD_NUMBER'] || "99" @headless = Headless.new(:display =&gt; display) @headless.start This will generate a headless session on the display number that is defined by the BUILD_NUMBER environmental variable, and as long as the build numbers are completely different from each other, you will be good.
Original URL: https://swdandruby.wordpress.com/2013/05/11/headless-gem-causes-errnoeconnrefused/
ðŸ‘€ Bruno Ribeiro

  sleep 1
end

rescue StandardError => e raise e end And how the call is made: await(5) { $examplepages.something.hash1_title? }``` Do you guys have any idea what it could be?

AurÃ©lien Reeves
2022-01-25 00:28:12

*Thread Reply:* It really looks like there is an issue related to the browser and some asynchronous things. How do you process async execution? I see you have a yield. Do you rely on promises or async/await? Or something else?

This is hardly related to cucumber. You may have more luck into looking for some help with capybara and/or parallel_tests folks.

However, we can still try to help of course. For this, could you share a little bit of your code? Do you think you could setup a public minimal reproducible example?

Charlan Bettiol
2022-03-11 09:30:16

*Thread Reply:* Good afternoon everyone, how are you? we discovered the problem we identified that in the after-scenario at the end of it the driver was being terminated and not just the session with the following code:Capybara.current_session.driver.quit we solved it just by restarting the driver session, thank you very much for your help! solution:Capybara.reset_sessions!

matt-SmartBear
2022-02-03 10:57:51

*Thread Reply:* We have something similar in the Docker image we use for testing some of our libraries. That's working for M1 as well as linux.

https://github.com/cucumber/build

The Makefile calls docker to generate different platform images: https://github.com/cucumber/build/blob/main/Makefile

and we use this script from the Dockerfile to install chromium: https://github.com/cucumber/build/blob/main/Dockerfile#L181 https://github.com/cucumber/build/blob/main/scripts/install-chromium.sh

Does that help?!

2022-02-03 10:45:00

Lean
2022-02-03 10:49:37

ðŸ‘ Fabricio Bedin
AurÃ©lien Reeves
2022-02-04 01:10:37

*Thread Reply:* Here's the code in cucumber-ruby which manage the report: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/formatter/http_io.rb

The first request to https://messages.cucumber.io/api/reports is a GET request. It should reply with a response "redirect" with a "location" in the headers where to PUT the report: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/formatter/http_io.rb#L127

Then the response from that PUT request should contain the public url for your report

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/formatter/http_io.rb | http_io.rb>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/formatter/http_io.rb | http_io.rb>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
âœ… Lean

AurÃ©lien Reeves
2022-02-08 00:17:40

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the info.

So, yes, indeed the attachments are all at the bottom of the html formatter.

You can open an issue/feature request here I guess: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react

But there's a catch: how to manage attachments to backgrounds? At the moment, those attachments are part of the scenario with the other attachments. If some changes are made to bring step attachments near their steps, the ones within the background won't be seen on the scenario level, but all attachments will be grouped at the "Background" section. I think that may be more of an issue than an improvement actually ðŸ¤”

cucumber/cucumber-react
React components for Cucumber

MarkSweetlove
2022-02-12 03:24:42

Happy Saturday everyone. I am trying to upgrade from 3.2 to 7.1 of the Cucumber ruby gem. In the former version i specified World(Pages) in world.rb in the support folder and was able to use methods from my pages module (all files in support/pages) in my step defs. After the upgrade I get the message: Code: ** features/support/env.rb ** features/support/world.rb uninitialized constant Pages (NameError) Is there something I need to do differently? Is it just files loading in the wrong order?

phebus
2022-02-14 07:23:56

*Thread Reply:* yeah they introduced a new loader in 4 so it â€œbrokeâ€ the unintended alphabetical loading that was happening before. i had to put Dir["#{File.dirname(__FILE__)}/****/**.rb"].sort.each { |f| require f } in env.rb to remedy this in my framework

MarkSweetlove
2022-02-14 07:40:00

*Thread Reply:* Ah that makes sense. Thanks! Iâ€™ll do something similar to that I think.

luke
2022-02-16 09:35:35

*Thread Reply:* there is also a legacy mode for this ^^

luke
2022-02-16 09:35:49

*Thread Reply:* Cucumber.use_legacy_autoloader

luke
2022-02-16 09:36:25

*Thread Reply:* As for the Code messages, this is something Jetbrains did recently, we have some proper oldschool code from cucumber 1 or so we need to delete. This is a combination of cucumber and jetbrains working in a way we didn't intend.

luke
2022-02-16 09:37:05

*Thread Reply:* FYI you should "never" depend on the order of an autoloader.

If you have items that are dependent, physically require the items in a specific order. That's what env.rb is designed for.

MarkSweetlove
2022-02-16 14:52:00

*Thread Reply:* Understood, i am specifying them in the env.rb now.

MarkSweetlove
2022-02-16 14:52:09

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for your help

luke
2022-02-17 09:32:09

*Thread Reply:* no probs. So for example, I specify all my section objects in the env.rb file (or a file associated from there). I don't bother with page objects, because the order doesn't matter there.

Oscar Barrios
2022-02-15 05:40:30

Oscar Barrios
2022-02-16 01:58:35

Matthias Carell
2022-02-16 04:59:18

Oscar Barrios
2022-02-16 05:59:36

Matthias Carell
2022-02-16 07:20:59

luke
2022-02-16 09:34:03

*Thread Reply:* So remember not to conflate the two items here.

the log method by default is not a traditional logger. It is a way of attaching a Cucumber Message to the output stream.

The logger is a ruby utility which is very common to log messages to a location. My logger I use at work is as follows

```# frozenstringliteral: true

class AutomationLogger class << self extend Forwardable include Helpers::EnvVariables

def_delegators :logger, :debug, :info, :warn, :error, :fatal, :unknown

def logger
  @logger ||= create_logger
end

private

def create_logger
  ::Logger.new(name, logs_to_keep, size_of_log).tap do |logger|
    logger.progname = 'AutomationLogger'
    logger.level = log_level
    logger.formatter = proc do |severity, time, progname, msg|
      "#{time.strftime('%F %T')} - #{severity} - #{progname} - #{msg}\n"
    end
  end
end

def name
  Pathname.new('tmp/logs') + log_filename
end

def logs_to_keep
  7
end

def size_of_log
  1_048_576
end

end end```

Oscar Barrios
2022-02-17 00:25:21

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I'm tempted to do my own logger on top of Cucumber log method, I was just curious if that was planned for a future version or if already existed

luke
2022-02-17 09:31:36

*Thread Reply:* Please don't. It's not required / advisable.

If you want to log messages ask yourself how/where you want to log them

â€¢ Want them on a report / html file / json stream - use the Worldable log method. â€¢ Want differing levels of granularity to error report during your code execution. Use the ruby Logger class. it comes with 6 differing levels of granularity and is customisable out of the box.

Oscar Barrios
2022-02-18 00:45:32

*Thread Reply:* My squad, only use the HTML report in order to review our CT. I want a mechanism to provide more or less log details in the HTML report, parameterizing our Jenkins Pipeline. Logger will not embed the information inside the scenario on the report, also I don't want to handle two different kind of loggers. If Cucumber-Ruby don't provide more granularity in log method, don't have plans to improve on that area and even discourage that idea, I don't see why I can not wrap it and do it by ourselves ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸ At the end, every project has their own needs.

luke
2022-02-28 01:11:34

*Thread Reply:* in ruby the standard is to use an instance of the ruby logger. and then call that with the relevant severity method i.e. log.debug('debug msg') or log.error('error msg')

If you want them embedding on the report use the log message protocol
