*Thread Reply:* For what it's worth in case anybody comes looking for an answer. I didn't find any easy solution so I reverted and implemented this gem instead: https://github.com/dvla/dvla-reportportal-ruby

Originally I was to use the gem as departing point to get to where I was going, but then realized Reporting Portal actually was useful, so we went ahead and used it as is.

Steve Kirkland

Could you just record a start time in the Before , in the most basic form:

  $scenario_start = Time.now
en

and then: After do |scenario| duration = Time.now - $scenario_start scenario.fail "Scenario took too long #(duration)s" if duration &gt; 120 end

*Thread Reply:* Ideally we'd have a failing acceptance test in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/1ecac4626cb238db17cb8b11791a32ff491[â€¦]3/features/docs/writingsupportcode/hooks/around_hooks.feature, but we can work towards that if we have a simple example that charaterises the problem.

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/1ecac4626cb238db17cb8b11791a32ff4919c7a3/features/docs/writing_support_code/hooks/around_hooks.feature | around_hooks.feature>
<pre><code>Feature: Around hooks In order to support transactional scenarios for database libraries that provide only a block syntax for transactions, Cucumber should permit definition of Around hooks. Background: Given a file named "features/support/env.rb" with: """ module HookLoggerWorld def logged_hooks @logged_hooks ||= [] end def log_hook(name) logged_hooks &amp;lt;&amp;lt; name end end World(HookLoggerWorld) """ Scenario: A single Around hook Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Then /^the hook is called$/ do expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['Around']) end """ And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with: """ Around do |scenario, block| log_hook('Around') block.call end """ And a file named "features/f.feature" with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: using hook Then the hook is called """ When I run `cucumber features/f.feature` Then it should pass with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: using hook # features/f.feature:2 Then the hook is called # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1 1 scenario (1 passed) 1 step (1 passed) """ Scenario: Multiple Around hooks Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Then /^the hooks are called in the correct order$/ do expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['A', 'B', 'C']) end """ And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with: """ Around do |scenario, block| log_hook('A') block.call end Around do |scenario, block| log_hook('B') block.call end Around do |scenario, block| log_hook('C') block.call end """ And a file named "features/f.feature" with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: using multiple hooks Then the hooks are called in the correct order """ When I run `cucumber features/f.feature` Then it should pass with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: using multiple hooks # features/f.feature:2 Then the hooks are called in the correct order # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1 1 scenario (1 passed) 1 step (1 passed) """ Scenario: Mixing Around, Before, and After hooks Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Then /^the Around hook is called around Before and After hooks$/ do expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['Around', 'Before']) end """ And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with: """ Around do |scenario, block| log_hook 'Around' block.call log_hook 'Around' expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['Around', 'Before', 'After', 'Around']) end Before do |scenario| log_hook 'Before' end After do |scenario| log_hook 'After' expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['Around', 'Before', 'After']) end """ And a file named "features/f.feature" with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: Mixing Around, Before, and After hooks Then the Around hook is called around Before and After hooks """ When I run `cucumber features/f.feature` Then it should pass with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: Mixing Around, Before, and After hooks # features/f.feature:2 Then the Around hook is called around Before and After hooks # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1 1 scenario (1 passed) 1 step (1 passed) """ Scenario: Around hooks with tags Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Then /^the Around hooks with matching tags are called$/ do expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['one', 'one or two']) end """ And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with: """ Around('@one') do |scenario, block| log_hook('one') block.call end Around('@one or @two') do |scenario, block| log_hook('one or two') block.call end Around('@one and @two') do |scenario, block| log_hook('one and two') block.call end Around('@two') do |scenario, block| log_hook('two') block.call end """ And a file named "features/f.feature" with: """ Feature: Around hooks @one Scenario: Around hooks with tags Then the Around hooks with matching tags are called """ When I run `cucumber -q -t @one features/f.feature` Then it should pass with: """ Feature: Around hooks @one Scenario: Around hooks with tags Then the Around hooks with matching tags are called 1 scenario (1 passed) 1 step (1 passed) """ Scenario: Around hooks with scenario outlines Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Then /^the hook is called$/ do expect(logged_hooks).to eq(['Around']) end """ And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with: """ Around do |scenario, block| log_hook('Around') block.call end """ And a file named "features/f.feature" with: """ Feature: Around hooks with scenario outlines Scenario Outline: using hook Then the hook is called Examples: | Number | | one | | two | """ When I run `cucumber features/f.feature` Then it should pass with: """ Feature: Around hooks with scenario outlines Scenario Outline: using hook # features/f.feature:2 Then the hook is called # features/f.feature:3 Examples: | Number | | one | | two | 2 scenarios (2 passed) 2 steps (2 passed) """ Scenario: Around Hooks and the Custom World Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Then /^the world should be available in the hook$/ do $previous_world = self expect($hook_world).to eq(self) end Then /^what$/ do expect($hook_world).not_to eq($previous_world) end """ And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with: """ Around do |scenario, block| $hook_world = self block.call end """ And a file named "features/f.feature" with: """ Feature: Around hooks Scenario: using hook Then the world should be available in the hook Scenario: using the same hook Then what """ When I run `cucumber features/f.feature` Then it should pass </code></pre>

*Thread Reply:* done here it is https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1623

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1623|#1623 When the automation fails to run in Around, the cucumber report is not mounted correctly>
<p>I have a problem that when we fail to run the automation directly on Around inside hooks.rb when generating the final cucumber report when there is a background and more than one scenario, the subsequent scenarios do not generate the failure information.</p> <p>In the example to be reproduced we have an infinite loop in the execution and in Around we have a timeout defined for the execution block, when reaching this time each scenario should fail correctly collecting all the error data but it only happens in the first scenario. in the case of this example project, in the main project, the cucumber report doesn't even fail, leaving it as passed but without any scenario information</p> <p><a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86666227/162947845-5398d16f-80dd-46d7-b734-12a7134823ad.png">image</a></p> <p>To Reproduce<br /> Steps to reproduce the behavior:<br /> 1 - Clone de Project: </p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/T00595/RubyTest">Project</a></h2> <p>2- Just run a comand <code>cucumber</code>, the existing tests will be executed and at the end the report will be presented that can be verified with the second scenario without information</p> <p>Expected behavior</p> <p>When failing Around with features with backgroud and various scenarios the final report is assembled correctly.</p> <p>Additional context</p> <p>The time out is here <a href="https://github.com/T00595/RubyTest/blob/8905ebf3125327981766cf2ba95aed3083681482/features/support/hooks.rb#L30">TImeout</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

luke
2022-04-12 01:31:37

@matt-SmartBear our around hook is notoriously flaky, and we want to remove it. The problem is the "ruby" concept of around makes sense, but the universal one less so.

Also we've got 3/4 long-standing issues, so it's likely we'll try kill it.

Charlan Bettiol

*Thread Reply:* yes but in this case as it is in a farm it closes the application but the farm does not return that the application was closed

Charlan Bettiol
2022-04-12 13:10:12

About my timeout problem I managed to solve it in a different way for those who want to know, I created a parallel thread running just to count the execution time and expire the entire execution when it reaches the value I passed, I call it in before and if it doesn't reach the time, I finish it in the after: $thr = Thread.new do Timeout.timeout(time) do sleep time + 1 abort("#{time / 60} MINUTES REACHED FAILING SCENARIO!") end end

ðŸ‘:skin_tone_2: matt-SmartBear
luke
2022-04-13 09:15:19

Timeout.timeout is pretty much the worst ever open secret in ruby. Please avoid using it in 99.99999999% of situations.

Charlan Bettiol
2022-04-13 09:21:24

*Thread Reply:* I used times, x.times do sleep end

was using the usage formatter to find steps that are no longer used and iâ€™ve found the output is nil for any non-regex style steps when it tries to output the step from the step definition file but outputs the step wording fine from the feature itself (or correctly marks it as NOT MATCHED). this is making it hard for me to clean up any new string style steps. not sure if this is a known issue but didnâ€™t find one in the issue tracker. iâ€™d be glad to try to take a wack at fixing as well but wanted to drop it here first

2022-05-19 11:45:26

  NOT MATCHED BY ANY STEPS

  NOT MATCHED BY ANY STEP

phebus
2022-05-19 13:32:15

*Thread Reply:* i have a fix for this and will attempt to put in a pr

phebus
2022-05-19 13:37:09

*Thread Reply:* itâ€™s in the cucumber-expressions gem but iâ€™m not sure where thatâ€™s sourced (broken links in rubygems)

phebus
2022-05-19 13:41:37

*Thread Reply:* nm i was looking for cucumber-expressions rather than cucumber-cucumber-expressions

phebus
2022-05-19 13:42:27

*Thread Reply:* nope those links to github also fail

phebus
2022-05-19 13:48:06

*Thread Reply:* ok found someone already has a PR open here https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/pull/116

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/pull/116|#116 Return the expression source instead of nil>
<p><strong>ðŸ¤” What's changed?</strong></p> <p>When running <code>cucumber --format=stepdefs --strict --dry-run</code> we saw plenty of <code>nil</code>s where the step definition should have been.</p> <p>The <code>to_s</code> method referenced a non-existent instance variable <code>@source</code> instead of the <code>source</code> method.</p> <p><strong>ðŸ·ï¸ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>â€¢ ðŸ› Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes a defect)</p> <p><strong>ðŸ“‹ Checklist:</strong></p> <p>â˜‘ï¸Ž I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> â˜‘ï¸Ž I've changed the behaviour of the code â˜‘ï¸Ž I have added/updated tests to cover my changes.</p>
Comments
2

<a href="https://github.com/aurelien-reeves">@aurelien-reeves</a>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-expressions">cucumber/cucumber-expressions</a>
luke
2022-05-20 00:54:48

*Thread Reply:* I've just approved this and ran CI for it.

ðŸŽ‰ Jo Laing

ðŸ‘Œ AurÃ©lien Reeves
Steve Kirkland
2022-07-06 01:07:24

We tag some scenarios to conditionally skip them: Before('@skip') do |scenario| skip_this_scenario("Skipping scenario") end The problem I have is that we have some After hooks that are still run for skipped scenarios. How can I determine in the hook if the scenario was skipped? The Cucumber::Core::Test::Case thatâ€™s passed doesnâ€™t seem to have that information.

luke
2022-07-06 02:53:23

@Steve Kirkland check the scenario status.

luke
2022-07-06 02:53:59

if test_case.failed? - Checks the failed state only.

luke
2022-07-06 02:58:30

If your state isn't in a handy helped (I cannot remember, but I know 100% that all status aren't made into helpers). Then check the verbose output. Which is a symbol representation of state.

test_case.status #=&gt; %i[passed failed unknown skipped pending flaky undefined]

Steve Kirkland
2022-07-06 03:00:29

ok, thereâ€™s a test_case.status that looks like it will work - thanks.

Steve Kirkland
2022-07-06 03:00:43

Shouldnâ€™t that be on https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/cucumber-core/Cucumber/Core/Test/Case though?

luke
2022-07-06 08:12:11

it's not quite that simple. But possibly.

luke
2022-07-06 08:14:17

Basically the result is dynamic. As such we use a dynamic class called RunningTestCase this then creates another "new" class as the result because a result has a bunch of methods used in the formatter/s

luke
2022-07-06 08:14:51

a quick hacky way in a console of checking what you "can" do on an object in ruby is to do the following

(foo.methods - Object.methods).sort

luke
2022-07-06 08:15:03

this will return all defined methods on foo in a nice sorted array

luke
2022-07-06 08:16:23

status is updated dynamically with another class set to the result param here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/blob/9b3c892c4056240be6542be05a2df6b5062b68e9/lib/cucumber/core/test/runner.rb#L46-L83

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/blob/9b3c892c4056240be6542be05a2df6b5062b68e9/lib/cucumber/core/test/runner.rb | runner.rb>
<pre><code> class RunningTestCase def initialize @timer = Timer.new.start @status = Status::Unknown.new(Result::Unknown.new) end def execute(test_step, &amp;amp;continue) status.execute(test_step, self, &amp;amp;continue) end def result status.result(@timer.duration) end def failed(step_result) @status = Status::Failing.new(step_result) self end def passed(step_result) @status = Status::Passing.new(step_result) self end def pending(message, step_result) @status = Status::Pending.new(step_result) self end def skipped(step_result) @status = Status::Skipping.new(step_result) self end def undefined(step_result) failed(step_result) self end </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
luke
2022-07-06 08:19:03

Then we include these checks https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/blob/main/lib/cucumber/core/test/result.rb#L38

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/blob/main/lib/cucumber/core/test/result.rb | result.rb>
<pre><code> include Result.query_methods :unknown </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
luke
2022-07-06 08:21:42

I'm about to dash off for a few days so probably can't help more than that. Hope that's enough to whet your appetite until I return.

Martin Phillips
2022-07-06 13:48:46

As a possible alternative, we make the skipping happen before the tests are called by passing -t "not @skip" to the cucumber command. I think what you are doing here is waiting till the tests are called and then calling the skipthisscenario method (I may be completely wrong here, but that's what we do and it seems to work.

ðŸ‘:skin_tone_2: matt-SmartBear
Marwa Hatamleh
2022-07-11 10:51:29

@Marwa Hatamleh has joined the channel

luke
2022-07-13 01:24:48

@Martin Phillips just depends on your use case. If you need to dynamically skip then you need to wait until inside.

Steve Kirkland
2022-08-03 03:22:01

I have a bunch of feature files, each with multiple Scenarios in. Whatâ€™s the easiest way to make one of them run first (that will survive adding/removing scenarios/features over time)? The best I can think of is to put the single scenario in a separate file, in a separate subfolder.

matt-SmartBear
2022-08-12 11:01:19

*Thread Reply:* Why do you need to do that?

Steve Kirkland
2022-08-12 14:53:17

*Thread Reply:* Itâ€™s a fair question - normally it shouldnâ€™t matter what order tests are run in.

We run tests on mobile devices. We also deliberately crash the app several times, which we believe can put the phone OS into a â€œmore sensitiveâ€ state, causing some particular types of tests to behave differently and fail. We were therefore looking to run those test types first, before we start crashing it all over the place.

In general of course you want tests to be completely independent, but to do that weâ€™d have to run a full clean cycle on the mobile, which takes a lot of time (overall far too much time for the number of tests we have).

Because itâ€™s such a niche situation, we just settled for numbers our feature files on this occasion.

matt-SmartBear
2022-08-12 20:24:59

*Thread Reply:* I think I would probably do that one in a separate run of Cucumber, and use tags to exclude it from the main run.

matt-SmartBear
2022-08-12 20:25:33

*Thread Reply:* Ordering your tests in the main run is a bit of a slippery slope.

Robert Reif
2022-08-25 05:32:33

@Robert Reif has joined the channel

Robert Reif
2022-08-25 05:46:55

Hey ho! can someone here give me a hint on how to change/overwrite a step result within the AfterStep hook?

The problem: I need to compare 2 documents. Dependent on the date it can happen, that both files are slightly different in a few places. As the scenarios in which these comparisons happen are extremely long, it would be helpful to let those small differences slip and continue with executing the rest of the scenario. The idea is to compare everything else of the document content but rather than just letting the test pass (in case that â€œblurryâ€ comparison was successful) to give an indication via result, that some manual review for a specific documents needs to be done

Martin Phillips
2022-08-25 05:56:37

Not an expert, but if you can make your 'blurry comparison' not raise an error when it doesn't quite match, you could set a variable, and then in the 'After' hook, check that variable and only fail then. We do that with checking for javascript errors on every page - if we have things being 'strict', it fails immediately in the step, if we are being nice, we wait till the 'After' hook before blowing up

Martin Phillips
2022-08-25 06:04:40

*Thread Reply:* ```Given /^I blurry check the document$/ do case blurrycheck when 0 # everything ok when 1 raise 'document check failed totally' when 2 @blurrychecknottotally_ok = true end end

After do |scenario| raise 'Blurry check was dodgy' if @blurrychecknottotallyok end```

Martin Phillips
2022-08-25 06:05:31

*Thread Reply:* Note - I'm really not an expert - not sure how sensible it is to use @ variables like this, and there may be a better way built into Cukes.

Robert Reif
2022-08-25 06:10:54

*Thread Reply:* as I already have an indicating variable in place this approach would absolutely work, thanks for the suggestion!

originally my idea was to avoid a hard failstatus and go with something more yellowâ€™ish like pending or unknown but yeah, after all that is just glitter to make it more convenient to differentiate for people ðŸ˜„

Martin Phillips
2022-08-25 06:12:44

*Thread Reply:* We have the same concept, but implemented in Jenkins - we find there are often intermittent failures / timing problems, so we make use of Cukes' rerun failed scenarios capability, - if the main run fails, but the rerun passes, we set Jenkins to show the build as 'yellow' rather than green - but it's better than red!

Martin Phillips
2022-08-25 06:16:49

*Thread Reply:* often, the 'glitter' can make management much les upset, even when it doesn't really change anything ðŸ™‚

brasmusson
2022-08-25 06:16:55

*Thread Reply:* A TestStep and its AfterStep-hook are two distinct test steps both with their own results. When the TestStep finished (before the AfterStep-hook has started) it will send an TestStepFinished message with the result. The AfterStep-hook will send its own TestStepFinished message (for the execution of the AfterStep-hook-TestStep), but it cannot change the result of the TestStep as its TestStepFinished message has already been sent.

Robert Reif
2022-08-25 06:18:51

*Thread Reply:* alright, that makes sense

Elin Pendered
2022-09-30 04:07:49

@Elin Pendered has joined the channel

phebus
2022-10-27 13:45:57

anyone running cucumber tests on circlci and have a solution to be able to use their parallelism by splitting tests by timing?

Steve Kirkland
2022-10-27 13:57:54

*Thread Reply:* We use Buildkite rather than CircleCI and Iâ€™m not sure if this is massively helpful - but we achieve a rough level of parallelism by using the --exclude option to split them into batches. Itâ€™s pretty rough, but hereâ€™s an example fwiw! https://github.com/bugsnag/bugsnag-cocoa/blob/master/.buildkite/pipeline.full.yml#L29

Would be interested to see if anyone contributes a better idea that we could make use of.

<https://github.com/bugsnag/bugsnag-cocoa/blob/master/.buildkite/pipeline.full.yml | pipeline.full.yml>
<pre><code> - "--exclude=features/[e-z].**.feature$" </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/bugsnag/bugsnag-cocoa">bugsnag/bugsnag-cocoa</a>
phebus
2022-10-28 06:22:12

Andrew Premdas
2022-12-06 04:16:01

Andrew Premdas
2022-12-06 04:17:07

Iâ€™m a little puzzled about how to deal with this, does anyone have any suggestions?

Andrew Premdas
2022-12-06 05:12:25

Following on from above

The issue is due to CUCUMBERCOLORS being defined in one environment but not another. There is a bug in the current release of Cucumber 8.0.0 which has been fixed by PR1641 in cucumber:main but has not been released. This bug causes Cucumber to crash on loading if run in an environment where CUCUMBERCOLORS is set. The PR to fix this was merged 6months ago. We need a point release to get this out

luke
2022-12-15 05:44:46

I still need to get around to getting some time on the multi-releasing. I've been a bit distracted last month owing to losing my job but I'll try get back on things in the new year.

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-12 10:48:55

hello everyone good afternoon how are you? In my project there are some tests that cannot be executed in parallel because one test can affect the other at runtime, the problem is that I use the parallel cucumber to run, has anyone here gone through something similar?

phebus
2023-01-12 11:19:10

probably not the answer you want but you just shouldnâ€™t have tests that affect other tests. is there a way to decouple them?

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-12 11:38:29

yes, it shouldnâ€™t exist, but as they are legacy and the system has a single means of configuration, if two tests that change the same configuration run at the same time, itâ€™s already a problem, Iâ€™m looking for a way to separate them.

phebus
2023-01-12 11:49:26

well by default the parallel gem runs the parallelism at the feature file level. if you put the tests that mess with the same config file in the same feature file then they will run in sequence

phebus
2023-01-12 11:49:59

if youâ€™re running the parallelism at the scenario level then iâ€™m not sure how to mitigate that

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-12 11:54:45

in this case, so if they are all in the same file or feature will they run in sequence?

phebus
2023-01-12 12:32:35

yes feature files are run sequentially

luke
2023-01-13 01:27:38

are you operating on the same single codebase/db. Because the parallelism shards them into separate threads.

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-13 04:59:59

yes in the same code

luke
2023-01-16 01:32:38

right, so each thread will be independent and won't affect each other.

If you have code that operates on a centrally deployed db then you need to amend your tests to use new data for writing based scenarios (creation/modification of data for example).

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-16 04:18:47

*Thread Reply:* right

Andrew Premdas
2023-01-23 07:04:09

Hey there fellow cukers. I was wondering if anyone had done any cuking with Rails 7 and Turbo, in particular dealing with things like broadcasts. What Iâ€™d ideally like to do is have one scenario opening two or more browsers with different sessions/users so we can see what happens users interacting with things causes broadcasts that should affect other users. If anyone has any ideas how to get this wired up Iâ€™d appreciate it. Iâ€™m using cucumber-rails and capybara.

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-23 08:31:39

*Thread Reply:* Hi, you can use threads, opening a thread for each execution of the cucumber

Andrew Premdas
2023-01-23 08:33:47

*Thread Reply:* Could you expand on your answer. You seem to be suggesting I need multiple executions of cucumber, but actually I think I want a single execution of a cucumber scenario opening multiple browsers.

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-23 08:51:57

*Thread Reply:* So, when it comes time to open the browser and execute the actions, you could use the native resource of ruby as threads, opening a thread for each browser and executing the actions, after finishing, close the thread and you will have your result in the thread of main execution

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-23 08:54:31

*Thread Reply:*

Andrew Premdas
2023-01-23 08:56:16

*Thread Reply:* Thats a reasonable theory. Have you done it in practice? There is quite a bit of trickery going on when running Cucumber in Rails, and your proposal relies on all that trickery being thread safe.

Charlan Bettiol
2023-01-23 08:59:36

*Thread Reply:* I used this to create a runtime counter for each thread fired from the parallelo cucumber, where each instance of parelello created launches a thread that counts the runtime when the value is reached it terminates the execution and the thread.

luke
2023-01-24 01:15:19

*Thread Reply:* I was going to suggest something similar, using threads to control the ivars for the browsers.

But again as you explain, i've never done it in practice. But in theory that's how I'd do it.

phebus
2023-01-24 12:45:33

hey so iâ€™m trying to set something up where we pause between each step and wait for the user to hit enter before moving on to the next step. currently itâ€™s accomplished through an afterstep, but iâ€™d like to implement it with an event listener that is triggered on the :test_step_finished . i have it working but the pause (accomplished through $stdin.getc ) doesnâ€™t print the step that has been paused on to the console until after the user hits enter. iâ€™d like the step to print to the console before waiting for the user input. iâ€™ve tried flushing various buffers ($stdout, config.out_stream) to no avail. from looking at the pretty print formatter it looks like it should already be printing before the pause but iâ€™m not seeing it. anyone have any ideas?

luke
2023-01-25 01:39:50

Are you editing the listener in cucumber-ruby-core. I have never done this but I know in there is some good stuff.

phebus
2023-01-25 06:48:55

iâ€™m using the method outlined in cucumber/events.rb ```Events tell you what's happening while Cucumber runs your features. They're designed to be read-only, appropriate for writing formatters and other output tools. If you need to be able to influence the result of a scenario, use a {RbSupport::RbDsl hook} instead. To subscribe to an event, use {Cucumber::Configuration#on_event}
Examples:

InstallPlugin do |config|
config.onevent :testcasefinished do |event|
puts event.result
end
end so i have this in a hook file: InstallPlugin do |config| config.onevent :teststepfinished do |event| next unless ENV['STEP'] next if event.test_step.hook?

$stdin.getc

end end``` and it works great, itâ€™s just that step isnâ€™t printed to the console when it gets to capturing STDIN so you donâ€™t know which step youâ€™re stopped on or if youâ€™ve actually stopped.

currently weâ€™re using an afterstep like this, which prints the step before pausing: ```AfterStep do |_scenario| next unless ENV['STEP']

$stdin.getc end``` however the one drawback is it wonâ€™t pause on a failed step, but using the event listener will

luke
2023-01-25 09:02:28

remember puts was deprecated in favour of log

luke
2023-01-25 09:02:37

because puts was overridden historically in cucumber, but now it isn't.

phebus
2023-01-25 09:04:06

thatâ€™s just the example in cucumber/events.rb. my code is the next block, sorry for the confusion

luke
2023-01-25 09:19:14

ah right. So your using identical code, and in one place it dumps the name of the step and the other one it doesn't. Hmm odd.

luke
2023-01-25 09:19:26

I would have expected neither to dump the name to be honest.

phebus
2023-01-25 09:27:06

not completely, one is an afterstep, and one is this installplugin event listener registration thing. maybe the event listener version doesnâ€™t print the step since it is meant to trigger whether the step passes or fails and maybe the printing of the step to the console is part of the same code that then fails the run?

phebus
2023-01-25 09:28:19

sorry if i confused things by posting the example code from the cucumber gem. i wanted to reference it for clarity on where i found it. i stumbled on this through some googling, it doesnâ€™t seem to be in any of the docs on cucumber.io

luke
2023-01-25 09:33:31

not a problem. I helped write some of these docs with aurelien ðŸ˜„

luke
2023-01-25 09:34:18

When I said identical code. I meant inside th bodies of the block. You don't do puts 'abc' in one and not the other for example.

phebus
2023-01-25 09:36:31

oh right, yeah the printing of the step is just what is coming naturally from cucumber

brasmusson
2023-01-25 10:59:06

A) As the concept of event is fundamentally asynchronous, using an event listener may work right now, but if/when cucucmber-ruby implements parallel execution natively, it is likely that the execution continues also when an event listener is waiting for user input.

B) If I'm correct that the step printing you are missing is the one coming from the pretty formatter, it is likely not printed because your event listener is invoked before the event listener of the pretty formatter. You cannot rely on a specific order of event listener invokations, any sequence, or indeed parallelism, of the order event listeners for the same event are invoked should be considered as an internal implementation detail.

phebus
2023-01-25 11:19:58

great, thank you for the details, that makes sense

Paul Pham
2023-02-10 00:48:42

@Paul Pham has joined the channel

MarkSweetlove
2023-02-21 03:08:25

Hi. Inside a formatter, is there an easy way of knowing if the current test_case is running because of the --retry flag? Is there an example of a formatter that currently handles retry well in cucumber ruby? Thanks ðŸ™‚

luke
2023-02-21 05:42:34

there is a property inside the pickle of what execution number you're on. I'm not sure of any formatters that directly grab that prop though

MarkSweetlove
2023-02-21 07:30:47

Thanks. Any idea how iâ€™d get the pickle from the event testcase? I assume iâ€™d use the astlookup somehow. Is it documented anywhere?

brasmusson
2023-02-22 00:32:02

If there is a property on the pickle, it should also be on the testcase, as a testcase is a pickle decorated with hooks and step definition mappings.

Charlan Bettiol
2023-03-02 09:38:22

phebus
2023-03-03 08:17:36

*Thread Reply:* not quite sure what youâ€™re saying but the after hook happens when the test ends, either by reaching the end of the scenario or failing earlier in the test so the screenshot will happen whenever the test ends. if the test ends because of a failure on the previous screen/step, then the screenshot will happen then

Charlan Bettiol
2023-03-03 08:26:09

*Thread Reply:* the problem is that it captures before the tests are finished, but I think the print is in the wrong place, it must be inside ensure.

phebus
2023-03-03 08:27:55

*Thread Reply:* it canâ€™t capture before the tests are finished because an after hook will not trigger before the test is finished

phebus
2023-03-03 08:28:31

*Thread Reply:* if the test finished because of an error before the end of the test then it will take a screenshot then

Charlan Bettiol
2023-03-03 08:29:34

*Thread Reply:* but in this case it is happening, if you put a sleep before the 5 second print it captures the right screen, if you donâ€™t put it it takes the wrong screen

phebus
2023-03-03 08:30:59

*Thread Reply:* then thereâ€™s more about how your tests run that i donâ€™t know about to be able to help. i have my screenshot taken at the end of the tests, not in an ensure, and it works (although i only screenshot on failure).

2023-11-15 22:12:34

2023-11-17 02:26:14

2023-11-15 06:47:14

luke
2023-11-15 06:51:39

Before do |test_case| p test_case.name p (test_case.methods - Object.methods).sort end

2023-11-15 06:51:44

Wirak Lim

@Wirak Lim has joined the channel

Charlie Alderete
2023-12-18 09:03:37

Hello all ðŸ‘‹ I had a question about the hexagonal architecture of cucumber. I am wondering how the implementation of this architecture is done for the cucumber project, for instance, is the cucumber-core module at the center? Or some other modules like glue ? And what modules make up the "edges" of the architecture?

TYIA!

brasmusson
2023-12-19 04:13:41

*Thread Reply:* I'm not sure that one could say that cucumber-ruby implements the hexagonal architecture. The most common reference for hexagonal architecture in relation to cucumber is about stating that hexagonal architecture provides testability (https://cucumber.io/docs/guides/testable-architecture/), which is beneficiary for apps you want to test with cucumber.

Charlie Alderete
2023-12-19 07:02:40

*Thread Reply:* I see thank you. The reference I saw was in the readme Cucumber Core is the inner hexagon for the Ruby flavour of Cucumber.

Maybe this should be updated to clearly reference testing architecture?

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core

cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core
Core library for the Ruby flavour of Cucumber

Wirak Lim
2023-12-18 09:05:37

Does anyone know whether cucumber-ruby captures scenario start time in JSON output? With the message formatter I can see timestamp fields in the resulting NDJSON file, but those fields do not appear in the JSON output. I've tried both the built-in json formatter as well as the Cucumber Standalone JSON Formatter.

brasmusson
2023-12-19 04:10:26

*Thread Reply:* It seems that you have answered your question yourself. Since the timestamp is part of the output of the message formatter, you could write a custom json formatter that includes the timestamps, but the current json formatter you mention does not include timestamp (only duration IIRC).

Stephan KÃ¤mper
2024-04-16 23:49:45

Hi all, it looks like Iâ€™ll have to update quite a few feature files: Things that were independent objects are turned into options of other things â€“ which means that steps need to be rewritten (sometimes replacing one Gherkin line with two, sometimes keeping track of parameters used in one step and reuse them in a later ones, sometimes changing entries in example tables); oh and any comments, cucumber tags, backgrounds etc. should be kept. Now, I donâ€™t feel like writing a Gherkin parser and wonder if itâ€™s possible to access the lines in a feature file from within a step definition. If that were possible, I could rewrite the feature file with Cucumber. Is that a good (or possible to implement) idea? Is it stupid? Has it been done before? â€” Or might I be better off with some tailor-made script?

luke
2024-04-17 02:53:51

Hi @Stephan KÃ¤mper - I'm not entirely sure what you're asking here sorry. It feels like I've missed part of the conversation.

So the cucumber tests run inside a construct called the "World" in essence, this is a single instance of a class that naturally will store instance variable state.

So I've just written a test that does this. (I've ommitted lots of stuff but you get the gist).

luke
2024-04-17 02:54:07

``` Scenario: The conference description is visible in the Conference Details Card When I add a conference description for the conference Then the description in the Conference Details Card can be seen by attendees And the description in the Conference Details Card can be seen by admins

steps

When('I add/amend a/the conference description for the conference') do @newconferencedescription = @app.conferencesetupdescription.updatedescription # iVar defined here @app.conferencesetup_description.continue.click end

Then('the description in the Conference Details Card can be seen by {word}') do |user_type| # complex stuff here....

expect(@app.dashboard.conferencedetailscard(wait: 5).description.text).to eq(@newconferencedescription) #iVar interrogated here

# To remove user state so the next user loads legitimately @app.dashboard.logout if user_type == 'attendees' end```

luke
2024-04-17 02:56:27

If you need access to things like comments / cucumber tags e.t.c. - You can observe them in them in various locations.

Scenario tags can be interrogated in the hooks. Then you can store them in a class to access later. I often did this when I worked at a previous company because certain assertions only worked if the screen size was small e.t.c.

Matthias Carell
2024-04-17 11:28:22

@Stephan KÃ¤mper maybe youâ€™re looking for something like this https://github.com/enkessler/cuke_modeler?

Stephan KÃ¤mper
2024-07-07 04:00:22

Thanks for all the hints. In the end I wrote a small tool special tailored for this problem of this project.

Last updated

Stephan KÃ¤mper
2024-07-07 10:02:44

*Thread Reply:* Oh. I figured out, well, something: If I have the gem rspec-expectations installed and then run cucumber without the Bundler context I get this error. Iâ€™m still a bit puzzled about this, but at least can avoid the situation. Is that because Cucumber uses RSpec expectations by default?

luke
2024-07-08 03:18:21

*Thread Reply:* by default cucumber is configured to use rspec expectations when you are asserting inside the World construct. Which is what you "should" be doing.

luke
2024-07-08 03:19:23

*Thread Reply:* Predominantly I use capybara and cucumber, which does a lot of the autoloading for me. I am not sure if you're using capybara/watir or something else entirely.

luke
2024-07-08 04:03:50

*Thread Reply:* Also one thing to bear in mind is it could be the way you've installed the gems.

Stephan KÃ¤mper
2024-07-08 04:11:31

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the answers! For this particular project, itâ€™s a command line tool. For now, Iâ€™m only surprised that the NoMethodError is raised even though I added the needed accessor & assertions to World. Well, Iâ€™m still not sure Iâ€™m doing it the right way, but either way find it strange the in a bundler context this work nicely, but outside I get this exception if rspec-expectations are installed.

luke
2024-07-08 04:13:54

*Thread Reply:* the reason for bundler vs non bundler context is because of how gems are installed via or not from bundler./
